seg.output: We give thanks, most illustrious prince, in the name of all pious people, that for many years now, especially in the recent days at Schvinfordiae and then at Norinbergae, you have so valiantly defended our cause, which is not ours, but that of our Lord Christ, against those who wished to see our doctrine, which they call Zuinglian, proscribed. You have seen, with that wisdom which you have been granted by the highest prince, God, that it is not a human doctrine which is proscribed, but the truth of God, which Zuinglius has proclaimed most piously and heartily to the whole world. Therefore we congratulate you here, most pious prince, on that remarkable wisdom and constancy which you possess, and we thank our most benign God that he has given you a fair judge and defender for our cause. We pray to him incessantly that he will confirm what he has begun and increase his gifts to you, that he will grant you a secure reign, a safe home, a strong army, a faithful senate, a virtuous and obedient people, holy and truthful prophets, and that he will keep you safe and on the path of truth for a long time.

seg.output: We give thanks to you, most illustrious prince, in the name of all the pious, that you have stoutly defended our cause, nay not ours but the cause of Christ our Lord, for many years already, and especially in recent days both at Schvinford and then at Norinberg, against those who wished to proscribe us and our doctrine which they call Zuinglian. For you have seen with your acute wisdom, which you have received from the supreme Prince, God, that it is not a doctrine of man which is proscribed, but the truth of God, which Zuinglius has preached as devoutly and as sincerely to the whole world. Therefore, mindful of the words of the Apostle which he addressed to his Timothy, saying, “Be not ashamed of the testimony of our Lord nor of me his prisoner” [2 Tim 1,8], you have not consented to the proscription of the truth under any pretext of human authority. Wherefore we congratulate you here too, most pious prince, on your excellent wisdom and constancy, and we give thanks to our most gracious God that He has appointed you a judge and guardian of our cause. We also pray Him without ceasing that He may confirm and increase His gifts in you, that He may grant you a secure kingdom, a safe home, brave armies, a faithful senate, a virtuous and obedient people, holy and true prophets, and that He may keep you for us for a long time and preserve you in the way of truth. For we know that without the special influence of the divine spirit the piety of princes is weak, so that we may now ascribe all that is done for us through you to the divine goodness, which uses you and your service, as a honourable vessel, for the glory of His Name in His house. We do not write this that we may think that the cause of truth can neither fail nor stand without your or other princes’ consent, for we have already learned that truth itself is invincible and immortal, and that by it not only princes but all the kingdoms of the world are preserved, and that whatsoever praise or blame, benefit or harm, princes possess, arises either from the cultivation or neglect of truth.

We give thanks to you, most illustrious prince, in the name of all pious people, for bravely defending our cause, not ours, but of the Lord Christ, for many years already, and especially in the recent days in Schwinfurt first and then in Nuremberg, against those who wanted to proscribe us and our teachings which they call Zwinglian. For you have seen with that sharp wisdom, which you have been endowed with by the highest prince God, that it is not human teaching that should be proscribed, but the truth of God which Zwingli has preached with both piety and courage to the whole world. Therefore, mindful of the words of the Apostle when he speaks to Timothy and says: “Do not be ashamed of the testimony of our Lord, nor of me His prisoner” [2 Tim 1,8], you have refused to proscribe the truth under any pretext of human name. Therefore, we also congratulate you here, most pious prince, for that great wisdom and constancy which is in you, and we give thanks to our most gracious God that He has given you a fair and just judge and protector for our cause. We pray Him incessantly with our prayers that He will confirm what He has begun and increase His gifts in you, and grant you a secure kingdom, a safe home, strong armies, a faithful senate, a virtuous and obedient people, holy and true prophets, and keep you safe and in the way of truth for us for a long time. We know that without a special breath of divinity, the piety of princes is weak, that is why we offer up to divine goodness all that is being done for us through you, which uses you and your ministerial vessel for the glory of His name in His house. For we do not write this, thinking that the work of truth cannot be done or preserved without your or other princes’ consent, for we have already learned that truth itself is invincible and immortal, by which not only princes but all the kingdoms of the world are preserved, and whatever praise or blame, benefit or harm princes have, it all comes from either the worship or neglect of truth. For what is more evident than what Christ said “I receive not testimony from man” [John 5,34]? And what is more clear than what the prophet wrote: “Do not trust in princes, nor in any man, in whom there is no salvation. Let the wrath of the Lord be poured out upon them, and let their fire be kindled” [Ps 146,3-4]?

Therefore we also congratulate you here, most pious prince, on that excellent prudence and constancy which is in you, and we thank our most kind God that He has given to us you as a fair judge and defender of our cause. We pray him with ceaseless prayers that he will confirm what He has begun, and increase his gifts in you, grant a safe kingdom, a secure home, brave armies, a faithful senate, a pious and obedient people, holy and true prophets, and preserve you for us long and safe in the way of truth. seg.output: We thank you most illustrious prince, on behalf of all pious people, for defending our cause – not only ours but that of Christ the Lord – for many years, and especially in the recent days, first in Schvinford and then in Norinberg, against those who wanted to proscribe us and our so-called Zuinglian doctrine. For you have seen with the acumen that the Most High God has given you that it is not a human doctrine that should be proscribed but rather the truth of God preached by Zuinglius as devoutly and faithfully as he did to the entire world. In memory of the words of the Apostle, in which he addresses Timothy and says, "Do not be ashamed of the testimony about our Lord or of me his prisoner" [2 Tim 1:8], you have not allowed truth to be proscribed under any pretext of human name. Therefore we congratulate you here too, most pious prince, for your excellent prudence and constancy and we give thanks to our most gracious God that He has given us an equitable judge and protector in you. And we pray ceaselessly to Him that He will confirm what He has started and grant you increase in His gifts, a secure kingdom, a safe home, brave troops, a faithful senate, a good and obedient people, holy and truthful prophets, and keep you safe and in the way of truth for us for a long time. For we know that it is only with a special divine inspiration that the piety of princes is preserved, so that we can accept that all this which is given to us through you is accepted by the divine goodness, which uses you and your service as an honorable vessel for the glory of His name in His house. We do not write this for the purpose of believing that the business of truth cannot exist or subsist without your or other princes' consent, for we have already learned that truth is invincible and immortal in itself, and by it alone, not only princes, but all the kingdoms of the world are preserved, and whatever praise or reproach, benefit or harm princes may have, it all arises from the worship or neglect of truth. For what is more evident than what Christ said, "I do not accept human testimony" [John 5:34]? What is more evident than what the prophet wrote, "Do not trust in princes or in any human, in whom there is no salvation. For when his spirit departs, he returns to the earth; then all his thoughts perish. But happy is he whose strength is in the God of Jacob, whose hope is in the Lord his God, who made heaven and earth, and whatever is in them, who keeps faith forever" [Ps 146:3-6]?

seg.output: We give you thanks, most illustrious prince, in the name of all pious people, that for many years you have defended our cause, nay not our cause, but the truth of Christ our Lord, especially in the past few days at Schvinfordia and then at Norinberg against those who would have our, what they call Zuinglian doctrine, proscribed. For you have seen, with that excellent prudence with which you are gifted by the highest prince God, that it is no human doctrine, but the truth of God which Zuinglius has preached piously and faithfully to the whole world. Therefore mindful of the words of the apostle, wherein he testifyeth to Timothy and saith, "Be not thou ashamed of the testimony of our Lord, nor of me his prisoner", [2 Tim. 1:8], you would not have the truth proscribed under any human pretext. Therefore we also congratulate you here, most pious prince, for your excellent prudence and constancy, and we give thanks to our most benign God, that he has given you a fair judge and defender for our cause. We beseech him with ceaseless prayers that he may confirm and increase his gifts in you, that he may grant you a secure kingdom, a safe home, strong armies, loyal senators, a good and obedient people, holy and true prophets, and preserve you long for us in the way of truth. For we know that without the singular inspiration of the Divinity, the piety of princes is feeble, that all which is granted us by you may be accepted as coming from divine goodness, which uses you and your ministerial vessel as an honourable vessel to the glory of his name in his house. We write this not because we think that the cause of truth cannot exist nor stand without your or other princes' consent, for we have already learned that truth itself is invincible and immortal, by which not only princes, but all the kingdoms of the world are preserved, and whatever honour or dishonour, profit or loss, princes have, it all arises either from the cult of truth or its neglect. For what is more clear than what Christ said, "I receive not testimony from man"? [John 5:34] And what more evident than what the prophet wrote, "Trust not in princes, nor in the son of man, in whom there is no salvation. His spirit goeth forth, he returneth to his earth; in that very day his thoughts perish. Happy is he that hath the God of Jacob for his help, whose hope is in the Lord his God, which made the heavens and the earth and the sea and all that is therein, which keepeth truth for ever. [Ps. 146:3-6] In the sacred histories we see that Saul, Ahab, Joas and Zedechiah, the chief enemies of truth, were troubled and nothing firm or safe throughout their life, and at last were even deprived of life and kingdom, with the slaughter of their own people: meanwhile truth, which they would have extinct, nevertheless remained perennial; but on the other hand we see David, Josaphat, Ezechias and Josias, the most faithful worshippers of truth, fearless in the midst of danger, tranquil in the greatest tumult, successfully and with the highest praise to conduct their affairs, and lastly to be rewarded with an eternal immortal glory by the faithful judge God.

Mindful of the words of the apostle in which he attests to Timothy and says: «Be not thou ashamed of the testimony of our Lord, nor of me his prisoner» [2 Tim 1,8], you would not have the truth proscribed under any name of man. Wherefore we too congratulate you, most pious prince, on that noble prudence and constancy that is in you, and we give thanks to our most benign God, who has given you as a fair judge and protector to our cause. We pray him incessantly that he may confirm what he has begun, and augment the gifts that he has given you, and that he may grant you a secure kingdom, a safe home, brave armies, a faithful senate, a good and obedient people, holy and true prophets, and preserve you long and safe on the path of truth. For we know that without a singular inspiration of the divine, the piety of princes is weak, that we may now bear all that is offered to us through you as acceptable to the divine goodness, whom you serve as an honourable vessel for the glory of his name. For we do not write this to suggest that the cause of truth could either cease or remain without your or other princes' consent, since we have long known that truth itself is invincible and immortal, and that not only princes, but all the kingdoms of the world are preserved by it, and whatever honour or dishonour, good or ill, that princes have, it all arises from either the worship or neglect of truth. For what is more open than what Christ said: «But I receive not testimony from man» [John 5,34]? What is more evident than what the prophet wrote: «Put not your trust in princes, nor in any children of men, in whom there is no safety» [Ps 146,3]?

seg.output: We give thanks to you, most illustrious prince, on behalf of all pious people, that you have vigorously defended our cause, nay not our cause, but that of Christ the Lord, for many years already, but especially in recent days at Schvinfordia and then at Norinberga against those who wanted to have us and our so-called Zuinglian doctrine proscribed. For you have seen with your sharp prudence, with which you are endowed by the highest prince, God, that it is not a human doctrine that is to be proscribed, but the truth of God, which Zuinglius has proclaimed with piety no less than with courage to the whole world. Therefore, mindful of the words of the Apostle, by which he admonishes Timothy his disciple and says, “Be not ashamed of the testimony of our Lord, nor of me his prisoner,” [2 Tim 1: 8], you were not willing that the truth should be proscribed under any pretext of human authority. Therefore, we also congratulate you here, most pious prince, for that admirable prudence and constancy which is in you, and we give thanks to our most gracious God, that he has given you a fair judge and protector for our cause. We pray him, moreover, with incessant prayers, that he may confirm what he has begun, and increase upon you his gifts, a secure dominion, a safe home, valiant armies, a faithful senate, a dutiful and obedient people, holy and true prophets, and preserve you to us for a long time safe and on the way of truth. For we know that without a special inspiration of the divine, the piety of princes is too weak, that now we may ascribe all this, which is conferred upon us through you, to the divine goodness, which uses you and your ministry as an honorable vessel to the glory of its name in its house. For we do not write this, because we think that the business of truth cannot exist or stand without your or other princes' consent; for we have long since learned that the truth itself is invincible and immortal, by which not only princes, but all the kingdoms of the world are preserved, and whatever praise or blame, benefit or injury princes have, it all arises either from the worship of the truth or from its neglect. For what is more open than what Christ said, “For I receive not testimony from man?” [John 5: 34]? What is more evident than what the prophet wrote, “Trust not in princes, nor in any man, in whom there is no salvation. For when his breath departeth from him, he returneth to his earth; then all his thoughts perish. But happy is he, whose help is the God of Jacob, whose hope is in the Lord his God, who made heaven and earth, and all that is in them, who keepeth his faith for ever” [Psalms 146: 3-6]? In the sacred histories, too, we see Saul, Ahab, Joash and Zedekiah, the chief enemies of the truth, to be in danger, to be troubled, to have nothing that is safe or firm, and at last to be deprived of their own slaughter, life and kingdom, but meanwhile the truth which they wanted to extinguish, nevertheless to remain perennial, on the other hand, David, Jehoshaphat, Hezekiah and Josiah, the most faithful worshippers of the truth, to be fearless even in the midst of danger, to stand firm in the midst of tumult, to manage things happily and with great praise, and to be rewarded with eternal immortality by the faithful Judge. From which it appears that the truth itself is happy and immortal. For those who defend the truth, they are defended by it and enjoy many good things by its benefit. But those who attack it, they are deprived not only of happiness, but even of what they wanted to obtain.

Blessed is he that hath the God of Jacob for his help, whose hope is in the Lord his God: Who made heaven, and earth, the sea, and all that therein is: Who keepeth truth for ever” [Psalms 146:3-6]? We also see in the sacred histories that Saul, Ahab, Joas and Zedechias, the most notorious enemies of truth, were troubled and nothing was safe or firm for them throughout their lives, and ultimately they were stripped of their lives, their kingdom even by a shameful slaughter of their own people, while truth, which they wanted to extinguish, nevertheless remained perennial; on the other hand, David, Jehoshaphat, Hezekiah and Josiah, very faithful cultists of truth, were fearless even in the midst of dangers, remained tranquil in the midst of turmoil, managed their affairs successfully and with great honor, and finally were rewarded with eternal immortality by the most faithful Agonothetes. From which it is clear that truth itself is happy and immortal. For those who defend truth, they are indeed defended by it and enjoy many good things from it. But those who attack it, are not only deprived of happiness, but even what they wanted to achieve they do not achieve. For truth has remained unmoved since the beginning of the world against the insults of all tyrants. The heavenly Father has dealt kindly with you, most illustrious prince, who has instilled in you the zeal for truth and wanted to use you, as an honorable vessel, in His Church. Therefore, we hope that your piety will now do what is wisely done if you do not fail to the call and diligently cultivate truth in the fear of the Lord.
We are also aware of what our enemies reproach you with here, that our doctrine is inconstant, factious and heretical, and that we should be avoided as schismatic and seditious men. We know what kind of poisonous language and what calumnies they use to assail and defame us. But since you have so far done us justice as a spectator, we hope that you will not be unjust to us now with such reproach.

seg.output: Therefore, since the matter itself proclaims that the doctrine we follow is holy and true, it will be your duty, most illustrious Prince, not to abandon the truth and to be, as you are said to be, a Prince devoted to truth and justice, who is not only not provoked by the calumnies of the wicked against the innocent, but is not even deterred by dangers from the true and the just. For we know how much equipment of speaking, nay of jesting, the adversaries bring in order, that they may the more inconvenience our cause and boast the victory of their enemies. We know, I say, that some cry out that a factious man has been oppressed by the just judgment of God in a tumult, while others contend that his death is a most certain argument of heretical doctrine. But hear, O most clement Prince: he who was so much devoted to true peace, equity, justice and love of his country, could not have perished through a tumult. It is indeed usually the best rather than the worst who are oppressed by war and tumult. But I will not say more now in this matter in behalf of this man, whom I defend so far as he is connected with the cause of truth, and so connected as either to be serviceable or hurtful to truth. We acknowledge the saying of Paul, “Who is Cephas, or Paul, or Apollos, but ministers by whom ye believed?” [1 Cor 3:4-5].

[1 Cor 3:4-5].Nor shall I write more about the cause or the law of war, whether it was war or tumult, since you know nothing of this and since the most authoritative works of that kind, published before the calamitous defeat of our most illustrious Senate of Zurich, have been put into the light.Therefore, since the matter itself cries out that the doctrine which we follow is holy and true, it will be your part, most illustrious prince, not to abandon the truth and to be, as you are said to be, a prince dedicated to truth and justice, who not only is not irritated by the calumnies of the unjust against the innocent, but is not even deterred by dangers from the true and just.Finally, I shall add that whatever kind of death it was, it cannot prove or disprove either faith or doctrine.

seg.input: Ago tibi gratias, illustrissime princeps, communi omnium piorum nomine, quod caussam nostram, imo non nostram, sed Christi domini multis iam annis, maxime vero proximis diebus Schvinfordiae primum, deinde Norinbergae adversus eos strenue defenderis, qui nos et nostram quam Zuinglianam vocant doctrinam voluere proscriptam . Vidisti enim acri illa qua a summo principe deo donatus es prudentia non hominis proscribi doctrinam, sed dei veritatem, quam Zuinglius non minus pie quam cordate toti orbi praedicavit. Memor itaque verborum apostoli, quibus Timotheum suum contestatur et dicit: «Ne pudeat te testimonii domini nostri neque te pudeat mei, qui sum vinctus illius» [2 Tim 1,8], noluisti veritatem ullo humani nominis praetextu proscribi. Quapropter gratulamur hic quoque tibi, princeps piissime, de illa praeclara, quae in te est, prudentia et constantia et deo nostro patri benignissimo gratias agimus, quod te nostrae caussae dederit aequum et iudicem et tutorem. Illum, porro, indefessis ora- mus precibus, ut quod coepit, confirmet et dona sua in te augeat, imperium quoque securum, domum tutam, exercitus fortes, senatum fidelem, populum probum et obedientem, prophetas quoque sanctos et veraces tribuat et te nobis diu incolumem et in via veritatis conservet. Scimus enim absque singulari numinis afflatu tenuem esse principum pietatem, ut nunc id totum, quod per te nobis confertur, divinae bonitati feramus acceptum, quae te et tuo ministerio ceu honorifico vase ad gloriam nominis sui utitur in domo sua. Neque enim ista in hoc scribimus, quod veritatis negotium sine tuo aut aliorum principum consensu interiisse aut constare non posse censeamus, qui iam olim didicimus ipsam veritatem per se quidem esse invincibilem et immortalem , qua non principes solum, sed omnia regna mundi conserventur, et quicquid laudis vel vituperii, commodi vel incommodi principes habeant, id omne aut ex veritatis cultu aut neglectu oriri. Quid enim apertius, quam quod Christus dixit: «Ego vero ab homine testimonium non accipio» [Ioh 5,34]? Quid evidentius, quam quod propheta scripsit: «Nolite fidere principibus aut quoquam hominum, in quibus non est salus. Ab homine enim cum abit spiritus eius, redit ad terram suam. Tunc pereunt universae cogitationes eius. Foelicem autem eum, cuius robur est deus Iacob, cuius spes est ad dominum deum suum, qui coelos, terram ac mare condidit, et quicquid in eis est, qui fidem in perpetuum servat» [Ps 146,3-6]? In historiis quoque sacris videmus Saulem, Achab, Ioas et Zedechiam, praecipuos veritatis hostes, per omnem vitam periclitari, tumultuari, nihil satis tuti aut firmi habere et tandem foeda etiam suorum strage et vita et regno exui, interim vero veritatem, quam illi extinctam volebant, nihilominus perennem manere , contra vero Davidem, Iosaphat, Ezechiam et Iosiam, fidelissimos veritatis cultores, veritatis beneficio etiam in mediis periculis impavidos obdurare, in ipsis quoque tumultibus tranquillos perstare, foeliciter et summa cum laude res gerere et aeterna demum immortalitatis gloria a deo fidelissimo agonotheta munerari.
seg.output: We give you thanks, most illustrious prince, in the name of all pious people, for defending our cause, and not just ours, but the Lord Christ's, for many years already, particularly in recent days, first in Schvinfordia and then in Norinberga, against those who wanted to outlaw us and our doctrine, which they call Zuinglian. For you saw with that acute prudence which the supreme prince God has given you that it is not a human doctrine that is proscribed, but the truth of God, that which Zuinglius preached with as much piety as courage to the whole world. Mindful, then, of the words of the Apostle who admonishes Timothy and says, “Do not be ashamed of the testimony of our Lord or of me his prisoner” [2 Tim 1,8], you were unwilling that the truth should be proscribed on any pretext of human authority. We therefore congratulate you here too, most pious prince, on that admirable prudence and constancy of yours, and we give thanks to our most kind God, that he has granted you to us as a fair judge and protector. We further unceasingly pray to him, that he may confirm what he has begun and augment his gifts in you, that he may grant you a secure rule, a safe home, brave armies, a faithful senate, a good and obedient people, and holy and true prophets, and keep you safe and on the path of truth for a long time. We know that without the special inspiration of the divine, the piety of princes is weak, so that we may attribute all that is being granted to us through you to the divine goodness, which uses you and your ministry as an honourable vessel for the glory of its name in its house. We do not write this in the belief that the affair of truth can neither be lost nor established without your or other princes' consent, for we have already learned that the truth itself is invincible and immortal, and that it is by it that not only princes, but all kingdoms of the world are preserved, and that whatever praise or blame, advantage or disadvantage princes have, all of it arises from the worship or neglect of the truth. For what is more open than what Christ said, “I accept no testimony from a man” [John 5,34]? What is more evident than what the prophet wrote: “Do not trust in princes or in any human, in whom there is no salvation. For when his spirit departs he returns to the earth; then all his thoughts perish. But happy is the man whose strength is in God, whose hope is in the Lord his God, who created the heavens, the earth and the sea, and all that is in them, who keeps faith forever” [Ps 146,3-6]? In the sacred histories we also see Saul, Ahab, Joas and Zedekiah, the chief enemies of the truth, being put to the test, disturbed and having nothing secure or firm, and in the end being stripped of their life and kingdom even in a shameful slaughter of their own people; meanwhile the truth, which they wanted to extinguish, nonetheless remaining eternal, on the other hand David, Josaphat, Ezechias and Josias, the most faithful worshippers of the truth, even in the midst of dangers remaining undaunted, standing firm even in the midst of tumults, succeeding happily and with great praise, and being rewarded finally with eternal and immortal glory by their most faithful judge.

From this it is clear that truth itself is blessed and immortal. For those who defend truth are defended by it and enjoy many good things from it. But those who oppose it, not only are deprived of happiness, but they do not even achieve what they wanted.

seg.output: We give thanks to you, most illustrious prince, in the name of all pious people, that you have most strenuously defended our cause, not ours, but that of Christ the Lord, for many years, most especially in recent days at Schvinfordia and then at Norinberga against those who wished to proscribe us and our doctrine, which they call Zuinglian. For you have seen with that sharp prudence, with which you are endowed by the supreme prince God, that not the doctrine of men should be proscribed, but the truth of God, which Zuinglius proclaimed no less piously than with courage to the whole world. Therefore, mindful of the words of the apostle, in which he testifies to Timothy and says: "Be not thou ashamed of the testimony of our Lord, nor of me his prisoner" [2 Tim 1,8], you did not wish the truth to be proscribed under any pretext of human name. Therefore, we congratulate you here also, most pious prince, for that excellent prudence and constancy that is in you, and we give thanks to our most kind God, who has given you to be a just judge and protector of our cause. We pray him unceasingly with prayers that he may confirm what he has begun and augment his gifts in you, that he may also give a secure empire, a safe home, strong armies, a faithful senate, an upright and obedient people, holy and true prophets, and may keep you safe and on the path of truth for a long time. For we know that without the singular influence of the divine, the piety of princes is weak, so that we may ascribe all this that is given to us through you to divine goodness, which uses you and your ministerial vessel as a honorific vessel to the glory of its name in its house. For we do not write this because we think that the affair of truth cannot exist or stand without your or other princes' consent, for we have already learned that the truth itself is invincible and immortal, by which not only princes are preserved, but all kingdoms of the world, and whatever praise or blame, benefit or loss princes have, it all arises either from the worship of truth or from its neglect. For what is more evident than what Christ said: "For I receive not testimony from man" [John 5,34]? What more evident than what the prophet wrote: "Put not your trust in princes, nor in the son of man, in whom there is no safety. His spirit goeth forth, he returneth to his earth; in that very day his thoughts perish. In the sacred histories also we see Saul, Ahab, Joas and Zedekiah, the chief enemies of truth, to be in peril, to be in turmoil, to have nothing safe or firm, and at last even to be stripped of their lives, their kingdom and their posterity with a foul slaughter; meanwhile the truth, which they wished to be extinct, notwithstanding remaining perennial. On the other hand, we see David, Josaphat, Ezechias and Josias, the most faithful worshippers of truth, to be fearless amidst dangers, to stand tranquil in the greatest tumults, to manage their affairs happily and with great applause, and to be rewarded at last with an immortal crown of glory by the faithful Agonotheta. From which it is evident that truth itself is happy and immortal. For they that defend truth, are defended by it, and enjoy many benefits by it. But they that strive against it, are not only destitute of felicity, but cannot attain that which they desired. For truth, from the very beginning of the world, has remained unmoved against the insults of all tyrants, and has remained perpetual.

Gracious, therefore, has been the heavenly Father's dealing with you, most illustrious prince, who has instilled in you a love of truth and used you as an honorable vessel in His church.

Therefore God has dealt kindly with you, most illustrious prince, who has planted in you a love of truth, and would make use of you as an honorable vessel in His church. Wherefore now it will be your part of piety to answer to His call, and to serve the truth with fear of the Lord.
Nor do we not know what our enemies object against us to you, that our doctrine is inconstant, seditious, and heretical; and that we are to be avoided as schismatics and seditious men. We know with what virulent language, with what calumnies they load and defame us. But since you have hitherto done us the justice to be an impartial spectator, we hope that neither will you now be unjust to us with such reproaches.

We are not ignorant of what our enemies here accuse us of, that our doctrine is inconstant, factious and heretical, and that we should be avoided as schismatics and seditious men. We know with what virulent language and what calumnies they revile and rend us. But since you have hitherto afforded us an equitable spectator, we hope for the future that you will not be unjust to us even now with such reproaches. For H. Zwingli, of holy memory, our predecessor, has proved by many writings, and also the man of spotless life and incomparable learning, John Oecolampadius, that our doctrine is holy and true. Zwingli, of holy memory, our predecessor, has proved by many writings, and also the man of spotless life and incomparable learning, John Oecolampadius, that our doctrine is holy and true. We still keep the same doctrine, which we received from the sacred scriptures of God by their ministry, as the disciples of God, not of men, whose they were servants, yet unviolated. This we prove in my commentary on the Epistle to the Hebrews of Paul, and also in the very epistle of Paul. From which, if one were allowed to read, one would understand that we believe and preach nothing new, factious or heretical, concerning the primary subjects of our religion, such as the scripture, the testament and the law of God, the unity and trinity of God, Christ God and man, the mediator, priest and sacrifice, the true salvation and justification, the church, the call to the ministry of teaching, the true faith, the sacraments and the true worship of God, but wholly sound, catholic and orthodox.
Therefore, since the thing itself cries out that the doctrine which we follow is holy and true, it shall be your part, most illustrious prince, not to forsake the truth, and to remain, as you are said to be, consecrated to truth and justice, so that you may not only not be stirred up by the calumnies of the wicked against the innocent, but may not even be deterred from the true and just by danger. For Cicero thought that all praise belongs to him who holds that prudence without constancy is nothing.

seg.output: Therefore, since the matter itself proclaims that the doctrine which we follow is holy and true, it is your duty, most illustrious prince, not to desert the truth and, being devoted to truth and justice, not to be provoked by the calumnies of the wicked against the innocent, nor even to be deterred from what is true and just by danger. For Cicero thought that all praise was due to him who showed that prudence without constancy was nothing. Plato, in his treatise entitled Laches, thought that knowledge without justice, and the other virtues, was rather craft than wisdom. And certainly we do not doubt that so generous a mind as yours has been endowed with so much strength from heaven that it is not shaken by the disaster of our Cappellanus, nor by the unexpected death of our Zuinglius. For we know how much artifice of speaking, or rather of jesting, the adversaries make use of, whereby they render the cause of ours the more troublesome, and their own victory the more triumphant. We know, I say, that some cry out that a factious man was by the just judgment of God crushed in the tumult; others, that the death of this man is an undoubted argument of heretical doctrine. But hear, most clement prince: he could not have been destroyed on account of the tumult who was so extremely devoted to the true peace, equity, justice, and country. It is true that the best men are often oppressed by wars and tumults, not the worst. But I will say no more for this man's sake respecting this matter, inasmuch as I defend him so far as his cause is connected with the truth, and is so connected as to either benefit or hurt the truth. Besides, we acknowledge that saying of Paul, "Who is Cephas, or Paul, or Apollos, but ministers by whom ye believed?" [1 Cor 3:4f]. Nor will I write any more concerning the justice of the cause, whether it was a war or a tumult; partly because you know nothing of this, and partly because before the disaster befell us, the most principal of that kind were published by our most illustrious senate of Zurich. This I will add, that whatsoever death it be, it cannot either prove or disprove either faith or doctrine. For you may see that most impious men sometimes depart with the most prosperous fortunes, and again you may see the best of men extinguished by the most dishonorable kind of death among mortals. For Isaiah, the prince of all the prophets, being hewn asunder with a saw, died under Manasseh, the robber of the prophets.

seg.output: Therefore, since the matter itself cries out that the doctrine we follow is holy and true, it will be your part, most illustrious prince, not to abandon truth and to be, as you are said to be, a prince devoted to truth and justice, who is not only not moved by the calumnies of the wicked against the innocent, but is not even deterred by danger from the true and just.For Cicero certainly thought that all praise was due to that which was without constancy without wisdom.And Plato in that treatise, whose title is Laches, thought that knowledge without justice, and the other virtues, was rather cunning than wisdom.And indeed we do not doubt that this so generous spirit of yours is endowed with so much divine strength, that it is neither shaken by the misfortune of our chapel nor by the unexpected death of our Zuingli.For we know how much the adversaries, in order to the more disadvantage our cause and to the more advantage of the victory of our enemies, make use of an apparatus of speaking, nay of scoffing.We know, I say, that some loudly proclaim that a factious man was justly oppressed by a tumult, others contend that this death is a most certain argument of the heresy of his doctrine.But hear, most clement prince: he could not have died by reason of a tumult who was so loving of the true peace, equity, justice, and his country.For generally it is the best that are oppressed by war and tumult.But I will not say more in this matter concerning him, who defend a man so far as his cause is joined with truth, and so joined as either to benefit or discommode the truth.Let us consider the words of Paul: "What is Apollos, or what is Paul, but ministers, by whom ye believed?" [1 Cor. 3:4-5].Neither will I write any more of the cause, or of the right of war, whether it was war or tumult, seeing that you know nothing thereof, and that, before the received misfortune, the chiefest works of that kind were published by our most illustrious senate of Zurich.Only this I will add, that whatever death it was, it can neither prove nor disprove his faith or doctrine.For you may see the most impious men pass away with the most fortunate destiny, and again you may see the best of men extinguished by the most dishonourable kind of death among mortals.For Isaiah, the prince of all the prophets, being cut in pieces with a saw by the robber Manasseh, died.Jeremiah, the most constant of the prophets, and Zacharias, the most faithful of all, were stoned by the most wicked of men.What shall I say of John, the son of Zacharias, who was born of women none more holy than he, and of our chosen vessel Paul?The one by the advice of a most infamous harlot was even put to death in prison by Herod, the most impure of all mortals, and the other, as a disturber of the public peace, was beheaded by Nero, the most cruel of all that have been or are.And yet no man, unless the most impious, ever questioned the doctrine or life of them on account of their punishments.What shall I say of John, the son of Zacharias, who was born of women none more holy than he, and of our chosen seg.output: What further shall I mention John, the son of Zechariah, whom no other born of women was more holy, or our chosen vessel Paul? The former was slain in prison by the most impure Herod, even through the counsel of a most disgraceful harlot, and the latter was beheaded by the most cruel robber of all who was or ever had been, Domitius Nero, as a disturber of public peace. In the meantime, no one except the most impious, doubted the doctrine and life of these men on account of their punishments. Why then do these of ours, Zwingli, bring his death to the condemnation of his faith and doctrine, since it is sufficiently evident that nothing is desired of him by the pious? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? Likewise: "The time will come that whoever kills you will think that he does God service" [John 16:2]. seg.output: What else should I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, who was born holier than any other man by women, or our chosen vessel Paul? John was killed in prison by the most impure Herod due to the advice of a shameful harlot, while Paul, who was seen as a disturber of public peace, was beheaded by the most cruel tyrant of all those who are and were, Domitius Nero. In the meantime, no one but the most wicked has put into question their doctrine and life due to their sufferings. So why do these Zwinglians of ours attribute their death to the damnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is clear that there is nothing that the pious desire from them? Have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? Likewise: "A time will come when whoever kills you will think they are doing service to God" [John 16:2]. Do they not know that "we must enter the kingdom of God through many afflictions" [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world so that they will suffer nothing, always be pleasing, offend no one, enjoy delicacies, and promise safety to their followers in security? A truly new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, taking the hatred of all men upon themselves, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God" [Galatians 1:10]. And: "Those who want to make a good appearance in the flesh, they compel you to be circumcised, only that they may not suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Galatians 6:12]. If these people think otherwise, why, I ask, are we so despised, especially on the grounds that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, insulted, deprived of our substance, beaten and daily afflicted by the expectation of death?

seg.output: What more shall I mention about John, son of Zachariah, whom no other man born of women was holier, or about our vessel of election, Paul? The former was killed in prison by the most wicked of women, Herodias, at the instigation of the most impure of all, Herod, and the latter was beheaded by the most cruel of all tyrants, the robber Domitian, as if he were a disturber of the public peace. And yet none but the most impious have ever called in question the doctrine and life of these men on account of the punishments they suffered. Why then do these of ours, Zwinglians, draw the death of these men to the condemnation of their faith and doctrine, when it is plain that the godly desire nothing more in them? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" (John 15:20)? Or again: "The time cometh, that whosoever killeth you will think that he doeth God service" (John 16:2)? Or do they not know that "we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God" (Acts 14:21)? Or will they preach the gospel to the world so as to suffer nothing, to please all men, to give none offence, to take their pleasure, and to promise security to their followers? A novel way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles, for they, taking upon them the hatred of all men, cried out, "If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God" (Galatians 1:10). And "They that are of the flesh, who seek to please men in the flesh, compel you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" (Galatians 6:12). But if these men mean otherwise, why, I pray, are we so vilified, and especially on this account, that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, that we are loaded with reproaches, plundered of our substance, beaten, and daily expect death? Why do they threaten that even the survivors of that (as they call it) sect shall perish? As if they had found out a kind of doctrine to which he who adhereth shall be out of all danger of the dart.

seg.output: What more shall I mention about John, the son of Zachariah, the holiest of men born of women, and our chosen vessel Paul? John was killed in prison, at the advice of a most vile harlot, by the most impure Herod; and Paul, who disturbed the public peace, was beheaded by the most cruel of all tyrants, Domitian. Yet nobody but the most ungodly called into question their doctrine and life on account of their punishments. Why then do our Zwinglians draw his death to a damnation of his faith and doctrine, since it is evident that nothing but what is pious is desired of him? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20], and also: "It will come to pass that whoever kills you will think he is doing God a service" [John 16:2]. Or do they not know that "through many tribulations we must enter into the kingdom of God" [Acts 14:21]? Or do they preach the gospel so that they suffer nothing, please everyone, offend no one, enjoy delights, and promise security to their followers? That would indeed be a new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, inviting all men's hatred upon themselves, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God" [Galatians 1:10], and again: "They compel you to be circumcised, only that they may not suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Galatians 6:12]. If these men think differently, why then are we so despised, especially on account that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, disgraced, stripped of our goods, beaten and daily wait for death? Why do they daily threaten that even the survivors of this (as they call it) sect shall perish? As if they had found a kind of doctrine, to which whoever adheres may be safe from any danger. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not times that deserve gentleness and security, nor are we now such as can bear or will bear free truth. Since then we who are entrusted with the word agree so well with the world (for no one forbids the pious to be approved), it is to be feared that many things are done by us through flattery, and much more omitted through cowardly fear.

seg.output: What else should I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, who was born of no women more holy, and our vessel of election Paul? The former was struck down in prison by the most impure Herod, even the most cruel of all tyrants, Domitian Nero, cut off his head in the name of public peace. Or do they not know that "we must enter the kingdom of God through many afflictions" [Acts 14:21]? Or shall they preach the gospel to the world so that they suffer nothing, always please, offend no one, enjoy delicacies, and promise security to their followers? A new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, taking on the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we would not have been servants of God" [Galatians 1:10]. And: "Those who want to please in the flesh, they compel you to be circumcised, only so that they do not suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Galatians 6:12]. If they think differently, why, I pray, are we so despised, and especially on the grounds that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, insulted, stripped of our substance, beaten, and daily in fear of death? Why do they threaten that the survivors of his (as they say) sect will perish? As if they had found a kind of doctrine by which anyone who adheres to it will be safe from any form of attack. But believe me, most illustrious prince: these are not the times that deserve leniency and security, nor are we today those who can or want to bear free truth. So since it suits us preachers so well with the world (for no one forbids the pious to be approved), it is to be feared that many things will be done by us through flattery, and much more omitted through cowardly fear. And to speak freely with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will soon come to such a pass that we will wish that those whom we now devote to dire curses had been intercepted by the Capellan disaster, and that we might say that they were most fortunate, who had the courage to suffer for truth and country, what we, the miserable, will be forced to experience much more cruelly throughout Germany.

seg.output: What further shall I mention John, son of Zechariah, whom no other man born of women was more holy, or our vessel of election Paul? The former was struck down in prison by the most impure Herod, with the counsel of a most disgraceful harlot, and the latter, as an disturber of the public peace, was beheaded by the most cruel robber of all, Domitius Nero. Or will they preach the gospel to the world in such a way that they suffer nothing, always please, offend no one, enjoy delights, and promise security to their followers? A strange manner of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, bringing upon themselves the hate of all men, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we would not have been the servants of God" [Galatians 1:10]. And: "Those who want to please in the flesh, they compel you to be circumcised, only so that they may not suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Galatians 6:12]. But if they think differently, why, I ask, are we so vilified by them, especially on the grounds that we suffer affliction from the enemies of the truth, are subjected to insults, deprived of our possessions, beaten, and daily agonize in expectation of death? Why do they threaten daily that even those who survive of his (as they say) sect will also perish? As though they had found a kind of doctrine by which whoever adheres to it would remain outside the reach of all weapons. But believe me, most illustrious prince: These are not the times that deserve leniency and security, nor are we such today that we can or wish to bear free truth. Therefore, since it suits us who presume to speak the word so well with the world (for no one forbids the pious to be approved), it is to be feared that many things will be done by us through flattery and much more will be omitted through cowardly fear. And to speak freely with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will soon be such that we must wish ourselves, along with those whom we now doom to dire punishments, to have been intercepted by that Capellana disaster, and call them the most fortunate, to whom it was granted to bravely endure for truth and country what the wretched will be forced to experience in a much more cruel way throughout Germany. seg.output: Therefore, since the matter itself cries out that the doctrine we follow is holy and true, it is your part, most noble prince, not to desert the truth and, as you are said to be a prince devoted to truth and justice, not to be stirred up even by the calumnies of the wicked against the innocent, nor to be deterred by dangers from what is true and just. For truly Cicero thought that all praise of action was due to prudence without constancy. Plato in that treatise which bears the title Laches, thought that knowledge without justice and the other virtues was rather craft than wisdom. And certainly we do not doubt that so generous a soul as yours has been endowed with so much divine strength that it is not moved either by the calamity of our Capito or by the unexpected death of our Zwingli. For we know with what array of arguments, yea, of sophisms, the adversaries, the more to discomfit our cause, exult in the victory of their enemies. We know, I say, that some cry out that a factious man has been overcome by the righteous judgment of God in a tumult, while others contend that his death is a most certain argument of a heretical doctrine. But hear, most clement prince: He could not have perished because of a tumult, who was most devoted to true peace, equity, justice, and his country. It is commonly the best rather than the worst who suffer in war and tumult. But I will not now say more in his favor, who defend a man only in so far as it is connected with the cause of truth, and so connected that it either profits or injures truth. Elsewhere we acknowledge that Pauline saying: "What is Apollos, or Paul, or Cephas, but ministers by whom ye believed?" [1 Cor. 3:4-5]. Nor will I write more of the cause or right of war, whether it was war or tumult, since you are ignorant of none of these things, and since there was published before the received disaster by our most illustrious Senate of Zurich the most eminent treatise of that kind. I will add this, that whatever kind of death it was, it neither proves nor disproves faith or doctrine.

seg.output: Therefore, since the matter itself cries out that the doctrine we follow is sacred and true, it will be your duty, most illustrious prince, to not abandon the truth and be what you are said to be, a prince consecrated to truth and justice, who is not only not provoked by the calumnies of the wicked against the innocent, but is not even deterred by danger from the true and just. Truly, Cicero thought that all praise of an action would be lost if it lacked constancy. Plato in his treatise with the title Laches thought that knowledge without justice and the other virtues was rather cunning than wisdom. Nor do we doubt that such strength of spirit has been given to you by the divine power, that you will not be moved by the disaster of our chapel or the unexpected death of our Zuinglius. For we know with what eloquent and indeed mocking apparatus the adversaries employ to the detriment of our cause and to the glory of the victory of our enemies. We know, I say, that some proclaim that a factious man was justly put down by a tumult, while others argue that his death is a sure argument of his heretical doctrine. But listen, most clement prince: He who was so devoted to true peace, equity, justice and his country could not have perished because of a tumult. It is usually the best who are oppressed by war and tumult. But I will not say more in his defence, since I defend the man only in so far as he is connected to the cause of truth, and is so connected that it either benefits or harms the truth. We also recognize that Pauline saying: “Who then is Paul, and who is Apollos, but ministers by whom ye believed, even as the Lord gave to every man?” [1 Cor. 3: 4-5]. Nor will I write more about the cause or right of war, whether it was war or tumult, since you know nothing of this, and since the most important productions of this kind have been published in the light by our illustrious Senate of Zurich before our disaster was accepted. I will add this, that whatever death it was could not either prove or disprove either faith or doctrine. For you can see that the most wicked people escape with the most fortunate fates, and again you can see the best of men extinguished by the most dishonorable of all deaths among mortals. For Isaiah, the prince of all the prophets, was cut in pieces under the robber Manasseh among the prophets.

Therefore, since the matter itself proclaims that the doctrine we follow is holy and true, it will be your part, most illustrious prince, not to abandon the truth and to be, as you are said to be, a prince dedicated to truth and justice, who is not only not provoked by the unjust accusations against the innocent, but is not even deterred by danger from the true and just. For indeed Cicero thought that all praise should be given to him who, without constancy, has no prudence. Plato in his treatise, whose title is Laches, thought that knowledge without justice is rather craftiness than wisdom. And indeed we do not doubt that so generous a spirit as yours has been so strengthened by divine power that it is not shaken by the disaster of our Cardinal nor by the unexpected death of our Zwingli. For we know with what great apparatus of speaking, rather of jesting, our adversaries use, to the greater detriment of our cause and the greater boasting of the victory of our enemies. We know, I say, that some cry out that the man of faction was oppressed by the just judgment of God in a tumult, while others contend that his death is the surest proof of heretical doctrine. But hear, most clement prince: He could not have perished on account of a tumult who was so devoted to true peace, equity, justice, and his country. For in war and tumult not the worst but the best are often oppressed. But I shall say no more of this man in this matter, for I defend him only so far as that his cause is connected with the truth and so connected that it is either advantageous or disadvantageous to the truth. Otherwise we acknowledge that Pauline saying: "Who is Cephas, or Paul, or Apollos, but ministers, by whom ye believed?" [1 Cor 3:4-5]. Nor further shall I write of the cause or right of war, whether it was war or tumult, since not only do you know nothing of that, but the chief writings of that sort were published in the light of day by our most illustrious Senate of Zurich before the accepted disaster. I will add this, that whatever the end may be, it cannot prove or disprove faith or doctrine. For you may see that the most impious are sometimes carried away by the most fortunate fates, and again you may see the best men extinguished by the most dishonorable and cruelest kind of death among mortals. For instance, Isaiah, the prince of all the prophets, was cut in pieces with a saw by the robber Manasseh. Jeremiah, the most constant of the prophets, and Zachariah, the most faithful, were stoned by the most wicked of mortals.
What more shall I mention of John, son of Zachariah, than that there was never a more holy man born of women, or of our chosen vessel Paul? For the former was slain in prison by the most impure Herod on account of his counsel to a most wicked harlot, and the latter was beheaded by the most cruel robber, Domitian, as a disturber of public peace, of all who are and were. Yet none save the most impious ever questioned the doctrine and life of these men on account of their punishments. The former was put to death in prison by the most impure Herod on account of the advice he gave to a wicked prostitute, while the latter was beheaded by the most cruel robber of all, Domitius Nero, being regarded as a disturber of public peace. In the meantime, no one but the most wicked questioned either his teachings or his life on account of the punishments he suffered. So why do our Zwinglians draw his death to the condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is quite clear that nothing is desired of him by the pious? But believe me, most illustrious prince: these are not our times that deserve leniency and security, nor are we today such as can or will endure free truth. Therefore, since it is so well agreed between us, who presume to speak, and the world (for none forbids the pious to be approved), it is to be feared that many things are done by us through flattery and much more is omitted through cowardice fear.

seg.output: What else should I mention about John, the son of Zacharias, who was born of women more holy than any other, and our vessel of election Paul? The former was struck in prison by the most shameful of harlots, the impure Herod, and the latter was beheaded by the most cruel of all robbers, Domitius Nero, as a disturber of public peace. In the meantime, no one except the most godless questioned the doctrine and life of these men because of their sufferings. Why then do these of ours, Zwingli, draw his death to the condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is clear enough that the pious desire nothing more of him? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? Also: "A time will come when whoever kills you will think he is doing a service to God" [John 16:2]. Or are they unaware that "we must go through many afflictions to enter the kingdom of God" [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world so that they suffer nothing, always be pleasing, offend no-one, enjoy delights and promise security to their followers? A new way of preaching indeed, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, provoking the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God" [Galatians 1:10]. And: "Those who wish to please in the flesh, compel you to be circumcised so that they may not be persecuted because of the cross of Christ" [Galatians 6:12]. If they think otherwise, why, I ask, are we so despised, especially on the grounds that we are afflicted by the enemies of the truth, insulted, stripped of our possessions, beaten and tormented daily with the expectation of death? Why do they daily threaten even those who survive of his (as they say) sect? As if they had found a kind of doctrine, to which he who adheres shall be safe from all weapons. But believe me, most illustrious prince: these are not the times that deserve leniency and security, nor are we such today that we can or wish to bear free truth. Therefore, since it so well agrees with us who presume to speak and with the world (for nobody forbids the pious), it is to be feared that many things will be done by us through flattery and much more omitted out of cowardly fear. And to speak freely with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will soon come to pass, that we shall wish with common prayers that we, together with those whom we now devote to direful destruction, were intercepted by the Capellana disaster and say that they are the most fortunate, who have had the courage to suffer for truth and country, what we wretched ones will be compelled to suffer far more cruelly throughout all Germany. And would that I were a false prophet.

seg.output: What else shall I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, who was born of women more holy than any other man, or about our vessel of election Paul? The former was struck down in prison, even by the most impure Herod, on the advice of a most shameful harlot, while the latter was beheaded by the most cruel robber of all time, Domitian Nero, as a disturber of public peace. Nevertheless, no one but the most impious has ever doubted the doctrine and life of these men on account of their punishments. Why then do our Zwinglians draw their death as a condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is clear that nothing less than piety is desired from them? Or, have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? And: "A time is coming when anyone who kills you will think he is offering service to God" [John 16:2]. Or, do they not know that "we must enter the kingdom of God through many tribulations" [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the Gospel to the world so that they suffer nothing, always please, offend no one, enjoy delicacies, and promise security to their followers? A new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, incurring the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we would not have been servants of God" [Galatians 1:10]. And: "Those who desire to please men in the flesh, compel you to be circumcised, only that they may not suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Galatians 6:12]. If they feel differently, why, I pray, are we so despised, especially on the grounds that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, dishonored, deprived of our substance, struck down, and everyday tormented by the expectation of death? Why do they threaten every day the survival of even those (as they say) of his sect? As if they had found a kind of doctrine, to which whoever adheres is beyond the reach of any weapon. But believe me, most illustrious prince: These are not times that deserve leniency and security, nor are we such today, who can or will bear free truth. Since then it is so well agreed between us who presume the word and the world (for no one forbids the pious to be approved), it is to be feared that many things will be done by us through flattery, and much more will be omitted through cowardly fear. And to speak freely with you, most gracious prince, it is no less to be feared that in a short time our affairs will come, that we may wish with common wishes that we may be included with those whom we now devote to direful punishments, and that we may say that they are the most fortunate, to whom it happened to contend bravely for the truth and their country, which we miserable must experience in all Germany, far more cruelly. And would that I were a false prophet. Yet the Scripture reveals that even in the times of Josiah a book of the law was found and prophecy was restored together with the true worship of God; nevertheless, a few years later the most holy king Josiah was killed by the hand of the most impious idolater Necho; so that he was killed who had received by oracle from the Lord. "For you have heard the law and have humbled yourself before God, I too have heard you and will gather you to your fathers, and your eyes will not see the evil that I will bring upon this place" [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. For a few years later Jerusalem, the most praised of cities, was plundered, burned, and utterly destroyed by the impious, which Jeremiah gave the reason for in 11f: "Because your fathers forsook me, says the Lord, and followed strange gods, whom they served and worshipped, but they forsook me and did not keep my law. You also have exceeded the wickedness of your fathers. "Therefore, trust me, most gracious prince: It is not to be feared that in a short time our affairs will come, that we may wish with common wishes that we may be included with those whom we now devote to direful punishments, and that we may say that they are the most fortunate, to whom it happened to contend bravely for the truth and their country, which we miserable must experience in all Germany, far more cruelly. And would that I were a false prophet.

seg.output: What else shall I mention about John, son of Zechariah, who was born of women no more holy than he, and about our chosen vessel Paul? The former was put to death in prison by the most impure Herod, even though he was condemned by the most cruel of all tyrants, Domitius Nero, as a disturber of public peace. In the meantime, no one but the most wicked questioned the doctrine and life of these men because of their punishments. Why then do our Zwinglians trace the death of this man to the condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is clear that nothing more is desired of him by the pious? Have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? Or: "The time will come when whoever kills you will think he is offering service to God" [John 16:2]? Or don't they know that "we must enter the kingdom of God through many tribulations" [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world so that they suffer nothing, are always pleasing, offend no one, indulge in delights, and promise security to their followers? That's a new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, incurring the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we would not have been servants of God" [Galatians 1:10]. And: "Those who wish to be pleasing in the flesh compel you to be circumcised, only to avoid persecution because of the cross of Christ" [Galatians 6:12]. If these men think differently, why then are we so despised, most especially on the grounds that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, mocked, stripped of our possessions, beaten, and daily tormented with the expectation of death? Why do they threaten daily that those who remain (as they say) of his sect will also perish? As if they had found a kind of doctrine to which whoever adheres will be safe from all harm. But believe me, most illustrious prince: these are not times that merit leniency and security, nor are we today such that we can or will bear free truth. Therefore, since it is so well suited to us who proclaim the word and to the world (for no one forbids the pious to be approved), it is to be feared that much is done by us through flattery and much more omitted through cowardly fear. And to speak freely with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will soon come to this, that we will wish along with those we now devote to dire curses that we had been intercepted by the Capellanean disaster and say that those are the most fortunate who, for the truth and their country, courageously endured what we wretched ones will be forced to experience throughout all Germany, more cruelly. And would that I were a false prophet. But scripture reveals that in the time of Josiah a book of the law was found and prophecy restored along with the true worship of God; yet a few years later the most holy king Josiah was killed by the hand of the impious idolater Necho. For the Lord said to him: "Because you have heard the law and humbled yourself before God, I also have heard you and will gather you to your fathers, and your eyes will not see the evil that I am going to bring upon this place" [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. Indeed, not many years after, the most great slaughter of princes and people followed, and Jerusalem, most praised of cities, was plundered by the impious, burned, and utterly destroyed. Jeremiah gave the cause in chapter 16 [11f]: "Because your fathers have forsaken me, says the Lord, and have followed alien gods, which they have served and worshipped, and have forsaken me and have not kept my law. You too have exceeded the wickedness of your fathers. For each of you follows the perverse thoughts of his own wicked heart, so that he does not obey me" [Jeremiah 16:11f].

seg.output: What else shall I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, no one born of women was holier than he, and what of our Paul, the vessel of election? The former was struck down in prison by the most impure Herod, even the most cruel tyrant of all, Domitius Nero, had the latter beheaded as a disturber of the public peace. Yet not even the most ungodly men have doubted their teachings or their lives because of their sufferings. So why do our Zwinglians attribute his death to the damnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is clear that the pious have nothing to reproach him for? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? And again: "It will be said in that time, that whosoever killeth you, doth it in service of God" [John 16:2]. Or do they not know that "we must enter into the kingdom of God through many tribulations" [Acts 14:21]? Or do they preach the gospel to the world, so that they may suffer nothing, always please everybody, offend no-one, enjoy delights and promise security to their followers? This would be a new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and Apostles, for they, provoking the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God" [Galatians 1:10]. And again: "They who seek to please men in the flesh, compel you to be circumcised only lest they suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Galatians 6:12]. And if they think otherwise, why, I pray, are we so despised, and that especially under the pretext that we are afflicted by the enemies of the truth, disgraced, despoiled of our substance, beaten and daily in expectation of death? Why do they threaten daily that the survivors of his (as they call it) sect will also perish? As if they had invented some doctrine, so that whoever embraces it shall be safe from all danger. But believe me, most illustrious prince: these are not the times that deserve leniency or security, nor are we such men as can bear or would wish to bear the free truth. Since then it is so well with us, who pretend to the word, and with the world (no one forbids it to the pious), it is much to be feared that many things are done by us through flattery and that much more is omitted through cowardly fear. And, to speak freely with you, most gracious prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs are so near a conclusion, that we shall wish ourselves together with those whom we now devote to horrible curses, to be taken away by the Capellanian plague, and to be said to be most happy, who, for the truth and their country, have courageously opposed what the miserable must shortly experience throughout all Germany. And would to God I were a false prophet. But the scripture tells us that in the days of Josiah was found a book of the law and that the prophecy, together with the true worship of God, was restored. Yet a few years after, the most holy king Josiah was slain by the most impious idolater Nechaon. For the Lord had said to him by an oracle: "Because thou hast hearkened to the voice of thy father, and hast humbled thyself before me, I also have heard thee, and will gather thee to thy fathers, and thine eyes shall not see the evil which I will bring upon this place" [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. Yet a few years after, Jerusalem, the most celebrated of cities, was plundered, burned and totally destroyed by the impious. The cause of this, Jeremiah gives us in chapter sixteen [11f]: "For thus saith the Lord, because your fathers have forsaken me, and have walked after strange gods, and have served them, and have worshipped them, and have forsaken me, and have not kept my law. Ye have done evil above your fathers. For every one of you walketh after the imagination of the evil of his own heart, to walk in my statutes, and to keep my judgments, and to do them" [Jeremiah 16:11-12]. If we compare these times with ours, what, I pray, is more like? For the law of the Lord is restored, yet the best of men presently perish.

seg.output:
Aut dubium est aeternam nos tandem perire damnationem, si et nos etiam illud non curamus?
What more shall I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, who was born of women no more holy than any other, and about our vessel of election, Paul? The former, by the wicked advice of a harlot, was even put to death in prison by the most impure of all, Herod; and the latter, as the disturber of public peace, was beheaded by the most cruel of all tyrants, Domitius Nero. Yet no one but the most wicked of men has ever called in question either the doctrine or the life of these men on account of their sufferings. Why then do our Zwinglians draw his death to the condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is evident that the pious have nothing to desire in them? Do they forget the words of our Lord: “If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you?” [John 15:20]. Also: “It shall come to pass that whosoever shall kill you shall think that he doeth God service” [John 16:2]. Do they not know that “we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God” [Acts 14:21]? Will they preach the gospel to the world so as to suffer nothing, always to please, never to offend, to indulge in delights, and to promise to their followers a state of safety? Surely, this is a new mode of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, drawing upon themselves the hatred of all men, cried out: “If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God” [Gal 1:10]. And: “They that desire to make a fair show in the flesh, compel you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ” [Gal 6:12]. But if these men feel differently, why, I pray, are we so despised, and that, too, for no other reason than that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, insulted, stripped of our substance, beaten, and daily threatened with death? Why, every day, do they threaten that even the survivors of his (as they call it) sect shall be destroyed? As though they had discovered a kind of doctrine, of which such as adhere to it are out of the reach of danger. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not such times as can deserve lenity and safety; neither are we such persons as we can bear free truth, or have a mind to do so. Since, therefore, it is so much for our interest to agree with the world (for no man blames the pious for this) it is much to be feared that much will be done by us through flattery, and much more omitted through a cowardly fear. And, to speak freely with you, most gracious prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will shortly come to that pass, that we shall wish ourselves in the same condition with those whom we now devote to destruction, and call those happy who were intercepted by the Capellan disaster, and who, for truth and their country, had the courage to suffer what we poor wretches shall be forced to endure in all Germany. And, oh that I may be a false prophet. Yet the Scripture informs us that in the days of Josiah a book of the law was found, and prophecy, with the true worship of God, was restored. Nevertheless, a few years after, the most holy king Josiah was put to death by the hand of the most impious idolater Necho; notwithstanding he had received an oracle from the Lord. “Forasmuch as thou hast heard the words of the Lord, and hast humbled thyself before the Lord, I have heard thee also, saith the Lord. And now, behold, I will gather thee to thy fathers, and thou shalt be gathered to thy grave in peace, neither shall thine eyes see all the evil which I will bring upon this place” [2 Chr 34:26-28]. In a few years after, the most glorious city of Jerusalem, the most celebrated of all cities, was by the impious destroyed, set on fire, and utterly demolished. To this Jeremiah gives the reason, in ch. 11: “Because your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and have gone after other gods, and have served them and worshipped them, and have forsaken me, and have not kept my law. And ye have done worse than your fathers. For, every one of you walketh after the imagination of his own evil heart, that they may not hearken unto me”. To which if we compare our times, what, I pray, can be more suitable? The law of the Lord is restored, but immediately the best of men perish. And what comes after? Or is there any doubt but that we shall at length bring upon ourselves eternal damnation, if we do not take care of this also?
