seg.output: What else shall I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, of whom no one born of women was holier, or our chosen vessel Paul? The former, by the advice of a most shameful prostitute, was even struck down in prison by the most impure Herod, while the latter, as a disturber of the public peace, was beheaded by the most cruel robber of all who were and ever shall be, Domitian Nero. Yet none but the most impious has ever called into question the doctrine and life of these two, on account of their sufferings. Why then do these Zwinglians of ours draw the death of these two to the damnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is clear enough that there is nothing to be desired from the pious? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: “If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you” [John 15:20]? Or again: “It will come to pass that whoever kills you will think he has done God service” [John 16:2]. Or do they not know that “we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God” [Acts 14:21]? Or are they going to preach the gospel to the world in such a way that they will suffer nothing, always please, offend nobody, take their pleasure and promise security to their followers? A strange way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, incurring the hatred of all men, cried out: “If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God” [Gal 1:10]. And again: “They compel you to be circumcised, only that they may not suffer persecution for the cross of Christ” [Gal 6:12]. But if these men think otherwise, why, pray, are we so despised, and that especially on this ground, that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, loaded with reproach, stripped of all our possessions, beaten and every day in expectation of death? Why do they threaten daily that even the survivors of his (as they say) sect shall perish? As if they had found out a kind of doctrine for which whoever adheres to it should be out of the reach of danger. But believe me, most noble prince, these are not our times that deserve lenity and security, nor are we such as can bear free truth, or will. Since, therefore, it is so well with us who preach the word, as no one blames the pious, it is to be feared that many things are done by us through flattery, and many more through cowardly fear are omitted. And that I may speak freely with you, most gracious prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will shortly come to such a pass, that we shall wish ourselves among those whom we now devote to destruction, and that we may say of those who are intercepted by the Capellan disaster, that they are the happiest who have courageously suffered for truth and their country, what we, wretched men, shall be driven to suffer, through all Germany, and much more cruelly. And may I prove a false prophet! And yet the scripture tells us, that in the time of Josiah the book of the law was found, and with true worship restored; yet a few years after, the most holy king Josiah was slain by the hand of the most impious idolater Nechaon; and he was slain who had received by oracle from the Lord, “Because thou hast heard the words of the Lord, and hast humbled thyself before the Lord, I also have heard thee; behold, I will gather thee to thy fathers, and thou shalt not see any evil” [2 Chr 34:26-28]. For a few years after the greatest slaughter of both princes and people, Jerusalem, the most renowned of cities, was plundered, burnt, and utterly destroyed, by the impious. The cause of this Jeremiah gives in ch. 16 [11f]: “For your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and have gone after other gods, whom they have served and worshipped, and have forsaken me and kept not my law. And you have done worse than your fathers; for behold, every one of you walketh after the imagination of his own wicked heart, that he may not hearken unto me”. If we compare our times with these, what, I pray, can we find more like? The law of the Lord indeed is restored, but the best of men presently perish. And what follows? Truth is preached somewhere, but it is immediately contemned together with God. And what follows?

seg.output: What more can I say about John, the son of Zechariah, who was born of women more holy than any other, and Paul our vessel of election? The former was put to death by the most wicked of all women, the harlot Herodias, even in prison, and the latter was beheaded by the most cruel of all tyrants, Domitius Nero, as an disturber of the public peace. Nevertheless, no one but the most impious has ever doubted the doctrine or life of these men on account of their sufferings. Why then do our Zuinglians draw the death of these men into condemnation of their faith and doctrine, when it is manifest that nothing but what is pious is desired by them? Do they forget the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" (John 15:20)? Also: "The time will come that whoever kills you will think that he does God service" (John 16:2). Or do they not know that "we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God" (Acts 14:21)? Or will they preach the gospel to the world in such a manner that they shall suffer nothing, always please, offend no man, enjoy delights, and promise their disciples security? A new method of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, drawing upon themselves the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God" (Gal. 1:10). And: "They compel you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" (Gal. 6:12). But if they think differently, why, I beseech you, are we so vilified, and that chiefly on this account, that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, exposed to contempt, stripped of our substance, beaten, and daily kept in expectation of death? Why do they threaten daily that even the survivors of this (as they call it) sect shall perish? As though they had found a kind of doctrine whereof he who adheres to it shall stand secure from all weapons. But believe me, most illustrious prince, the present times do not merit lenity and security, nor are we such at this day, that we can bear free truth, or are willing to do so. Since, therefore, it is so well with us who presume to speak the word, with the world (for no one forbids it to be approved by the pious), it is to be feared that many things will be done by us through flattery, and much more will be omitted, through cowardly fear. And that I may freely speak with you, most gracious prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will shortly be brought to such a pass, that we shall wish ourselves, with those whom we now devote to destruction, to be intercepted by the Capellan disaster, and to have been most happy to have suffered for truth and their country with courage, which miserable men shall be forced, through all Germany, to endure far more cruel things. And would to God I were a false prophet. But the Scripture shews that the book of the law was found in the time of Josiah, and prophecy and the true worship of God restored; yet a few years after, the most holy king Josiah was slain with the hand of the most impious idolater, Necho, even he who had received the oracle from the Lord. "Forasmuch as thou hast heard the words of the law, and hast been humbled before the Lord thy God, I also have heard thee," saith the Lord, "and will gather thee to thy fathers, and thou shalt not see the evil that I will bring upon this place" (2 Chron. 34:26-28). But a few years after, there happened the greatest slaughter of princes and people, Jerusalem, the most renowned of cities, was by the wicked plundered, burned, and utterly destroyed. To this the prophet Jeremiah gave the reason in chapter 16: "Because your fathers have forsaken me," saith the Lord, "and walked after other gods, whom they have served and worshipped, and have forsaken me, and have not kept my law: and you have done worse than your fathers; for every one of you walketh after the imagination of his evil heart, that he may not obey me". If we compare these times with our own, what is more like, I pray you? The law of the Lord is restored, but presently the best of men perish. And what comes after? The truth is indeed preached in some places, but it is nevertheless contemned with God. For some of the prophets prophesy lies in the pope's name, and others, who seem to stand firm to truth, are more silent in that part where they should have been loudest, in treating sweetly and to the great applause of the people of charity, lenity, and divine mercy; where they should have spoken severely of justice, and have denounced the crimes wherewith the whole world is now so full.

seg.output: What else can I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, who was born of no woman holier than himself, and of our chosen vessel Paul? The former was killed in prison by the most unclean Herod at the advice of a most shameful harlot, and the latter was beheaded by the most cruelest thief of all time, Domitian Nero, as a disturber of the public peace. Yet no one but the most wicked questioned the doctrine and life of these two, on account of their punishments. Why then do our Zwinglians draw his death to the damnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is plain that nothing but what is pious is desired of them? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20], and again: "A time is coming when whoever kills you will think he is offering a service to God" [John 16:2]? Or do they not know that "we must enter the kingdom of God through many afflictions" [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world in such a way that they will suffer nothing, please everyone, offend no one, live in delight, and promise safety to their followers? Surely this is a new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, provoking the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God" [Galatians 1:10], and again: "They that seek to please in the flesh, compel you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Galatians 6:12]. If others think otherwise, why then, I beseech you, are we so vilified, and that particularly for our being afflicted by the enemies of truth, exposed to contempt, stripped of our substance, beaten, and every day expecting death? Why do they threaten the daily destruction of those who remain of his (as they call it) sect? As if they had found a kind of doctrine, by adhering to which, a man might remain wholly free from danger. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not our times that deserve lenity and security; nor are we such as either can or will bear free truth. Since then it is so well agreed between us, who profess the word, and the world (for no one forbids what is pious to be approved), it is to be feared that, by our flattery, many things are done, and by our cowardly fear much more omitted. And, to speak freely with you, most gracious prince, it is no less to be feared, that our affairs will shortly come to that pass, that we shall wish ourselves to have been taken away with those whom we now devote to destruction, in the blow of Capellan, and to have been among those who were happily snatched away by a noble courage for the truth and their country, since we shall be constrained to undergo far more cruel things throughout all Germany. And would to God I were a false prophet! But the Scripture shows, that in the days of Josiah a book of the law was found, and prophecy with the true worship of God restored; yet not many years after, the most holy king Josiah was slain by the hand of the most impious idolater, Nechoh; and he was slain, who, by the commandment of the Lord, had received this oracle: "Because thou hast heard the law, and hast been humbled before the Lord, I have also heard thee, and will gather thee to thy fathers, and thou shalt not see any evil thing in my sight" [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. And if we compare our times with those, what, I pray, is more like? For the law of the Lord is restored, but the best of men immediately perish; and what comes after? The truth is indeed preached in some places, but is nevertheless slighted with God; for some of the prophets prophecy lies in the pope's name, others, who seem to stand for the truth, are more mute in that point wherein they ought to be the loudest; in sweetly and with the greatest applause of the people discoursing of charity, gentleness, and divine mercy, when it was fit to treat of justice, and to lay down the crimes, wherewith the whole world now abounds. For the magistrate, whose duty it was to maintain equity and justice, partly drives away or murders the innocent in the name of truth, banishes the truth itself, and lives upon the blood of his subjects; partly feigns a religion, and therefore neglects judgment and justice; yea, and himself practises violence, takes upon him persons, riots, whores, and clothes himself with luxury, dice, immoderate hunting, pride, and pomp; wastes all that was in the public treasury, and afterward impoverishes the people with new exactions, foreign wars, and wicked arts.

seg.input: Quid praeterea commemorem Ioannem, Zachariae filium, quo sanctior alius a mulieribus nemo prognatus est, quid vas electionis Paulum nostrum? Quorum ille consilio turpissimi scorti ab omnium impurissimo Herode etiam in carcere caesus, hic vero ceu publicae pacis interturbator ab omnium, qui sunt et fuerunt, crudelissimo latrone Domitio Nerone truncatus est capite. Interim vero nemo nisi impiissimus quisque doctrinam et vitam istorum propter supplicia posuit in dubium . Cur ergo isti Zuinglii nostri interitum trahunt ad damnationem fidei eius et doctrinae, cum satis constet in iis a piis desiderari nihil? An vero obliti sunt verborum domini: «Si me persecuti sunt et vos persequentur» [Ioh 15,20]? Item: «Veniet tempus, ut quisquis interficiat vos, videatur cultum praestare deo» [Ioh 16,2]. An ignorant, quod «per multas afflictiones oporteat nos intrare in regnum dei» [Apg 14,21]? An vero evangelium ita orbi praedicabunt, ut nihil patiantur, semper placeant, neminem offendant, delitiis fruantur et securi sequacibus securitatem polliceantur? Novus sane praedicandi modus, prophetis et apostolis incognitus. Illi enim omnium hominum odia in se suscipientes clamabant: «Si hominibus placuissemus, servi dei nequaquam essemus» [Gal 1,10]. Et: «Qui iuxta faciem volunt placere in carne, cogunt vos circuncidi, tantum ne ob crucem Christi persecutionem patiantur» [Gal 6,12]. Quodsi aliud sentiunt isti, cur, obsecro, nos adeo vilipendimur, idque eo potissimum nomine, quod ab hostibus veritatis affligimur, contumeliis afficimur, substantia nostra exuimur, caedimur et quotidie mortis expectatione angimur? Cur indies minantur interituros etiam superstites eius (ut aiunt) sectae viros? Quasi vero ipsi doctrinae genus invenerint, cui qui adhaereat, extra omnem teli iactum constiterit. At mihi crede, illustrissime princeps: Non ea sunt nostra tempora, quae lenitatem et securitatem mereantur, neque tales hodie sumus, qui liberam veritatem ferre aut possimus aut velimus. Cum itaque nobis, qui verbo praesumus, cum mundo (nemo enim piis probari vetat) tam bene conveniat, verendum est plurima a nobis per adulationem fieri et multo plura per ignavum timorem omitti. Et ut libere tecum loquar, princeps clementissime, id non minus timendum est, eo res nostras brevi deventuras, ut communibus votis optemus nos una cum iis, quos nunc diris devovemus, illa clade Capellana interceptos dicamusque eos esse foelicissimos, quibus pro veritate et patria fortiter oppetere contigit, quod miseri longe crudeliora tandem per universam Germaniam experiri cogemur. Atque utinam vanus sim vates. Atqui scriptura prodit, Iosiae quoque temporibus legis librum esse repertum, prophetiam quoque una cum vero dei cultu restitutam: at nihilominus paucis post annis sanctissimum regem Iosiam impiissimi idololatrae Nechaonis manu esse interfectum, adeoque eum esse interfectum, qui oraculo a domino acceperat . «Quoniam audisti legem et humiliatus es in conspectu dei, ego quoque exaudivi te et colligam te ad patres tuos, nec videbunt oculi tui malum, quod ego inducturus sum super locum istum» [2 Chr 34,26-28].
seg.output: What more can I mention about John, son of Zachariah, who was born of no purer woman, and about our vessel of election Paul? John was struck down in prison by the most impure Herod, even at the command of the most shameful harlot, but Paul, who disturbed the public peace, was beheaded by the most cruel robber of all, Domitian Nero. Yet no one, unless he was most impious, has ever put in doubt the doctrine and life of these two men on account of their punishments. Why then do our Zwinglians draw the death of this man to the condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is quite clear that nothing was desired of him by the pious? Or do they forget the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" (John 15:20)? Or again: "The time will come, when whoever kills you will think he is doing a service to God" (John 16:2). Or do they not know that "we must enter into the kingdom of God through many tribulations" (Acts 14:21)? Or will they preach the gospel to the world so that they will suffer nothing, always please, offend no one, take delight in their pleasures and promise security to their followers? A new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, drawing hatred upon themselves from all men, cried: "If we had pleased men, we would not have been the servants of God" (Galatians 1:10). And: "They who seek to please in the flesh compel you to be circumcised, only to avoid the persecution of Christ" (Galatians 6:12). If they think differently, why, I beseech you, are we so despised, especially on the ground that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, dishonoured, deprived of our substance, beaten and daily afflicted with the expectation of death? Why do they daily threaten to destroy even the surviving members of this (as they say) sect? As though they had discovered a kind of doctrine to which, if a man adheres, he will be beyond the reach of any missile. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not our times which deserve leniency and security, nor are we such as can or will bear the free truth. Since therefore it is so well agreed between us who presume to speak the word and the world (for none forbids it to the pious) it is much to be feared that many things will be done by us out of flattery, and much more will be omitted through cowardly fear. And to speak freely with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will soon come to pass, that we shall wish ourselves, with those whom we now devote to destruction, to have been intercepted by the Capellan disaster, and to have been the most happy of men to have suffered courageously for the truth and country. And would to God I were a false prophet. Yet Scripture teaches that in the times of Josiah the book of the law was found, and prophecy was restored together with the true worship of God; yet nevertheless a few years after the most holy king Josiah was slain by the hand of the wicked idolater Nechaon; and he was slain to whom the Lord had by oracle promised: "Because thou hast heard the law and hast humbled thyself before God, I have also heard thee, and will gather thee to thy fathers, and thine eyes shall not see the evil which I will bring upon this place" (2 Chronicles 34:26-28).

And again: “For they that desire to be pleasing in the flesh compel you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ” [Galatians 6:12]. And that I may speak freely with you, most gracious prince, this is no less to be feared, that our affairs will shortly come to pass, that we shall wish ourselves together with those whom we now so bitterly devote to destruction to have been intercepted by the Capellanian disaster, and to have been the most happy of all, who have courageously encountered what the miserable shall soon experience all over Germany in a much more cruel manner. But a few years after, Jerusalem, the most renowned of all cities, was laid waste, burnt, and entirely destroyed by wicked men, with the greatest slaughter of both princes and people.

And, to speak freely with you, most clement prince, this is no less to be feared, that our affairs should shortly come to such a pass, that we should wish ourselves, with those whom we now devote to destruction, to have been intercepted by the Capellan death, and to have been the most fortunate, for whom it had happily happened to suffer bravely in defence of truth and country, what we, the wretched, must expect to endure in the most cruel manner throughout all Germany. An ignorant, quod «per multas afflictiones oporteat nos intrare in regnum dei» [Apg 14,21]? An vero evangelium ita orbi praedicabunt, ut nihil patiantur, semper placeant, neminem offendant, delitiis fruantur et securi sequacibus securitatem polliceantur? Novus sane praedicandi modus, prophetis et apostolis incognitus. Illi enim omnium hominum odia in se suscipientes clamabant: «Si hominibus placuissemus, servi dei nequaquam essemus» [Gal 1,10]. Et: «Qui iuxta faciem volunt placere in carne, cogunt vos circuncidi, tantum ne ob crucem Christi persecutionem patiantur» [Gal 6,12]. Quodsi aliud sentiunt isti, cur, obsecro, nos adeo vilipendimur, idque eo potissimum nomine, quod ab hostibus veritatis affligimur, contumeliis afficimur, substantia nostra exuimur, caedimur et quotidie mortis expectatione angimur? Cur indies minantur interituros etiam superstites eius (ut aiunt) sectae viros? Quasi vero ipsi doctrinae genus invenerint, cui qui adhaereat, extra omnem teli iactum constiterit. At mihi crede, illustrissime princeps: Non ea sunt nostra tempora, quae lenitatem et securitatem mereantur, neque tales hodie sumus, qui liberam veritatem ferre aut possimus aut velimus. Cum itaque nobis, qui verbo praesumus, cum mundo (nemo enim piis probari vetat) tam bene conveniat, verendum est plurima a nobis per adulationem fieri et multo plura per ignavum timorem omitti. Et ut libere tecum loquar, princeps clementissime, id non minus timendum est, eo res nostras brevi deventuras, ut communibus votis optemus nos una cum iis, quos nunc diris devovemus, illa clade Capellana interceptos dicamusque eos esse foelicissimos, quibus pro veritate et patria fortiter oppetere contigit, quod miseri longe crudeliora tandem per universam Germaniam experiri cogemur. Atque utinam vanus sim vates. Atqui scriptura prodit, Iosiae quoque temporibus legis librum esse repertum, prophetiam quoque una cum vero dei cultu restitutam: at nihilominus paucis post annis sanctissimum regem Iosiam impiissimi idololatrae Nechaonis manu esse interfectum, adeoque eum esse interfectum, qui oraculo a domino acceperat . «Quoniam audisti legem et humiliatus es in conspectu dei, ego quoque exaudivi te et colligam te ad patres tuos, nec videbunt oculi tui malum, quod ego inducturus sum super locum istum» [2 Chr 34,26-28]. Siquidem non multis post annis maxima et principum et populi strage Hierusalem, urbium laudatissima, ab impiis direpta, incensa, et funditus excisa est . Caussam istis reddidit Ieremias in 16 [11f]: «Eo, quod patres vestri dereliquerunt me, ait dominus, et secuti sunt deos alienos, quos et coluerunt et ado- raverunt, me autem deseruerunt et legem meam non custodierunt. Vos quoque sceleribus vestris malitiam patrum vestrorum superavistis.
seg.output:
At ego confringam vos et in gentibus dispersabo, quas ignorantes non cognoscitis» [Ier 16,11-13].
What more can I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, who was born of more holy women than any other, and our vessel of election, Paul? The former was killed by the most impure Herod even in prison, through the advice of the most shameful harlot, and the latter was beheaded by the most cruel robber of all who are and were, Domitius Nero, as a disturber of the public peace. In the meantime, no one except the most wicked has questioned the doctrine and life of these two on account of their punishments. So why do our Zwinglians draw their death to the condemnation of their faith and doctrine, when it is quite certain that nothing is desired from the pious? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? And again: "The time will come when whoever kills you will think he is doing service to God" [John 16:2]. Or do they not know that "we must enter the kingdom of God through many tribulations" [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world in such a way that they will not suffer anything, always be pleasing, not offend anyone, enjoy pleasures and promise security to their followers? A truly new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For those, receiving the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we would not have been the servants of God" [Gal 1:10]. And: "They who seek to please in the flesh compel you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Gal 6:12]. If they think otherwise, why, I pray, are we so vilified, especially on the grounds that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, dishonored, deprived of our possessions, wounded and daily tormented with the expectation of death? Why do they threaten that even the survivors of this (as they call it) sect will perish? As though they had invented a kind of doctrine by which those who adhere to it would be safe from all weapons. But believe me, most illustrious prince: These are not our times which deserve gentleness and security, nor are we today such as can or would bear free truth. Since, therefore, it is so well agreed between us who presume to speak the word and the world (for no one forbids it to be approved of by the pious), it is to be feared that many things are done by us through flattery, and much more is omitted through cowardly fear. And to speak freely with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will soon come to pass, that we may wish ourselves to be intercepted by this Capellan calamity with those whom we now devote to terrible destruction, and that we may call them the most happy who had the courage to suffer for the truth and their country; which miserable ones we shall soon be forced to experience in all Germany. And would to God I were a false prophet. But the Scripture teaches us that in the time of Josiah the book of the law was found, and prophecy with the true worship of God was restored; yet a few years after, the most holy king Josiah was killed by the most impious idolater Necho, as he had received by oracle from the Lord: "Because thou hast heard the law, and hast been humbled before the face of the Lord, I have also heard thee, and will gather thee to thy fathers, and thy eyes shall not see the evil which I will bring upon this place" [2 Chr 34:26-28]. For a few years after, with the greatest slaughter of princes and people, Jerusalem, most renowned of cities, was by the wicked plundered, burnt and utterly destroyed. The cause of this was given by Jeremiah in [11f]: "For this cause the Lord hath said, Behold, I will bring evil upon them which they shall not be able to escape; and though they shall cry unto me, I will not hearken unto them. Then shall the cities of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem go and cry unto the gods unto whom they offer incense; but they shall not save them at all in the time of their trouble" [Jer 16:11-13].

Restituta est doctrina veritatis, sed omnibus inimicis fidei et veritatis extirpanda.
What else should I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, who was born more holy than any other man by women, and what about our vessel of election Paul? The former was killed in prison by the most impure Herod with the counsel of a most shameful prostitute, and the latter was beheaded by the most cruel tyrant of all time, Domitius Nero, like an disturber of public peace. Yet no one, not even the most wicked, doubted the doctrine and life of these men because of the punishments. So why do these of ours, Zwinglians, draw their death to the damnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is clear that nothing but piety is desired from them? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? Also: "The time will come that whoever kills you will think he is doing a service to God" [John 16:2]. Or do they not know that "we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God" [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world in such a way that they will suffer nothing, always please everyone, offend no one, enjoy delights, and promise security to their followers? And to speak freely with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will soon come to such a pass that we will wish ourselves, together with those whom we now devote to dire curses, to have been intercepted by the Capellan disaster, and to say that they are most fortunate, to whom it befell to bravely suffer for truth and fatherland, which wretched ones we shall soon be compelled to experience throughout all Germany in a far more cruel manner. And would that I were a false prophet. But the scripture shows that even in the time of Josiah a book of the law was found and the prophecy, together with the true worship of God, was restored; yet shortly afterwards the most holy king Josiah was slain by the impious idolater Necho with his own hand, so that he was killed to whom the Lord had given an oracle: "Because you have heard the law and humbled yourself before the face of God, I have also heard you and will gather you to your fathers, and your eyes shall not see the evil that I will bring upon this place" [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. And you have done worse than your fathers; for every one follows the imagination of his own evil heart, that he may not obey me" And if we compare our times to these, what, I pray, is more similar? For the law of the Lord is restored, but immediately the best men perish. The doctrine of truth is restored, but all enemies of the faith and truth are to be exterminated.

seg.input: Quid praeterea commemorem Ioannem, Zachariae filium, quo sanctior alius a mulieribus nemo prognatus est, quid vas electionis Paulum nostrum? Quorum ille consilio turpissimi scorti ab omnium impurissimo Herode etiam in carcere caesus, hic vero ceu publicae pacis interturbator ab omnium, qui sunt et fuerunt, crudelissimo latrone Domitio Nerone truncatus est capite. Interim vero nemo nisi impiissimus quisque doctrinam et vitam istorum propter supplicia posuit in dubium . Cur ergo isti Zuinglii nostri interitum trahunt ad damnationem fidei eius et doctrinae, cum satis constet in iis a piis desiderari nihil? An vero obliti sunt verborum domini: «Si me persecuti sunt et vos persequentur» [Ioh 15,20]? Item: «Veniet tempus, ut quisquis interficiat vos, videatur cultum praestare deo» [Ioh 16,2]. An ignorant, quod «per multas afflictiones oporteat nos intrare in regnum dei» [Apg 14,21]? An vero evangelium ita orbi praedicabunt, ut nihil patiantur, semper placeant, neminem offendant, delitiis fruantur et securi sequacibus securitatem polliceantur? Novus sane praedicandi modus, prophetis et apostolis incognitus. Illi enim omnium hominum odia in se suscipientes clamabant: «Si hominibus placuissemus, servi dei nequaquam essemus» [Gal 1,10]. Et: «Qui iuxta faciem volunt placere in carne, cogunt vos circuncidi, tantum ne ob crucem Christi persecutionem patiantur» [Gal 6,12]. Quodsi aliud sentiunt isti, cur, obsecro, nos adeo vilipendimur, idque eo potissimum nomine, quod ab hostibus veritatis affligimur, contumeliis afficimur, substantia nostra exuimur, caedimur et quotidie mortis expectatione angimur? Cur indies minantur interituros etiam superstites eius (ut aiunt) sectae viros? Quasi vero ipsi doctrinae genus invenerint, cui qui adhaereat, extra omnem teli iactum constiterit. At mihi crede, illustrissime princeps: Non ea sunt nostra tempora, quae lenitatem et securitatem mereantur, neque tales hodie sumus, qui liberam veritatem ferre aut possimus aut velimus. Cum itaque nobis, qui verbo praesumus, cum mundo (nemo enim piis probari vetat) tam bene conveniat, verendum est plurima a nobis per adulationem fieri et multo plura per ignavum timorem omitti. Et ut libere tecum loquar, princeps clementissime, id non minus timendum est, eo res nostras brevi deventuras, ut communibus votis optemus nos una cum iis, quos nunc diris devovemus, illa clade Capellana interceptos dicamusque eos esse foelicissimos, quibus pro veritate et patria fortiter oppetere contigit, quod miseri longe crudeliora tandem per universam Germaniam experiri cogemur. Atque utinam vanus sim vates. Atqui scriptura prodit, Iosiae quoque temporibus legis librum esse repertum, prophetiam quoque una cum vero dei cultu restitutam: at nihilominus paucis post annis sanctissimum regem Iosiam impiissimi idololatrae Nechaonis manu esse interfectum, adeoque eum esse interfectum, qui oraculo a domino acceperat . «Quoniam audisti legem et humiliatus es in conspectu dei, ego quoque exaudivi te et colligam te ad patres tuos, nec videbunt oculi tui malum, quod ego inducturus sum super locum istum» [2 Chr 34,26-28]. Siquidem non multis post annis maxima et principum et populi strage Hierusalem, urbium laudatissima, ab impiis direpta, incensa, et funditus excisa est . Caussam istis reddidit Ieremias in 16 [11f]: «Eo, quod patres vestri dereliquerunt me, ait dominus, et secuti sunt deos alienos, quos et coluerunt et ado- raverunt, me autem deseruerunt et legem meam non custodierunt. Vos quoque sceleribus vestris malitiam patrum vestrorum superavistis. Quisque enim vestrum sequitur pravas cogitationes cordis sui mali, quominus mihi pareat». Quibus si nostra conferamus tempora, quid, oro, similius? Restituta enim est lex domini, sed pereunt protinus optimi viri. Et quid postea?
seg.output:
Restitutae sunt doctrinae et instituta christiana, sed eversa est pene una vice tota Germania, eoque in modo, ut iam simus in exspectatione ultimi exitii, quo tandem, ut omnes video, non possimus effugere.
What further should I mention about John, son of Zecahriah, who was born of no more holy woman, or about our Paul, the vessel of election? The former, by the counsel of a most vile harlot, was even slain in prison by the most impure Herod, while the latter, as a disturber of the public peace, was beheaded by the most cruel tyrant of all, Domitius Nero. Yet none but the most wicked of men have ever doubted the doctrine and life of these two, on account of their punishments. Why then do these of ours seek to drag the death of Zwingli to the condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is plain enough that there is nothing in them that is not desired by the pious? Or have they forgotten the Lord's words: “If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you” [John 15:20]; and also, “It will come to pass, that whosoever kill you will think that he doeth God service” [John 16:2]? Or do they not know that “we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God” [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world, so that they suffer nothing, please everybody, offend no man, give themselves up to delights, and promise security to their followers? A very new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For these, drawing upon themselves the hatred of all men, cried out: “If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God” [Galatians 1:10]; and again, “They that desire to make a fair show in the flesh, constrain you to be circumcised; only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ” [Galatians 6:12]. If they think otherwise, why, I beseech you, are we so vilified, and especially on the ground that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, exposed to contumely, stripped of our substance, beaten, and daily in expectation of death? Why do they threaten daily that even the survivors of this (as they call it) sect shall be destroyed? As if they had discovered a kind of doctrine, to which whoever adheres shall be out of the reach of danger. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not times that deserve gentleness and safety, nor are we such, who can or will bear a free profession of truth. So that, since it is so well with us who venture to speak the truth, with the world (for no one forbids it to be approved by the pious); it is to be feared, that through flattery much shall be done by us, and much more omitted through cowardly fear. And that I may speak freely to you, most clement prince, this is no less to be feared, that our affairs will shortly come to such a pass, that we shall heartily wish ourselves to be partakers of that calamity at Capua, which we now denounce, and to say of them that were intercepted there, that they were most happy, who, for the truth and their country, had the fortune to suffer courageously, what, alas! we, miserable wretches, shall be forced to endure with much more cruelty throughout all Germany. And would to God I were a false prophet. But Scripture tells us, that even in the days of Josiah, a book of the law was found, and prophecy, with the true worship of God, restored: yet a few years after, the most holy king Josiah was slain by the impious idolater Nechaon; notwithstanding he had the assurance from the Lord by an oracle: “Because thine heart was tender, and thou hast humbled thyself before the Lord, when thou heardest what I spake against this place, and against the inhabitants thereof, that they should become a desolation and a curse, and hast rent thy clothes, and wept before me; I also have heard thee, saith the Lord” [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. For a few years after, with the great slaughter of princes and people, Jerusalem, the most renowned of cities, was plundered, set on fire, and razed to the ground by the wicked. To this the prophet Jeremiah gives the reason, chap. 16 [11f]: “Because your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and have walked after other gods, and have served them, and have worshipped them, and have forsaken me, and have not kept my law; and you have done worse than your fathers. For, behold, every one of you walketh after the imagination of his evil heart, that they may not hearken unto me.” If we compare these with our times, what, I pray, is more like? For the law of the Lord is restored, but immediately the best of men perish. And what comes after? The Christian doctrine and institutions are restored, but almost in a moment, all Germany is overturned, in such a manner, that we are now in expectation of a total destruction, which, as all see, we cannot escape.

Cum itaque nobis, qui verbo praesumus, cum mundo (nemo enim piis probari vetat) tam bene conveniat, verendum est plurima a nobis per adulationem fieri et multo plura per ignavum timorem omitti. Et ut libere tecum loquar, princeps clementissime, id non minus timendum est, eo res nostras brevi deventuras, ut communibus votis optemus nos una cum iis, quos nunc diris devovemus, illa clade Capellana interceptos dicamusque eos esse foelicissimos, quibus pro veritate et patria fortiter oppetere contigit, quod miseri longe crudeliora tandem per universam Germaniam experiri cogemur. Atque utinam vanus sim vates. Atqui scriptura prodit, Iosiae quoque temporibus legis librum esse repertum, prophetiam quoque una cum vero dei cultu restitutam: at nihilominus paucis post annis sanctissimum regem Iosiam impiissimi idololatrae Nechaonis manu esse interfectum, adeoque eum esse interfectum, qui oraculo a domino acceperat . «Quoniam audisti legem et humiliatus es in conspectu dei, ego quoque exaudivi te et colligam te ad patres tuos, nec videbunt oculi tui malum, quod ego inducturus sum super locum istum» [2 Chr 34,26-28]. Siquidem non multis post annis maxima et principum et populi strage Hierusalem, urbium laudatissima, ab impiis direpta, incensa, et funditus excisa est . Caussam istis reddidit Ieremias in 16 [11f]: «Eo, quod patres vestri dereliquerunt me, ait dominus, et secuti sunt deos alienos, quos et coluerunt et ado- raverunt, me autem deseruerunt et legem meam non custodierunt. Vos quoque sceleribus vestris malitiam patrum vestrorum superavistis. Quisque enim vestrum sequitur pravas cogitationes cordis sui mali, quominus mihi pareat». Quibus si nostra conferamus tempora, quid, oro, similius? Restituta enim est lex domini, sed pereunt protinus optimi viri. Et quid postea? Praedicatur equidem alicubi veritas, sed ea nihilosetius una cum deo floccipenditur. Nam ex prophetis alii quidem in papa mendacium prophetant, alii vero, qui a veritate stare videntur, ea parte plus, quam decet, muti sunt, qua tamen maxime vocales esse oportebat, siquidem de charitate, lenitate et divina miseratione suaviter et maximo vulgi plausu commentantur, ubi de iusticia disserendum erat eaque severiter protrahenda scelera, quibus totus orbis hodie scatet.
seg.output: What else should I mention about John, the son of Zachariah, who was born of no woman more holy, and of our chosen vessel Paul? John was killed by the most wickedly impure Herod in prison by the advice of a very shameful harlot, and Paul, the disturber of public peace, was beheaded by the most cruelly wicked robber Domitius Nero. In the meantime, no one, except the most wicked, has questioned the doctrine and the life of these two on account of their sufferings. Why then do our Zwinglians draw the death of this man to a condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is clear that nothing is lacking from the pious? Or, have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? And again: "The time is coming that whoever kills you will think that he is doing God a service" [John 16:2]. Do they not know that "we must through many tribulations enter the kingdom of God" [Acts 14:21]? Or do they preach the gospel to the world, so that they suffer nothing, ever please, offend no one, enjoy their delights, and promise safety to their followers? A new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, taking upon themselves the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God" [Galatians 1:10]. And: "They that desire to make a fair show in the flesh, they constrain you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Galatians 6:12]. If they think otherwise, why, I pray, are we so despised, and that especially because we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, disgraced, stripped of our substance, beaten, and daily distressed with the expectation of death? Why do they threaten daily that even the survivors of this (as they call it) sect shall perish? As if they had found a kind of doctrine, that whoever adheres to it shall remain out of the reach of all darts. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not our times that merit leniency and security, nor are we such nowadays that we can or will bear free truth. Since, therefore, it so well agrees with us preachers, and with the world (for no one forbids it to the pious), it is to be feared that much is done by us through flattery, and much more is omitted through cowardly fear. And to speak freely with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs are soon to come to such a pass, that we shall wish ourselves with them whom we now devote to dismal destruction, and say that they were the most happy who had the opportunity to suffer bravely for truth and country, which wretched ones we shall be compelled to experience in all Germany, far more cruelly. And would to God I were a false prophet. Yet the Scriptures declare that in the days of Josiah the book of the Law was found, and the prophecy, together with true worship, restored; yet nevertheless a few years after the most holy king Josiah was slain by the hand of the most wicked idolater Necho, to whom God had said by oracle: "Because thou hast heard the Law, and humbled thyself before the Lord, I have also heard thee, and I will gather thee to thy fathers, and thine eyes shall not see the evil that I will bring upon this place" [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. For a few years after, with the greatest slaughter of both princes and people, Jerusalem, the most renowned city, was sacked, burnt, and utterly destroyed by the wicked. The cause of this the prophet Jeremiah declared in the 16th [11f]: "Because your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and have walked after other gods, and have served and worshipped them, and have forsaken me, and have not kept my Law. Ye also have done worse than your fathers; for, behold, every one of you walketh after the imagination of his own evil heart, that he may not obey me" [Jeremiah 16:11f]. If we compare our times with those, what, I pray, is more like? For the Law of the Lord is restored, yet immediately the best of men perish. And what follows? The truth is indeed preached somewhere, yet in despite of God it is contemned. For some of the prophets prophesy lies in the Pope; some, who seem to stand to the truth, are more silent in that part where they should have been the most vocal, in treating sweetly and with the greatest applause of the people of charity, lenity, and divine mercy, whereas they should have seriously reproved the wickedness, wherewith the whole world is now overspread.

seg.output: What else shall I mention John, the son of Zachariah, whom no other man born of women was holier, or Paul our chosen vessel? The former, by the advice of a most vile harlot, was even slain in prison by the most impure Herod; and the latter, as an disturber of the public peace, was beheaded by the most cruel robber of all, Domitius Nero. Yet no one but the most impious ever doubted the doctrine and life of these two men on account of their punishments. Why then do these Zuinglians of ours draw their death to a condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is sufficiently evident that nothing is required of the pious? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: “If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you” [John 15:20]? Also “the time will come, that whosoever kills you will think that he doeth God service” [John 16:2]. Or do they not know that “we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God” [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the Gospel to the world in such a manner that they shall suffer nothing, always please, offend nobody, enjoy delights, and promise security to their followers? A new way indeed of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles! For they, incurring the hatred of all men, cried out: “If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God” [Gal 1:10]. And: “They who seek to please men in the flesh, compel you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ” [Gal 6:12]. But if these men have any other sentiments, why I pray you, are we so vilified, especially on this account, that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, abused with contumely, stripped of our substance, slain, and every day exposed to the expectation of death? Why do they daily threaten that even the survivors of this (as they call it) sect shall perish? As if they had found out a kind of doctrine, to which, who so adhereth, shall be out of the reach of every weapon. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not our times that deserve lenity and security; nor are we of such a temper, that we can or will bear free truth. When we preachers, therefore, agree so well with the world (for none blame the pious) it is to be feared that we shall do many things out of flattery, and omit much more through cowardly fear. And, to speak freely with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will shortly come to pass, that we shall heartily wish ourselves, together with those whom we now devote to dismal curses, intercepted by the Capellan disaster, and say that they are most happy, who had courage to suffer for truth and their country; whereas we, miserable creatures, shall be forced to undergo much more cruel things all over Germany. And happy were I if I were a false prophet. But the Scripture informs us that in the times of Josiah a book of the Law was found, and the true worship of God restored; yet a few years after, the most holy king Josiah was slain by the hand of the impious idolater Necho. “Forasmuch as thou hast heard the Law, and hast been humbled before the Lord, I also have heard thee,” saith the Lord, “and have gathered thee to thy fathers; and thy eyes shall not see the evil that I will bring upon this place” [2 Chr 34:26-28]. For shortly after, the greatest slaughter both of princes and people, Jerusalem, the most renowned of cities, was spoiled, burnt, and utterly destroyed, by the impious. The cause of which Jeremiah in [11f] gives them: “Because your fathers have forsaken me,” saith the Lord, “and have walked after other gods, whom they have served and worshipped, and have forsaken me, and kept not my Law. And you have done worse than your fathers; for behold, every one of you walketh after the imagination of his evil heart, that they may not hearken unto me.” If we compare these times with ours, what is more like? For the Law of the Lord is restored, but immediately the most excellent men perish. And what follows? True indeed is somewhere preached, but nevertheless God and truth are every where contemned. For out of the prophets, some lie in the name of the Pope, others, who seem to stand for truth, are silent in that part where they should have been most vocal, namely, when they should sweetly and with the greatest applause of the people discourse of charity, lenity, and divine compassion, but sharply reprove the sins, wherewith the whole world now aboundeth; the magistrate also, whose duty it was to reverence justice and equity, partly expelleth and killeth the innocent under the name of truth, proscribeth truth itself, and liveth upon the blood of the people; partly feigneth religion, and therefore neglecteth judgment and justice, yea, and useth violence himself, taketh persons, is drunken, whoremongeth, spendeth his time in gaudy apparel, gaming, immoderate hunting, state, and pomp, and consumeth all that was in the public treasury; and then, by new exactions, foreign wars, and evil arts, enervateth both the strength and riches of the people. The people also cheat, lie, swear, and forswear, drink, and no less spend their substance in luxury; and that which they had gotten by evil arts.

seg.output: What else shall I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, who was more holy than any other man born of women, or our chosen vessel Paul? The former was slain in prison by the most wicked Herod, even though he was the worst of all sinners, while the latter was beheaded by the most cruel robber of all those who have been and will be, Domitius Nero, for disturbing the public peace. Nevertheless, no one but the most wicked has ever doubted the doctrine and life of these men on account of their punishments. Why then do our Zwinglians drag his death to the condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is obvious that the pious have nothing to be desired of him? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: “If they persecuted Me, they will also persecute you” [John 15:20]? Also: “The time will come when whoever kills you will think that he is offering service to God” [John 16:2]. Or do they not know that “we must through many tribulations enter the kingdom of God” [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world so that they will never suffer, always be pleasing, never offend, enjoy pleasures, and promise security to their followers? This is certainly a new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, incurring the hatred of all men, cried out: “If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God” [Galatians 1:10] and “Those who desire to make a good showing in the flesh, they compel you to be circumcised, only that they may not suffer persecution for the cross of Christ” [Galatians 6:12]. If these men think otherwise, why, I ask, are we so despised, and that especially on the ground that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, that we are treated with contempt, that our substance is taken away from us, that we are beaten, and that we are in daily expectation of death? Why do they threaten that even those who survive of his (as they say) sect will soon be destroyed? As if they had found a kind of doctrine, to which whoever adheres will be out of the reach of all weapons. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not our times, which merit gentleness and security, neither are we such men today, who can bear free truth, or will. Since then it is so well agreed between us who take upon us to preach the word and the world (for no one forbids the pious to be approved), it is to be feared that much will be done by us out of flattery, and much more left undone through a cowardly fear. And that I may freely speak with you, most gracious prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will soon come to that pass, that we shall wish ourselves to be involved in that calamity of the Capitulation, and to be counted among the most happy who have bravely endured for the truth and their country, what miserable wretches must we expect to suffer in all Germany? And would to God that I were a false prophet. Yet the Scripture tells us that in the times of Josiah a book of the Law was found, and prophecy with the true worship of God was restored; notwithstanding, a few years after the most holy king Josiah was slain by the hand of the most wicked idolator Nechaon; so that he was slain who had received an oracle from the Lord. “Because thou hast heard the Law and hast humbled thyself before God, I have also heard thee and will gather thee with thy fathers, and thine eyes shall not see the evil which I will bring upon this place” [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. For few years after the great slaughter of both princes and people, Jerusalem, the most renowned of cities, was spoiled, burnt, and utterly destroyed by the wicked. To this Jeremiah gives the reason in the 11th chapter: “Because your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and have followed strange gods which they have served and worshipped, and have forsaken me and kept not my Law. You have also done more wickedly than your fathers; for every one follows the imagination of his own wicked heart, that they may not hearken unto me”. If we compare these times with ours, what, I pray, is more like? For the Law of the Lord is restored, but immediately the best of men perish. And what after that? The truth is indeed preached in some places, but it is nevertheless contemned together with God. For some of the prophets prophesy lies in the Pope’s name, and others who seem to stand for the truth are too silent in that part where they should have been most vocal, where they comment sweetly and with the greatest applause of the multitude on charity, gentleness, and the divine mercy, when they should have been treating of justice and severely reproving the crimes which the whole world now abounds with. The magistrate also, whose office it was to observe equity and justice, partly drives innocent men into banishment and slays them for the truth’s sake, and proscribes the truth itself and lives on the blood of the citizens; partly counterfeits religion, and therefore neglects judgment and justice, yea, and even uses violence, takes up persons, feasts, whores, and consumes with superfluous apparel, gaming, immoderate hunting, pride, and pomp, whatever was in the public treasury: and then by new exactions, foreign wars, and evil arts enervates both the strength and riches of the people. The people also cheat, lie, swear, and forswear, drink, and no less dissipate their substance in luxury; which they had gathered by evil arts. Meanwhile we all comment sweetly on the gospel, but no man changes his life for the better, no man reproves crimes as he ought, no man reproves and punishes them.

impurissimo Herode etiam in carcere caesus, hic vero ceu publicae pacis interturbator ab omnium, qui sunt et fuerunt, crudelissimo latrone Domitio Nerone truncatus est capite.Interim vero nemo nisi impiissimus quisque doctrinam et vitam istorum propter supplicia posuit in dubium.Cur ergo isti Zuinglii nostri interitum trahunt ad damnationem fidei eius et doctrinae, cum satis constet in iis a piis desiderari nihil?An vero obliti sunt verborum domini: «Si me persecuti sunt et vos persequentur» [Ioh 15,20]?Item: «Veniet tempus, ut quisquis interficiat vos, videatur cultum praestare deo» [Ioh 16,2].An ignorant, quod «per multas afflictiones oporteat nos intrare in regnum dei» [Apg 14,21]?An vero evangelium ita orbi praedicabunt, ut nihil patiantur, semper placeant, neminem offendant, delitiis fruantur et securi sequacibus securitatem polliceantur?Novus sane praedicandi modus, prophetis et apostolis incognitus.Illi enim omnium hominum odia in se suscipientes clamabant: «Si hominibus placuissemus, servi dei nequaquam essemus» [Gal 1,10].Et: «Qui iuxta faciem volunt placere in carne, cogunt vos circuncidi, tantum ne ob crucem Christi persecutionem patiantur» [Gal 6,12].Quodsi aliud sentiunt isti, cur, obsecro, nos adeo vilipendimur, idque eo potissimum nomine, quod ab hostibus veritatis affligimur, contumeliis afficimur, substantia nostra exuimur, caedimur et quotidie mortis expectatione angimur?Cur indies minantur interituros etiam superstites eius (ut aiunt) sectae viros?Quasi vero ipsi doctrinae genus invenerint, cui qui adhaereat, extra omnem teli iactum constiterit.At mihi crede, illustrissime princeps: Non ea sunt nostra tempora, quae lenitatem et securitatem mereantur, neque tales hodie sumus, qui liberam veritatem ferre aut possimus aut velimus.Cum itaque nobis, qui verbo praesumus, cum mundo (nemo enim piis probari vetat) tam bene conveniat, verendum est plurima a nobis per adulationem fieri et multo plura per ignavum timorem omitti.Et ut libere tecum loquar, princeps clementissime, id non minus timendum est, eo res nostras brevi deventuras, ut communibus votis optemus nos una cum iis, quos nunc diris devovemus, illa clade Capellana interceptos dicamusque eos esse foelicissimos, quibus pro veritate et patria fortiter oppetere contigit, quod miseri longe crudeliora tandem per universam Germaniam experiri cogemur.Atque utinam vanus sim vates.Atqui scriptura prodit, Iosiae quoque temporibus legis librum esse repertum, prophetiam quoque una cum vero dei cultu restitutam: at nihilominus paucis post annis sanctissimum regem Iosiam impiissimi idololatrae Nechaonis manu esse interfectum, adeoque eum esse interfectum, qui oraculo a domino acceperat.«Quoniam audisti legem et humiliatus es in conspectu dei, ego quoque exaudivi te et colligam te ad patres tuos, nec videbunt oculi tui malum, quod ego inducturus sum super locum istum» [2 Chr 34,26-28].Siquidem non multis post annis maxima et principum et populi strage Hierusalem, urbium laudatissima, ab impiis direpta, incensa, et funditus excisa est.Caussam istis reddidit Ieremias in 16 [11f]: «Eo, quod patres vestri dereliquerunt me, ait dominus, et secuti sunt deos alienos, quos et coluerunt et ado-raverunt, me autem deseruerunt et legem meam non custodierunt.Vos quoque sceleribus vestris malitiam patrum vestrorum superavistis.Quisque enim vestrum sequitur pravas cogitationes cordis sui mali, quominus mihi pareat».Quibus si nostra conferamus tempora, quid, oro, similius?Restituta enim est lex domini, sed pereunt protinus optimi viri.Et quid postea?Praedicatur equidem alicubi veritas, sed ea nihilosetius una cum deo floccipenditur.Nam ex prophetis alii quidem in papa mendacium prophetant, alii vero, qui a veritate stare videntur, ea parte plus, quam decet, muti sunt, qua tamen maxime vocales esse oportebat, siquidem de charitate, lenitate et divina miseratione suaviter et maximo vulgi plausu commentantur, ubi de iusticia disserendum erat eaque severiter protrahenda scelera, quibus totus orbis hodie scatet.Ipse enim magistratus, cuius erat aequitatem et iusticiam colere, partim innocentes veritatis nomine in exilium pellit et iugulat, veritatem ipsam proscribit et sanguine civium vivit, partim religionem simulat ideoque et iudicium et iusticiam negligit, imo et ipse vim facit, personas suscipit, perpotat, scortatur, luxu vestium, alea, immoderatis venationibus, fastu et pompa concoquit, quicquid in publico erat aerario, deinde vero novis exactionibus, alienis bellis et malis artibus totas populi enervat cum vires tum opes.Populus quoque ipse frau-dat, mentitur, iurat et peiurat, potat et nihilo segnius luxu dissipat, quod malis artibus collegerat.Interea vero omnes suaviter commentamur de evangelio, sed nemo vitam mutat in melius, nemo ita, ut decebat, accusat scelera, nemo protrahit et conficit.Quid autem dicam de monopolis, crematistis [!], publicanis et usurariis, qui omnes suas illas iniquitatis radices tam alte egerunt, tu annosam quercum minori negotio evellas, quam istos redigas in ordinem?
seg.output: What else shall I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, whom no other man born of women was more holy, or our vessel of election, Paul?The former was cut down in prison by the most impure Herod, even at the advice of the most vile harlot, and the latter was beheaded by the most cruel robber, Domitian Nero, for being a disturber of the public peace.Yet no one, unless he was most impious, ever called into question the doctrine and life of these men on account of their punishments.Why then do these, our Zuinglians, draw his death to the condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is sufficiently clear that nothing is desired from the pious?Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: “If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you” [John 15:20]?Also: “It will come to pass, that whosoever will kill you will think that he does God service” [John 16:2].Or do they not know, that “we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God” [Acts 14:21]?Or shall they preach the gospel to the world so, that they may suffer nothing, always be pleasing, offend no man, enjoy ease and promise security to their followers?This is surely a new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles.For they, incurring the hatred of all men, cried out: “If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God” [Gal 1:10].And: “They compel you to be circumcised, only that they may not suffer persecution for the cross of Christ” [Gal 6:12].But if these men think otherwise, why, I pray you, are we so vilified, and that especially on this account, that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, loaded with reproach, stripped of our substance, beaten and daily expecting death?Why do they daily threaten to destroy even the survivors of this (as they call it) sect?As if they had found a kind of doctrine, to which he that adheres may be secure from the shot of all.But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not our times that deserve lenity and security, nor are we such at this day who can or will bear free truth.Since, then, it is so well suited to us who take upon us to speak the word, and to the world (for none forbids it to be approved by the pious), it is much to be feared, that much will be done by us out of flattery, and much more omitted through cowardly fear.And to speak freely with you, most clement prince, that is no less to be feared, which may shortly befall our affairs, that we may wish ourselves together with those whom we now devote to dismal ruin, to have been intercepted by the Capellan disaster, and to have been most happy, to whom it fell out bravely to suffer for truth and their country, which the miserable shall be forced to experience in all Germany in a more cruel manner.And would to God I were a false prophet.But scripture tells us, that in the time of Josiah a book of the law was found, and prophecy also together with the true worship of God restored; yet nevertheless the most holy king Josiah was soon after slain by the impious idolater Necho, though he had received by an oracle from the Lord.“Forasmuch as thou hast heard the words of the Lord, and hast humbled thyself before the Lord, I also have heard thee, saith the Lord, and I will gather thee to thy fathers, and thou shalt not see any evil” [2 Chr 34:26–28].For a few years after, Jerusalem, the most renowned of cities, was spoiled, burnt and utterly destroyed by the wicked.And Jeremiah gave the cause of it in 11 [11f]: “Forasmuch as your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and have followed strange gods, whom they have served and worshipped, and have forsaken me, and kept not my law; and you have done worse than your fathers; for, behold, every one follows the imagination of his own evil heart, that they may not hearken unto me”.If we compare these things with our times, what, I pray, is more like?For the law of the Lord is restored, yet presently the best men perish.And what follows?Verily, truth is preached somewhere, yet notwithstanding it is contemned with God, and without any more ado.For some of the prophets prophesy falsehood in the pope, and others, who seem to stand to the truth, are too silent in that part, where they should chiefly have spoken, when they sweetly and to the greatest applause of the multitude discourse of charity, mildness, and divine mercy, where they should have discoursed of justice, and have severely punished those crimes, which abound in the world at this day.For the magistrate, whose duty it was to maintain equity and justice, partly banishes and slays the innocent in the name of truth, proscribes truth itself, and lives on the blood of his subjects, partly affects religion, and therefore neglects judgment and equity, yea, and he himself does violence, takes up persons, drinks, whores, squanders away in superfluous apparel, gaming, immoderate hunting, pride and pomp, whatsoever was in the public treasury, and then by new exactions, foreign wars, and wicked arts, enervates both the strength and wealth of all the people.The people also cheat, lie, swear and perjure, drink and no less dissipate in luxury that which they had gotten by wicked arts.Meanwhile, all of us sweetly discourse of the gospel, yet none amend his life, none as was meet accuseth the crimes, none punisheth and confineth them.What shall I say of monopolies, usurers, publicans, who have all driven these their roots of iniquity so deep, that you may sooner pluck up an ancient oak, than reduce these to order.

seg.output: What else should I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, whom no other born of women is more holy, or Paul our chosen vessel? The former, by the advice of a most shameful harlot, was even killed in prison by the most impure of all, Herod, and the latter, as a disturber of public peace, was beheaded by the most cruel of all tyrants, Domitius Nero. Yet no one except the most impious has ever questioned their doctrine and their life on account of their sufferings. Why then do our Zwinglians draw the conclusion that his death is a condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is clear that nothing is wanting in them that is pleasing to the pious? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? And again: "The time shall come when whosoever shall kill you shall think he doth a service to God" [John 16:2]. Or do they not know that "we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God" [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world in such a way that they will suffer nothing, always be pleasing, offend nobody, enjoy pleasures, and promise their followers safety and security? Surely a new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, incurring the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had been pleasing to men, we should not have been the servants of God" [Gal. 1:10]. And: "They that seek to please men in the flesh, compel you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Gal. 6:12]. If they think otherwise, why, I pray, are we so despised, and that chiefly on this ground, that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, loaded with insults, deprived of our substance, scourged, and every day in expectation of death? Why do they threaten that even those who survive that (as they call it) sect shall perish? As if they had discovered a species of doctrine, by adhering to which a man may be secure from the shot of the enemy. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not times that deserve lenity and security, nor are we such as can bear a free profession of truth, or will. Since therefore it is so well with us who presume to speak, and with the world (for no one forbids the pious to be approved), it is to be feared that many things will be done by us through flattery, and much more through a cowardly fear be omitted. And to speak freely with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will shortly come to that pass, that we shall wish ourselves with those whom we now devote to destruction, and say that they are the happiest who have had the courage to suffer for truth and their country, what we, wretched creatures, shall be forced to undergo throughout all Germany, by a far more cruel fate. And would to God I were a false prophet. But the Scripture testifies that in the time of Josiah a book of the Law was found, and that prophecy, together with the true worship of God, was restored; yet a few years after, the most holy king Josiah was slain by the impious idolater Necho; so that he was slain who had received the oracle from the Lord, saying: "Because thine heart was tender, and thou didst humble thyself before God, when thou heardest his words against this place, and against the inhabitants thereof, and humbledst thyself before me, and didst rend thy clothes, and weep before me; I have even heard thee also, saith the Lord" [2 Chron. 34:26-28]. For soon after a great slaughter of princes and people, Jerusalem, the most renowned of cities, was plundered, burned, and utterly destroyed by the impious. Jeremiah gives the reason in 11[f]: "Because your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and have walked after other gods, and have served them, and have worshiped them, and have forsaken me, and have not kept my law; and ye have done worse than your fathers; for, behold, every one of you walketh after the imagination of his evil heart, that they may not hearken unto me" [Jer. 16:11f]. If we compare these times with ours, what, I pray, is more like? The law of the Lord is restored, but immediately the best of men perish. And what comes after? The truth is indeed somewhere preached, but nevertheless it is contemned together with God. For some of the prophets prophesy lies in the pope's name; and those who appear to stand for the truth, are silent in that point wherein they should have spoken loudest, in sweetly discoursing of charity, lenity, and divine mercy, when the time was to discourse of justice severely, and to punish the crimes with which the whole world is now overflowing. The very magistrate, whose business it was to reverence equity and justice, partly banishes and slaughters the innocent in the name of truth, proscribes truth itself, and lives upon the blood of his subjects; partly feigns religion, and neglects judgment and justice, yea, and himself uses violence, receives persons, drinks, whores, spends in superfluity of apparel, gaming, immoderate hunting, pride, and pomp, whatever was in the public treasury, and then by new exactions, foreign wars, and evil arts, enervates the strength and wealth of the people. The people also deceive, lie, swear, and forswear, drink, and no less dissipate their substance in luxury; yet none of those who would be taken for the pillars of the Christian religion, sets himself against them in any tolerable degree. What shall I say of monopolies, engrossers, publicans, and usurers, who have so deeply rooted these iniquities, as you may sooner pull up an old oak than reduce them to order? They openly spoil the whole world, in their hands are the traffics and treasures of the whole orb, and being raised by theft, fraud, and rapine, yet none of those who would be thought patrons of the Christian religion, oppose themselves to them in any tolerable degree. But all sweetly discourse of the gospel, yet no man changes his life for the better, none reproves crimes according to duty, none punishes and reform them; what shall I say of engrossers, monopolists, publicans, and usurers, who have so deeply rooted these iniquities, as you may sooner pull up an old oak than reduce them to order? seg.output: What else should I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, who was more holy than any other man born of women; what of our Paul, the vessel of election? The former was killed by the most impure Herod, even in prison, by the advice of an infamous harlot, while the latter, regarded as a disturber of public peace, was beheaded by the most cruel tyrant of all, Domitius Nero. Nevertheless, no one but the most impious has ever doubted their doctrine and their life on account of their punishments. Why then do these Zuinglians infer his death as a condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is sufficiently evident that nothing is desired of them but what is pious? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: “If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you” [John 15:20]? Also: “The time cometh, that whosoever killeth you will think that he doeth God service” [John 16:2]. Or do they not know that “we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God” [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world so that they suffer nothing, always please everyone, offend no one, enjoy delights, and promise security to their followers? This is certainly a new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, incurring the hatred of all men, cried out: “If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God” [Galatians 1:10]. And: “They which are of the flesh desire to have you circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ” [Galatians 6:12]. If these people have other views, why, I pray, are we so vilified, especially on the ground that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, disgraced, deprived of our substance, slain, and daily tormented with the expectation of death? Why do they daily threaten even the survivors of his (as they say) sect with destruction? As if they had found a kind of doctrine, to which whoever adheres may be secure from the reach of the sword. But believe me, most illustrious prince, our times are not such as to deserve lenity and security, nor are we such as to bear free truth, either can or will. Since, then, it is so well with us who presume to preach in word, and with the world (for no one forbids what is approved by the pious), it is to be feared that much is done by us through flattery, and much more is omitted through cowardly fear. And, that I may freely speak with you, most gracious prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will shortly come to pass in such a manner that we shall wish ourselves to be included with those whom we now devote to destruction, and say that they are most happy who were intercepted by the Capellan disaster, in bravely opposing for truth and country what we, poor wretches, shall be compelled to experience throughout all Germany with far more cruel severity. And would to God I were a false prophet. But the Scripture shows that in the time of Josiah a book of the law was found, and prophecy, together with the true worship of God, was restored; yet nevertheless the most holy king Josiah was soon after killed by the hand of the impious idolater Necho; and he was slain to whom the Lord had given a command by an oracle. “Because thou hast heard the words of the law, and hast humbled thyself before the Lord, I also have heard thee, saith the Lord; and I will gather thee to thy fathers, and thou shalt not see the evil that I will bring upon this place” [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. For a few years after, Jerusalem, the most renowned of cities, was destroyed, pillaged, burnt, and entirely razed to the ground by the impious. Jeremiah gave the cause of it in the 16th [11f]: “Because your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and have followed strange gods, which they have served and worshipped, and have forsaken me, and kept not my law. And you also have done more wickedly than your fathers; for, behold, every one of you walketh after the imagination of his own evil heart, that he may not hearken unto me”. If we compare our times with these, what, I pray, can be more like? For the law of the Lord is restored, but immediately the best men perish. And what comes after? The truth is indeed here and there preached, yet nevertheless it is contemned together with God. For some of the prophets prophesy lies in the name of the pope, and others, who seem to stand for the truth, are more mute than is fitting in that part especially, where they should speak most, namely, in sweetly commending charity, gentleness, and divine mercy, when they should discourse of justice and severely punish those crimes with which the whole world is now filled. For the magistrate, whose duty it was to honor equity and justice, partly drives innocent men into exile and slays them for the truth’s sake, proscribes the truth itself, and lives by the blood of the citizens; partly feigns religion and therefore neglects judgment and justice, yea, he himself uses violence, receives persons, gets drunk, prostitutes himself, delights in superfluous clothing, gaming, immoderate hunting, pomp, and pride; wastes whatever was in the public treasury; and then, by new exactions, foreign wars, and bad arts, enervates both the strength and riches of the whole people. The people likewise defraud, lie, swear and forswear, drink, and no less wastefully dissipate in luxury what they had gotten by evil arts. Meanwhile all sweetly talk of the gospel, but no one amends his life for the better, no one accuses crimes as he ought, no one punishes and corrects them. What shall I say of monopolists, informers, publicans, and usurers, who have so deeply planted these roots of iniquity, that you may more easily pull up an old oak than reduce them to order? These waste the whole world with impunity, all the trading and treasures of the world are in their hands; and being exalted by theft, fraud, and rapine, yet none of those who would be thought the pillars of the Christian religion oppose themselves to them in anything, though but in a moderate degree. So it comes to pass that our affairs are carried on by violence, the poor are oppressed, and the judge himself (as the prophet says) is partial in giving judgment.
