seg.output: What else can I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, who was born of women no holier than him, or our vessel of election Paul? The former was put to death by the most depraved of men, King Herod, even while in prison, and the latter was beheaded by the cruelest of all tyrants, Domitian Nero, for disturbing the peace of the world. Yet no one except the most wicked questioned their teachings and lifestyle on account of their punishments. So why do our Zwinglis draw his death to the damnation of his faith and teachings, when it is plain to see there is nothing to be desired from the pious? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? Or again: "The time will come that whoever kills you will think he is offering a service to God" [John 16:2]. Or do they not know that "we must enter the kingdom of God through many tribulations" [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the Gospel to the world in such a way that they will never suffer, always please, never offend, enjoy delights and promise security to their followers? A strange new mode of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, incurring the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God" [Galatians 1:10]. And: "They who seek to please men in the flesh compel you to be circumcised, lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Galatians 6:12]. If these men think differently, why then, I pray, are we so despised, and especially on the grounds that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, subjected to abuse, stripped of our possessions, battered and daily tortured by the expectation of death? Why do they threaten that the survivors of his (as they say) sect will be wiped out too? As if they had found a kind of doctrine to which whoever adheres would be safe from all danger. But believe me, most illustrious Prince: these are not times of gentleness and safety, nor are we such men today who can or wish to bear free truth. Since it is so compatible with us, who presume to speak the word of God, and with the world (for no one forbids it to be approved by the pious), it is to be feared that much will be done by us through flattery and much more will be omitted through cowardly fear. And that I may speak freely with you, most clement Prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will soon turn out in such a way that we may wish, with the common desire, that we may be said to have been intercepted by the same calamity of Capua, and that we may call them most fortunate who had the courage to oppose truth and their country, which we miserable ones will be forced to experience in all Germany, with much more cruel results. And would that I were a false prophet! But Scripture reveals that in the time of Josiah a book of the Law was found, and prophecy was restored along with the true worship of God; yet soon after the most holy king Josiah was slain by the most impious idolater Necho, he whom the Lord had received by an oracle. "For thou hast heard the law and hast humbled thyself before the face of the Lord, and I have also heard thee, saith the Lord, and will gather thee to thy fathers, and thine eyes shall not see the evil that I will bring upon this place" [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. For a few years later, with the great slaughter of princes and people, Jerusalem, the most renowned of cities, was plundered, burned and destroyed by the wicked. Jeremiah gave the cause of this in chapter 16 [11f]: "For your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and followed strange gods, which they have served and worshipped, and have forsaken me, and kept not my law. And ye have done worse than your fathers; for, behold, every one of you walketh after the imagination of his own wicked heart, that he may not hearken unto me" [Jeremiah 16:11f]. If we compare these with our own times, what, I pray, is more like? The law of the Lord is indeed restored, but immediately the best of men perish. And what follows? The truth is indeed preached somewhere, but it is nevertheless despised together with God. For some of the prophets prophesy lies in the Pope, and others, who seem to stand for the truth, are more silent in that part where they ought to have been the most vocal, namely when speaking sweetly and with the greatest applause of the people about charity, gentleness and divine mercy, where it was necessary to discourse severely and punish the crimes with which the whole world is now teeming. The magistrate himself, whose duty it was to observe equity and justice, partly drives the innocent away for the sake of truth into exile and puts them to death, proscribes truth itself and lives on the blood of his subjects, partly feigns religion and therefore neglects judgment and justice, yea, he himself does violence, takes up persons, drinks, fornicates, fills himself with luxury in apparel, dice, excessive hunting, pride and pomp, and wastes the strength and riches of all people by new exactions, foreign wars and evil arts. The people also fraudulently, falsely swear, swear falsely, drink and as diligently spend their riches on luxury, as they had collected them by evil arts. Meanwhile, we all sweetly comment on the gospel, but no one changes his life for the better, no one accuses the crimes as befitted, no one punishes and completes them. What shall I say of monopolies, crematists, publicans and usurers, who have so deeply rooted all these iniquities of theirs, that you can more easily pluck up an old oak tree than reduce them to order? These pillage the whole world with impunity, all the business and treasure of the world is in their hands, and since they have been exalted by theft, fraud and rapine, yet none of those who would be seen as pillars of the Christian religion oppose them in any way. Thus it comes to pass that our affairs are carried on by a certain violence, the poor oppressed, and the judge himself (as the prophet says) is partial in rendering judgment. What then is left for us but some common plague, either Nebuchadnezzar, or Sennacherib, or Antiochus, or some other scourge of mankind, to once purge this abominable land with fire and sword, famine and pestilence?

seg.output: What else should I mention about John, the son of Zachariah, who was born of women more holy than any other, and our vessel of election Paul? The former, by the counsel of a most wicked harlot, was even struck down in prison by the most impure Herod, but the latter, as a disturber of public peace, was beheaded by the most cruel robber of all who ever were and are, Domitius Nero. Yet, no one but the most impious cast doubt upon the doctrine and life of these men because of their sufferings. Why then do our Zwinglians draw his death to the condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is clear that nothing more is desired of the pious? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: 'If they persecuted me, they will also persecute you'? [John 15:20] And, 'It will come to pass, that whoever kills you will think he is doing God a service' [John 16:2]. Or do they not know that 'we must enter into the kingdom of God through much tribulation' [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world so that they suffer nothing, always please everyone, offend no one, delight in delights, and promise security to their followers? That is a new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For these, taking upon themselves the hatred of all men, they cried out: 'If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God' [Galatians 1:10]. And, 'They that seek the glory of the flesh, they compel you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ' [Galatians 6:12]. If they think otherwise, why then are we so vilified, especially on the grounds that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, treated with contempt, stripped of our property, beaten and every day tormented with the expectation of death? Why do they daily threaten even those survivors of his (as they call it) sect with destruction? As if they had discovered a kind of doctrine by which whoever adheres to it shall be safe from all danger. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not the times that deserve leniency and security, nor are we such today who can or will bear free truth. Since then, it is to be feared that much is done by us through flattery, and much more is omitted through cowardice and fear. And, to speak freely with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs are soon to come to such a pass that we shall wish, together with those whom we now devote to dire curses, to have been intercepted by the Capellan disaster, and to call them most happy who were granted the honor, for the sake of truth and country, to suffer bravely what we shall assuredly soon have to experience in all Germany. Oh, that I were a false prophet! But the Scripture tells that in the time of Josiah the book of the Law was found, and prophecy, together with true worship, was restored; yet nevertheless a few years after that the most holy king Josiah was slain by the hand of the impious idolater Necho; so that he was slain who had according to the oracle received of the Lord. 'Forasmuch as thou hast heard the Law and hast humbled thyself before the Lord, I have also heard thee and gathered thee unto thy fathers, and thine eyes shall not see the evil that I will bring upon this place' [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. For, not many years after, Jerusalem, the most renowned of cities, was laid waste by the impious, plundered, burned and utterly destroyed by a great slaughter of princes and people. The cause of this did Jeremiah set forth in chapter 16 [11ff]: 'Forasmuch as your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and have walked after other gods, whom they have served and adored, and have forsaken me, and kept not my Law. Ye also have done more wickedly than your fathers; for, behold, every one of you walketh in the imagination of his own wicked heart, that he may not hearken unto me.' How if we compare our times with these? For the Law of the Lord is restored, but straightway the best of men perish. And what then? The truth is indeed preached here and there, yet nevertheless it is contemned with God himself. For some of the prophets prophesy lies in the name of the Pope, and others, who seem to stand for truth, are more mute than was fitting in that part where they ought to have been loudest, when they sweetly and to the greatest applause of the people discoursed of charity, lenity, and divine mercy, while they ought to have been discoursing of justice and severely punishing the crimes wherewith the whole world is now full. The magistrate also, whose business it was to reverence equity and justice, partly banishes and slays the innocent in the name of truth, proscribes truth itself, and lives upon the blood of citizens; partly feigns religion, and therefore neglects judgment and justice; yea, himself does violence, receives persons, gets drunk, and whores; feeds upon the expense of public money, and afterwards upon fresh exactions, foreign wars, and evil arts enervates both the strength and goods of all people. The people also cheat, lie, swear and forswear, drink and no less dissipate their goods in luxury, which they had gathered by evil arts. In the mean time we all talk sweetly of the Gospel, but no man changes his life for the better, no man accuses wickedness as he ought, no man punishes and destroys it. What shall I say of monopolisers [!], scriveners, publicans, and usurers, who have so deeply rooted all those roots of iniquity that it is easier to pluck up an old oak than to reduce them to order? These spoil the whole world with impunity, in their hands are the dealings and treasures of the whole world; and being lifted up by theft, fraud, and rapine, no one of those who would seem to be the pillars of the Christian religion withstands them in any measure. So it comes to pass that our affairs are carried on by a kind of force, the poor are oppressed, and the judge himself (as the prophet hath it) is partial in judgment. What then can we expect but some common pestilence, whether of Nebuchadnezzar, Sanherib, Antiochus, or some other scourge of mankind, which, once with sword and fire, famine and pestilence, may wash away this execrable land? What the Lord hath taken away with Zwingli, and with him so many saints, so many good, so many learned, so many patricians and senators, yea, so many innocent citizens and peasants at once, was doubtless done by a sign and divine counsel.

seg.input: Quid praeterea commemorem Ioannem, Zachariae filium, quo sanctior alius a mulieribus nemo prognatus est, quid vas electionis Paulum nostrum?Quorum ille consilio turpissimi scorti ab omnium impurissimo Herode etiam in carcere caesus, hic vero ceu publicae pacis interturbator ab omnium, qui sunt et fuerunt, crudelissimo latrone Domitio Nerone truncatus est capite.Interim vero nemo nisi impiissimus quisque doctrinam et vitam istorum propter supplicia posuit in dubium.Cur ergo isti Zuinglii nostri interitum trahunt ad damnationem fidei eius et doctrinae, cum satis constet in iis a piis desiderari nihil?An vero obliti sunt verborum domini: «Si me persecuti sunt et vos persequentur» [Ioh 15,20]?Item: «Veniet tempus, ut quisquis interficiat vos, videatur cultum praestare deo» [Ioh 16,2].An ignorant, quod «per multas afflictiones oporteat nos intrare in regnum dei» [Apg 14,21]?An vero evangelium ita orbi praedicabunt, ut nihil patiantur, semper placeant, neminem offendant, delitiis fruantur et securi sequacibus securitatem polliceantur?Novus sane praedicandi modus, prophetis et apostolis incognitus.Illi enim omnium hominum odia in se suscipientes clamabant: «Si hominibus placuissemus, servi dei nequaquam essemus» [Gal 1,10].Et: «Qui iuxta faciem volunt placere in carne, cogunt vos circuncidi, tantum ne ob crucem Christi persecutionem patiantur» [Gal 6,12].Quodsi aliud sentiunt isti, cur, obsecro, nos adeo vilipendimur, idque eo potissimum nomine, quod ab hostibus veritatis affligimur, contumeliis afficimur, substantia nostra exuimur, caedimur et quotidie mortis expectatione angimur?Cur indies minantur interituros etiam superstites eius (ut aiunt) sectae viros?Quasi vero ipsi doctrinae genus invenerint, cui qui adhaereat, extra omnem teli iactum constiterit.At mihi crede, illustrissime princeps: Non ea sunt nostra tempora, quae lenitatem et securitatem mereantur, neque tales hodie sumus, qui liberam veritatem ferre aut possimus aut velimus.Cum itaque nobis, qui verbo praesumus, cum mundo (nemo enim piis probari vetat) tam bene conveniat, verendum est plurima a nobis per adulationem fieri et multo plura per ignavum timorem omitti.Et ut libere tecum loquar, princeps clementissime, id non minus timendum est, eo res nostras brevi deventuras, ut communibus votis optemus nos una cum iis, quos nunc diris devovemus, illa clade Capellana interceptos dicamusque eos esse foelicissimos, quibus pro veritate et patria fortiter oppetere contigit, quod miseri longe crudeliora tandem per universam Germaniam experiri cogemur.Atque utinam vanus sim vates.Atqui scriptura prodit, Iosiae quoque temporibus legis librum esse repertum, prophetiam quoque una cum vero dei cultu restitutam: at nihilominus paucis post annis sanctissimum regem Iosiam impiissimi idololatrae Nechaonis manu esse interfectum, adeoque eum esse interfectum, qui oraculo a domino acceperat.«Quoniam audisti legem et humiliatus es in conspectu dei, ego quoque exaudivi te et colligam te ad patres tuos, nec videbunt oculi tui malum, quod ego inducturus sum super locum istum» [2 Chr 34,26-28].Siquidem non multis post annis maxima et principum et populi strage Hierusalem, urbium laudatissima, ab impiis direpta, incensa, et funditus excisa est.Caussam istis reddidit Ieremias in 16 [11f]: «Eo, quod patres vestri dereliquerunt me, ait dominus, et secuti sunt deos alienos, quos et coluerunt et ado-raverunt, me autem deseruerunt et legem meam non custodierunt.Vos quoque sceleribus vestris malitiam patrum vestrorum superavistis.Quisque enim vestrum sequitur pravas cogitationes cordis sui mali, quominus mihi pareat».Quibus si nostra conferamus tempora, quid, oro, similius?Restituta enim est lex domini, sed pereunt protinus optimi viri.Et quid postea?Praedicatur equidem alicubi veritas, sed ea nihilosetius una cum deo floccipenditur.Nam ex prophetis alii quidem in papa mendacium prophetant, alii vero, qui a veritate stare videntur, ea parte plus, quam decet, muti sunt, qua tamen maxime vocales esse oportebat, siquidem de charitate, lenitate et divina miseratione suaviter et maximo vulgi plausu commentantur, ubi de iusticia disserendum erat eaque severiter protrahenda scelera, quibus totus orbis hodie scatet.Ipse enim magistratus, cuius erat aequitatem et iusticiam colere, partim innocentes veritatis nomine in exilium pellit et iugulat, veritatem ipsam proscribit et sanguine civium vivit, partim religionem simulat ideoque et iudicium et iusticiam negligit, imo et ipse vim facit, personas suscipit, perpotat, scortatur, luxu vestium, alea, immoderatis venationibus, fastu et pompa concoquit, quicquid in publico erat aerario, deinde vero novis exactionibus, alienis bellis et malis artibus totas populi enervat cum vires tum opes.Populus quoque ipse frau-dat, mentitur, iurat et peiurat, potat et nihilo segnius luxu dissipat, quod malis artibus collegerat.Interea vero omnes suaviter commentamur de evangelio, sed nemo vitam mutat in melius, nemo ita, ut decebat, accusat scelera, nemo protrahit et conficit.Quid autem dicam de monopolis, crematistis [!], publicanis et usurariis, qui omnes suas illas iniquitatis radices tam alte egerunt, tu annosam quercum minori negotio evellas, quam istos redigas in ordinem?Hi impune totum orbem expilant, in horum manibus sunt totius orbis negotiationes et thesauri, cumque eo per furtum, fraudem et rapinam evecti sint, nemo tamen ex illis, qui christianae religionis columina videri volunt, se illis vel mediocriter opponit.Ita fit, ut vi quadam res nostrae agantur, pauperes opprimantur ipseque iudex (ut propheta ait) in reddendo sit.Quid ergo nobis nisi communis aliqua pestis, vel Nabuchodonosor vel Sanherib vel Antiochus vel alia generis humani lues, expectanda, quae semel ferro et flamma, fame et peste execrabilem hanc terram lustret?Quod ergo Zuinglium sustulit dominus, quod cum eo tot sanctos, tot probos, tot doctos, tot patritios et senatores, tot denique innocentes cives et colonos una hora sustulit, nimirum omine et divino quodam consilio factum est.Procul dubio quod graviora, ni prorsus convertamur, miseros nos maneant.
seg.output: What else shall I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, who was born of no holier women, and about our Paul, the vessel of election?The former, with the advice of the most shameful harlot, was slain even in prison by the most unclean Herod; and the latter, as a disturber of the public peace, was beheaded by the most cruel robber of all who have been and are, Domitian Nero.Meanwhile, no one, unless he were most impious, has ever doubted the doctrine and life of these men on account of their sufferings.Why then do our Zwinglians draw his death to the damnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is manifest that nothing is desired of the pious in them?Do they forget the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]?And again: "The time will come, that whosoever kills you will think he does God service" [John 16:2].Do they not know that "we must enter into the kingdom of God through many tribulations" [Acts 14:21]?Or will they preach the gospel to the world in such a way, that they will suffer nothing, always be pleasing, offend no one, enjoy delights, and promise security to their followers?What a new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles!For they, receiving the hatred of all men upon themselves, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we would not have been the servants of God" [Gal. 1:10].And: "They compel you to be circumcised, that they may not suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Gal. 6:12].But if those men have another opinion, why, I pray, are we so despised, and this chiefly on the ground that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, exposed to reproaches, deprived of our property, wounded, and daily expecting death?Why do they threaten to perish those who survive him (as they say) of his sect?As if they had invented a kind of doctrine, to which, if any man adheres, he stands secure from all danger.But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not our times which deserve lenity and security; nor are we such as can or will bear free truth.Since then it is so well with us who presume to preach the word, and with the world (for none forbids the pious to be approved), it is to be feared that much is done by us through flattery, and much more omitted through cowardly fear.And that I may speak freely with you, most clement prince, this is no less to be feared, that our affairs will shortly come to pass, that we may wish ourselves, together with those whom we now devote to destruction, to be intercepted by that Capellian plague, and to be counted the happiest, who, for truth and their country, have bravely encountered what we shall be forced to suffer, far more cruelly, throughout all Germany.And would to God I were a false prophet.But the Scripture reveals that in the times of Josiah, the book of the law was found, and the prophecy, together with the true worship of God, was restored; yet shortly after the most holy king Josiah was slain by the impious idolater Necho, he who had received an oracle from the Lord.“Forasmuch as thou hast heard the words of the Lord, and hast humbled thyself before the Lord, I also have heard thee, saith the Lord; and I will gather thee to thy fathers, and thou shalt not see any evil” [2 Chr. 34:26-28].For a few years after, there was a great slaughter of both princes and people, and Jerusalem, the most renowned of cities, was plundered, burnt, and wholly destroyed by the wicked.Jeremiah assigns the cause of it in Chapter 16:“Because your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and have walked after other gods, and have served them, and have worshiped them, and have forsaken me, and have not kept my law; and you have done worse than your fathers; for, behold, every one follows the imagination of his own evil heart, that they may not hearken unto me”.If we compare our times with these, what, I pray, is more like?For the law of the Lord is restored, but immediately the best of men are destroyed.And what comes after?The truth is indeed preached in some places, but it is nevertheless despised with God.For some of the prophets prophecy lies in the Pope's name; and others, who seem to stand for truth, are, in that part where they should have been the most vocal, too mute; sweetly and with great applause of the people discoursing of charity, gentleness, and divine mercy; but where it was to have been discoursed of justice, and that severely, of the crimes wherewith the whole world is now overrun.The magistrate himself, whose duty it was to cultivate equity and justice, partly drives away the innocent, in the name of truth, into banishment and slays them; he proscribes truth and lives upon the blood of his subjects; partly he feigns religion, and for that cause neglects both judgment and justice, yea, he himself is violent, takes persons, drinks, whores, is mad in apparel, plays at dice, keeps immoderate hunting, is proud and pompous, and consumes, by one means or other, whatever is in the public treasury; and the people themselves cheat, lie, swear and forswear, drink and yet lose not their luxury; with evil arts they gather together, and with the same they dissipate.In the meantime, we all discourse sweetly of the gospel, but no man alters his life for the better, no man accuseth crimes as he ought, no man prosecutes and finishes them.What shall I say of monopolists, usurers, and tax-gatherers, who have so deeply rooted these their iniquities, that you will sooner pluck up a year-old oak than reduce them to order?These safely spoil the whole world, all the negotiations and treasures of the world are in their hands; and whereas they are thus advanced by theft, fraud, and rapine, yet none of those who would be seen the pillars of the Christian religion makes himself in any measure a competitor to them.So it comes to pass that our affairs are carried on by a kind of violence, the poor are oppressed, and the judge himself (as the prophet saith) is partial in giving judgment.What remains for us but some general calamity, either of Nebuchadnezzar, or Sanherib, or Antiochus, or some other plague of mankind, which may once purify this abominable land with fire and sword, famine and pestilence?That therefore which the Lord hath taken away with Zwinglius, and with him so many saints, so many good men, so many learned men, so many patricians and senators, so many innocent citizens and country-people in one hour; doubtless it was done by a sign and a divine counsel.Doubtless greater evils are to be expected, unless we turn wholly to the Lord.

seg.output: Therefore, neglecting the boldness of some, remember, illustrious prince, the words of your Lord, with which he speaks of his own in a courteous way and says: “Come to me, all you who labor and are burdened, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls. For my yoke is easy and my burden is light” [Mt 11:28-30]. We can freely testify to the truth and kindness of the Lord with gratitude, for our Church was never lacking in the midst of storms of afflictions, but rather He has encouraged it, and even now He does not desert it, since our Senate stands and prophecy, the laws against Popery and luxury remain, and so does the people. And may the Lord continue to do so much good. Therefore, give yourself entirely to this powerful and kind Father, worship His truth, and stay in this one. If you do this, you will certainly achieve what Paul strives for throughout this Epistle to the Hebrews.

dominus.Patri itaque tam potenti et benigno te quoque totum trade, veritatem eius cole, in hac persta huic immorere.Id si feceris, illud sane praestiteris, quod Paulus tota hac ad Hebraeos epistola ambit.Quam ita, ut nostris illustrata est commentariis, tuo nomini voluimus dicatam.Dominus Iesus confirmet te spiritu suo sancto.Amen.
Tiguri, 17. augusti 1532.
seg.output:
Therefore, O illustrious prince, remember the wit of some people, and the words of your Lord, in which he speaks to his people in a polite way and says: "Come to me, all you that labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you, and learn of me; for I am meek and lowly in heart: and you shall find rest unto your souls. For my yoke is easy, and my burden is light" [Mt 11:28-30]. Indeed, as far as we are concerned, we can freely report with thanksgiving of the truth and kindness of the Lord, that our Church has never lacked in the midst of storms of affliction, but rather has encouraged its people, and even now does not desert them, since our Senate stands, and prophecy and laws stand against papism and luxury, and the people stand. And may the Lord continue to show such kindness. Therefore, give yourself wholly to this so powerful and kind Father, worship his truth, stand in this, commit yourself to him. If you do this, you will certainly do what Paul strives for in this entire Epistle to the Hebrews. As it is made clear by our commentaries, we have dedicated it to your name. May the Lord Jesus confirm you with his holy Spirit. Amen.
Zurich, August 17th, 1532.

seg.input: Quid praeterea commemorem Ioannem, Zachariae filium, quo sanctior alius a mulieribus nemo prognatus est, quid vas electionis Paulum nostrum? Quorum ille consilio turpissimi scorti ab omnium impurissimo Herode etiam in carcere caesus, hic vero ceu publicae pacis interturbator ab omnium, qui sunt et fuerunt, crudelissimo latrone Domitio Nerone truncatus est capite. Interim vero nemo nisi impiissimus quisque doctrinam et vitam istorum propter supplicia posuit in dubium . Cur ergo isti Zuinglii nostri interitum trahunt ad damnationem fidei eius et doctrinae, cum satis constet in iis a piis desiderari nihil? An vero obliti sunt verborum domini: «Si me persecuti sunt et vos persequentur» [Ioh 15,20]? Item: «Veniet tempus, ut quisquis interficiat vos, videatur cultum praestare deo» [Ioh 16,2]. An ignorant, quod «per multas afflictiones oporteat nos intrare in regnum dei» [Apg 14,21]? An vero evangelium ita orbi praedicabunt, ut nihil patiantur, semper placeant, neminem offendant, delitiis fruantur et securi sequacibus securitatem polliceantur? Novus sane praedicandi modus, prophetis et apostolis incognitus. Illi enim omnium hominum odia in se suscipientes clamabant: «Si hominibus placuissemus, servi dei nequaquam essemus» [Gal 1,10]. Et: «Qui iuxta faciem volunt placere in carne, cogunt vos circuncidi, tantum ne ob crucem Christi persecutionem patiantur» [Gal 6,12]. Quodsi aliud sentiunt isti, cur, obsecro, nos adeo vilipendimur, idque eo potissimum nomine, quod ab hostibus veritatis affligimur, contumeliis afficimur, substantia nostra exuimur, caedimur et quotidie mortis expectatione angimur? Cur indies minantur interituros etiam superstites eius (ut aiunt) sectae viros? Quasi vero ipsi doctrinae genus invenerint, cui qui adhaereat, extra omnem teli iactum constiterit. At mihi crede, illustrissime princeps: Non ea sunt nostra tempora, quae lenitatem et securitatem mereantur, neque tales hodie sumus, qui liberam veritatem ferre aut possimus aut velimus. Cum itaque nobis, qui verbo praesumus, cum mundo (nemo enim piis probari vetat) tam bene conveniat, verendum est plurima a nobis per adulationem fieri et multo plura per ignavum timorem omitti. Et ut libere tecum loquar, princeps clementissime, id non minus timendum est, eo res nostras brevi deventuras, ut communibus votis optemus nos una cum iis, quos nunc diris devovemus, illa clade Capellana interceptos dicamusque eos esse foelicissimos, quibus pro veritate et patria fortiter oppetere contigit, quod miseri longe crudeliora tandem per universam Germaniam experiri cogemur. Atque utinam vanus sim vates. Atqui scriptura prodit, Iosiae quoque temporibus legis librum esse repertum, prophetiam quoque una cum vero dei cultu restitutam: at nihilominus paucis post annis sanctissimum regem Iosiam impiissimi idololatrae Nechaonis manu esse interfectum, adeoque eum esse interfectum, qui oraculo a domino acceperat . «Quoniam audisti legem et humiliatus es in conspectu dei, ego quoque exaudivi te et colligam te ad patres tuos, nec videbunt oculi tui malum, quod ego inducturus sum super locum istum» [2 Chr 34,26-28]. Siquidem non multis post annis maxima et principum et populi strage Hierusalem, urbium laudatissima, ab impiis direpta, incensa, et funditus excisa est . Caussam istis reddidit Ieremias in 16 [11f]: «Eo, quod patres vestri dereliquerunt me, ait dominus, et secuti sunt deos alienos, quos et coluerunt et ado- raverunt, me autem deseruerunt et legem meam non custodierunt. Vos quoque sceleribus vestris malitiam patrum vestrorum superavistis. Quisque enim vestrum sequitur pravas cogitationes cordis sui mali, quominus mihi pareat». Quibus si nostra conferamus tempora, quid, oro, similius? Restituta enim est lex domini, sed pereunt protinus optimi viri. Et quid postea? Praedicatur equidem alicubi veritas, sed ea nihilosetius una cum deo floccipenditur. Nam ex prophetis alii quidem in papa mendacium prophetant, alii vero, qui a veritate stare videntur, ea parte plus, quam decet, muti sunt, qua tamen maxime vocales esse oportebat, siquidem de charitate, lenitate et divina miseratione suaviter et maximo vulgi plausu commentantur, ubi de iusticia disserendum erat eaque severiter protrahenda scelera, quibus totus orbis hodie scatet. Ipse enim magistratus, cuius erat aequitatem et iusticiam colere, partim innocentes veritatis nomine in exilium pellit et iugulat, veritatem ipsam proscribit et sanguine civium vivit, partim religionem simulat ideoque et iudicium et iusticiam negligit, imo et ipse vim facit, personas suscipit, perpotat, scortatur, luxu vestium, alea, immoderatis venationibus, fastu et pompa concoquit, quicquid in publico erat aerario, deinde vero novis exactionibus, alienis bellis et malis artibus totas populi enervat cum vires tum opes.
seg.output: What else shall I mention John, the son of Zechariah, whom no other man born of women was more holy, or our vessel of election Paul? The former was killed by the most impure Herod, even in prison, by the counsel of a most shameless harlot; the latter was beheaded by the most cruel thief of all, Domitian Nero, as a disturber of public peace. Nevertheless, no one but the most wicked doubted the doctrine and life of these two, on account of their punishments. Why then do these Zwinglians of ours draw the death of he to the condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is plain that nothing is desired of the godly? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? Also: "The time cometh, that whosoever killeth you will think that he doeth God service" [John 16:2]. Or do they not know, that "we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God" [Acts 14:21]? Or shall they preach the gospel to the world, that they may suffer nothing, always please men, offend no man, enjoy delights, and promise security to their followers? A strange mode of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, incurring the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God" [Gal. 1:10]. And: "They who desire to please men in the flesh, compel you to be circumcised, only that they may not suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Gal. 6:12]. But if these men think otherwise, why, I pray, are we so vilified, and that chiefly on this account, that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, defamed, stripped of our goods, beaten, and daily put in expectation of death? Why do they threaten daily that even the survivors of his (as they call it) sect shall be destroyed? As if they had found out a kind of doctrine, to which none who adhere could be safe from the reach of the sword. But believe me, most illustrious Prince, these are not our times which deserve lenity and security, nor are we such at present, who can or will bear a free profession of the truth. Since therefore it so well agrees with us, who profess the word, and the world (for none forbid it to be approved by the godly), it is to be feared, that many things are done by us through flattery, and a great many more omitted through a cowardly fear. And that I may speak freely with you, most clement Prince, this is no less to be feared, that our affairs will shortly come to pass in such a manner, that we shall wish ourselves to be involved in the same ruin with those whom we now devote to destruction, and call them most happy who have had an opportunity of bravely suffering for truth and their country, what we miserable men shall be forced shortly to undergo all over Germany with much greater cruelty. And oh that I were a false prophet! Yet the scripture tells us, that in the days of Josiah a book of the law was found, and prophecy with the true worship of God restored; yet not long after, the most holy King Josiah was slain by the wicked idolater Necho; so that he perished, who by the command of the Lord had received this oracle: "Because thou hast humbled thyself before me, and hast heard my words, I have also heard thee, and will gather thee to thy fathers, and thou shalt not see the evil which I will bring upon this place" [2 Chron. 34:26-28]. For not long after, with the greatest slaughter of princes and people, the most renowned city of Jerusalem was taken, burnt, and utterly destroyed by the wicked. For which the prophet Jeremiah gives this reason, chap. 16: [11f.], "Because your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and have walked after other gods, whom they have served and worshipped, and have forsaken me, and have not kept my law. And ye have done worse than your fathers; for, behold, ye walk every one after the imagination of his evil heart, that ye may not hearken unto me. Therefore will I cast you out of this land into a land that ye know not, neither ye nor your fathers." If we compare these times with ours, what, I pray, is more like? For the law of the Lord is restored, but straightway the best men perish. And what comes next? The truth is indeed preached in some places, but nevertheless it is contemned together with God. For some of the prophets prophesy lies in the Pope's behalf; and others, who seem to stand for truth, are more mute in that part wherein they ought to have been most vocal, while they sweetly discourse, and with the greatest applause of the people, concerning the love, mildness, and divine mercy, where they ought to have treated of justice, and severely reproved the enormities which the whole world is now filled with. For the magistrate, whose office it was to observe equity and justice, partly banishes and slaughters the innocent in the name of truth, proscribes truth itself, and lives upon the blood of the people; partly he counterfeits religion, and therefore neglects judgment and justice; yea, he himself is guilty of violence, receives persons, is addicted to drinking, whoring, luxury in apparel, gaming, immoderate hunting, pride and pomp; he wastes whatever was in the public treasury; and then he enervates the strength and wealth of the people by new exactions, foreign wars, and evil devices.

seg.output:
Denique pauci sunt, qui bonam mentem in se habeant, qui de veritate possint aut velint cogitare, qui et de se et de alio iudicare sapiunt, qui sint iusti, qui maritos et parentes velint esse, qui deo possint, velint, amice placere.
What else should I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, who was more holy than any other man born of women, or the vessel of election, our Paul? John was killed by the most filthy harlot, Herod, even while he was in prison, and Paul was beheaded by the most cruel robber of all, Domitius Nero, as a disturber of the public peace. Nevertheless, no one but the most wicked doubted the doctrine and life of these two, on account of their punishments. Why then do our Zwinglians draw the death of this man to a condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is clear that nothing but what is pious is desired in him? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: “If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you” [John 15:20]? Also, “There will come a time when whoever kills you will think he is doing service to God” [John 16:2]. Or do they not know that “we must enter the kingdom of God through many tribulations” [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world so as to never suffer anything, always pleasing everyone, not offending anyone, enjoying delights, and promising security to their followers? A new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, receiving the hatred of all men, cried out: “If we had pleased men, we would not have been the servants of God” [Galatians 1:10]. And: “Those who desire to please men in the flesh, they compel you to be circumcised, only that they may not suffer persecution for the cross of Christ” [Galatians 6:12]. If these men have a different opinion, why, I pray, are we so despised, and especially on the grounds that we suffer from the enemies of the truth, are treated with contempt, deprived of our substance, slain, and daily afflicted with the expectation of death? Why do they threaten that the survivors of this (as they say) sect will also be destroyed? As if they had found a kind of doctrine, to which whoever adheres will remain safe from any attack. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not times that merit leniency and security, nor are we so today, who can bear or wish for free truth. Therefore, since it is so suitable to us who presume to speak the word and to the world (for no one forbids it to be approved by the pious), it is to be feared that much is done by us through flattery, and much more omitted through cowardly fear. And to speak freely with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will shortly come to such a pass, that we shall heartily wish to have been intercepted by the Capellan disaster with those whom we now devote to dire curses, and that we may call them most happy who have been allowed to bravely oppose for the truth and their country, what wretched ones we shall be forced to experience throughout all Germany. And would that I were a vain prophet. But the scripture shows that in the time of Josiah the book of the law was found and the prophecy, together with the true worship of God, restored; yet a few years after the most holy king Josiah was slain by the hands of the most wicked idolator Nechaon; so that he was slain who had received by oracle from the Lord, “Because thou hast heard the law and hast been humbled before the Lord, I have also heard thee, and have gathered thee to thy fathers, and thine eyes shall not see the evil that I will bring upon this place” [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. For a few years after that, the most noble city of Jerusalem, most renowned of cities, was despoiled, set on fire, and utterly destroyed by the wicked. The cause of it Jereomiah shows in 16 [11f]: “For thus saith the Lord, because your fathers have forsaken me, and have walked after other gods, and have served them, and have worshipped them, and have forsaken me, and have not kept my law; and ye have done worse than your fathers; for, behold, ye walk every one after the imagination of his evil heart, that they may not hearken unto me”. If we compare our times to these, what, I pray, is more like it? For the law of the Lord is restored, but immediately the best of men perish. And what after this? The truth is indeed preached somewhere, but yet, notwithstanding, it is slighted with God, by the Papists prophesying lies in his name; and by those who seem to stand for the truth, being silent on that part where they ought to be most vocal, viz. of the sweetness, gentleness, and divine mercy, which they may delightfully and to the greatest applause of the people discourse of, when it is to be discoursed of justice, and that in a severe way, since the world is now overrun with wickedness. For the magistrate, whose duty it is to maintain justice and equity, partly banishes and slays the innocent in the name of the truth, proscribes the truth itself, and lives upon the blood of his subjects; partly pretends religion, and so neglects judgment and justice, yea, and himself does violence, receives persons, is drunk, whores, spends his substance in superfluous apparel, gaming, immoderate hunting, ostentation, and pomp, wastes what was in the public treasury, and afterwards by new exactions, foreign wars, and wicked arts enervates both the strength and riches of the people. The people also cheat, lie, swear and forswear, are drunken, and yet as freely spend their substance in luxury; which they had gotten by their wicked arts. Finally, there are few that have a good mind, that can or will think of the truth, that can judge aright of themselves and others, that are just, that will be husbands and parents, that can and will please God in a friendly way.

Ipse enim magistratus, cuius erat aequitatem et iusticiam colere, partim innocentes veritatis nomine in exilium pellit et iugulat, veritatem ipsam proscribit et sanguine civium vivit, partim religionem simulat ideoque et iudicium et iusticiam negligit, imo et ipse vim facit, personas suscipit, perpotat, scortatur, luxu vestium, alea, immoderatis venationibus, fastu et pompa concoquit, quicquid in publico erat aerario, deinde vero novis exactionibus, alienis bellis et malis artibus totas populi enervat cum vires tum opes. Populus quoque ipse frau- dat, mentitur, iurat et peiurat, potat et nihilo segnius luxu dissipat, quod malis artibus collegerat. Interea vero omnes suaviter commentamur de evangelio, sed nemo vitam mutat in melius, nemo ita, ut decebat, accusat scelera, nemo protrahit et conficit .
seg.output: What more shall I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, whom no other man born of women was holier, and about our Paul, the vessel of election? The former, by the counsel of a most shameful whore, was even slain in prison by the most impure Herod, and the latter, as a disturber of public peace, was beheaded by the most cruel robber, Domitian Nero, of all who have been and ever shall be. Nevertheless, no one but the most impious has called in doubt the doctrine and life of these two on account of their punishments. Why then do these of ours, Zuinglius, draw his death to the damnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is sufficiently known that nothing is desired from the godly? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20] and "The time will come, that whosoever kills you will think that he does God service" [John 16:2]? Or do they not know that "we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God" [Acts 14:21]? Or shall they preach the gospel to the world in such a manner that they shall suffer nothing, always please, offend no man, enjoy delights, and promise security to their followers? A most new fashion of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, taking upon them the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God" [Galatians 1:10], and "they that seek to please men in the flesh, compel you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Galatians 6:12]. If they have any other thought, why are we so much vilified, and especially for this, that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, treated with reproaches, despoiled of our substance, beaten, and daily oppressed with the expectation of death? Why do they daily threaten that even those that survive of his (as they call it) sect shall perish? As if they have found a kind of doctrine, to which, if any man adhere, he shall be out of the reach of all danger. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not our times, which deserve lenity and security; nor are we such at this day, that can or will bear free truth. Wherefore, since it is so well agreed between us, that preach with the word, and the world (for none forbids it to the godly), it is to be feared that much will be done by us through flattery, and much more left undone through cowardly fear. And, to speak freely with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will shortly come to pass, that we shall wish ourselves to be involved in the same calamity which we now execrate, and to have been intercepted by the Cappelan stroke, and to have been the most happy of all, to whom it was granted, through love of truth and country, to suffer bravely that which the miserable shall be constrained to suffer in all Germany, with much greater cruelty. And would to God I were a false prophet. But the Scripture informs us, that in the days of Josiah a book of the law was found, and the worship of the true God restored; yet a few years after that most holy king was slain by the hand of the wicked idolater Necho, notwithstanding he had received this oracle from the Lord, "Because thou hast humbled thyself before the Lord, and hast mourned for the affliction of the poor, I also have heard thee, saith the Lord; and I will gather thee to thy fathers, and thou shalt not see the evil which I will bring upon this place" [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. Yea, a few years after, the most famous city of Jerusalem, was spoyled, burnt, and utterly destroyed by the wicked, to which the prophet Jeremiah gives this reason in the 11th chapter, "Because your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and have followed other gods, and have served them, and have worshipped them, and have forsaken me, and have not kept my law: and you have done worse than your fathers; for, behold, ye walk every one after the imagination of his evil heart, that they may not hearken unto me." If we compare these things with our times, what do we see more like? For the law of the Lord is restored, but the best men immediately perish. And what comes after? The truth is indeed preached in some places, but it is contemned and blasphemed with God. For some of the prophets prophesy lies in the Pope's name, and others, who seem to stand for truth, are too silent in that place, where they should speak loudest; when they discourse sweetly and with much applause of the people, of charity, meekness, and divine mercy, they should have been most severe and pressing in pressing and confuting of those sins wherewith the world doth now abound. The magistrate himself, whose office it was to maintain equity and justice, partly by banishing and killing of the innocent in the name of truth, doth proscribe truth itself, and liveth upon the blood of his subjects; partly he feigneth religion, and so neglecteth both judgment and justice, yea, he himself doth violence, receiveth persons, is given to drunkenness, whoredom, excess in apparel, gaming, immoderate hunting, pride, and pomp; he devoureth whatsoever was in the public treasury; and after that, by new exactions, foreign wars, and wicked practices, he enervateth both the strength and wealth of whole nations. The people also defraud, lie, swear, and forswear, drink, and no less waste their substance in luxury; which they had gotten by evil arts. Mean while all of us sweetly discourse of the gospel, but no man changeth his life to the better; no man accuseth sins as he should do; no man presseth and concludeth.

seg.input: Quid praeterea commemorem Ioannem, Zachariae filium, quo sanctior alius a mulieribus nemo prognatus est, quid vas electionis Paulum nostrum? Quorum ille consilio turpissimi scorti ab omnium impurissimo Herode etiam in carcere caesus, hic vero ceu publicae pacis interturbator ab omnium, qui sunt et fuerunt, crudelissimo latrone Domitio Nerone truncatus est capite. Interim vero nemo nisi impiissimus quisque doctrinam et vitam istorum propter supplicia posuit in dubium . Cur ergo isti Zuinglii nostri interitum trahunt ad damnationem fidei eius et doctrinae, cum satis constet in iis a piis desiderari nihil? An vero obliti sunt verborum domini: «Si me persecuti sunt et vos persequentur» [Ioh 15,20]? Item: «Veniet tempus, ut quisquis interficiat vos, videatur cultum praestare deo» [Ioh 16,2]. An ignorant, quod «per multas afflictiones oporteat nos intrare in regnum dei» [Apg 14,21]? An vero evangelium ita orbi praedicabunt, ut nihil patiantur, semper placeant, neminem offendant, delitiis fruantur et securi sequacibus securitatem polliceantur? Novus sane praedicandi modus, prophetis et apostolis incognitus. Illi enim omnium hominum odia in se suscipientes clamabant: «Si hominibus placuissemus, servi dei nequaquam essemus» [Gal 1,10]. Et: «Qui iuxta faciem volunt placere in carne, cogunt vos circuncidi, tantum ne ob crucem Christi persecutionem patiantur» [Gal 6,12]. Quodsi aliud sentiunt isti, cur, obsecro, nos adeo vilipendimur, idque eo potissimum nomine, quod ab hostibus veritatis affligimur, contumeliis afficimur, substantia nostra exuimur, caedimur et quotidie mortis expectatione angimur? Cur indies minantur interituros etiam superstites eius (ut aiunt) sectae viros? Quasi vero ipsi doctrinae genus invenerint, cui qui adhaereat, extra omnem teli iactum constiterit. At mihi crede, illustrissime princeps: Non ea sunt nostra tempora, quae lenitatem et securitatem mereantur, neque tales hodie sumus, qui liberam veritatem ferre aut possimus aut velimus. Cum itaque nobis, qui verbo praesumus, cum mundo (nemo enim piis probari vetat) tam bene conveniat, verendum est plurima a nobis per adulationem fieri et multo plura per ignavum timorem omitti. Et ut libere tecum loquar, princeps clementissime, id non minus timendum est, eo res nostras brevi deventuras, ut communibus votis optemus nos una cum iis, quos nunc diris devovemus, illa clade Capellana interceptos dicamusque eos esse foelicissimos, quibus pro veritate et patria fortiter oppetere contigit, quod miseri longe crudeliora tandem per universam Germaniam experiri cogemur. Atque utinam vanus sim vates. Atqui scriptura prodit, Iosiae quoque temporibus legis librum esse repertum, prophetiam quoque una cum vero dei cultu restitutam: at nihilominus paucis post annis sanctissimum regem Iosiam impiissimi idololatrae Nechaonis manu esse interfectum, adeoque eum esse interfectum, qui oraculo a domino acceperat . «Quoniam audisti legem et humiliatus es in conspectu dei, ego quoque exaudivi te et colligam te ad patres tuos, nec videbunt oculi tui malum, quod ego inducturus sum super locum istum» [2 Chr 34,26-28]. Siquidem non multis post annis maxima et principum et populi strage Hierusalem, urbium laudatissima, ab impiis direpta, incensa, et funditus excisa est . Caussam istis reddidit Ieremias in 16 [11f]: «Eo, quod patres vestri dereliquerunt me, ait dominus, et secuti sunt deos alienos, quos et coluerunt et ado- raverunt, me autem deseruerunt et legem meam non custodierunt. Vos quoque sceleribus vestris malitiam patrum vestrorum superavistis. Quisque enim vestrum sequitur pravas cogitationes cordis sui mali, quominus mihi pareat». Quibus si nostra conferamus tempora, quid, oro, similius? Restituta enim est lex domini, sed pereunt protinus optimi viri. Et quid postea? Praedicatur equidem alicubi veritas, sed ea nihilosetius una cum deo floccipenditur. Nam ex prophetis alii quidem in papa mendacium prophetant, alii vero, qui a veritate stare videntur, ea parte plus, quam decet, muti sunt, qua tamen maxime vocales esse oportebat, siquidem de charitate, lenitate et divina miseratione suaviter et maximo vulgi plausu commentantur, ubi de iusticia disserendum erat eaque severiter protrahenda scelera, quibus totus orbis hodie scatet. Ipse enim magistratus, cuius erat aequitatem et iusticiam colere, partim innocentes veritatis nomine in exilium pellit et iugulat, veritatem ipsam proscribit et sanguine civium vivit, partim religionem simulat ideoque et iudicium et iusticiam negligit, imo et ipse vim facit, personas suscipit, perpotat, scortatur, luxu vestium, alea, immoderatis venationibus, fastu et pompa concoquit, quicquid in publico erat aerario, deinde vero novis exactionibus, alienis bellis et malis artibus totas populi enervat cum vires tum opes. Populus quoque ipse frau- dat, mentitur, iurat et peiurat, potat et nihilo segnius luxu dissipat, quod malis artibus collegerat. Interea vero omnes suaviter commentamur de evangelio, sed nemo vitam mutat in melius, nemo ita, ut decebat, accusat scelera, nemo protrahit et conficit . Quid autem dicam de monopolis, crematistis [!], publicanis et usurariis, qui omnes suas illas iniquitatis radices tam alte egerunt, tu annosam quercum minori negotio evellas, quam istos redigas in ordinem?
seg.output: What further should I recall about John, the son of Zechariah, whom no other man born of women was holier, or about our vessel of election, Paul? The former was slaughtered in prison even by the most impure of all, King Herod, on the advice of a most shameful harlot, and the latter was beheaded by the most cruel of all tyrants, Domitius Nero, as a disturber of the public peace. Yet no one except the most impious has ever called into question their doctrine and their life on account of their punishments. Why then do our Zwinglians drag his death to the condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is clear that nothing is sought from the pious? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord, "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? And again, "A time is coming when anyone who kills you will think he is offering service to God" [John 16:2]. Or do they ignore that "It is through many tribulations that we must enter the kingdom of God" [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world so as to suffer nothing, always to please everyone, to offend no one, to indulge in pleasure, and to promise security to their followers? This is certainly a new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, drawing the hatred of all men upon themselves, cried out, "If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God" [Gal. 1:10], and again, "Those who seek to please men in the flesh, compel you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution on account of the cross of Christ" [Gal. 6:12]. If this is not the sentiment of these people, then why, I pray, are we so despised, especially on the grounds that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, dishonoured, stripped of our possessions, beaten, and daily brought to the brink of death? Why do they daily threaten even the survivors (as they say) of his sect with destruction? As if they had discovered a form of doctrine to which whoever adheres will be assured of protection from every weapon. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not the times that merit leniency and security, nor are we of such disposition today as to be able to bear or to be willing to bear free truth. For since it is so well suited to us, who presume to speak the word, and to the world (for no one forbids it to the pious), it is to be feared that many things are done by us through flattery and much more is left undone through a cowardly fear. And to speak freely with you, most clement prince, this is no less to be feared, that our affairs will shortly fall out so that we should wish ourselves to have been intercepted by the same calamity that we now devote to dire curses, and should say that those are most fortunate who had the courage to suffer for truth and country, whereas we, the miserable, must endure far worse throughout Germany. And may I be a false prophet! But the Scripture shows that in the days of Josiah the book of the Law was found and the true worship of God was restored. Yet a few years later the most holy king Josiah was slain by the hand of the most impious idolater Necho, even he to whom the Lord had promised by oracle, "Because thou hast heard the words of the Law, and hast humbled thyself before the Lord, I have heard thee also, and will gather thee to thy fathers, and thine eyes shall not see all the evil which I shall bring upon this place" [2 Chron. 34:26-28]. And what followed? For a few years after, there was the greatest slaughter of princes and people, Jerusalem, the most famous of cities, was sacked, burnt, and utterly destroyed by the impious. The cause of it the prophet Jeremiah sets forth in the 16th, saying, "Your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and have followed strange gods, whom they have served and worshipped; but me they have forsaken, and kept not my law. And you have done worse than your fathers; for, behold, ye walk every one after the imagination of his evil heart, that ye may not hearken unto me" [11 ff]. How shall we compare this to our times? For the law of the Lord is restored, but immediately the best of men perish. And what follows? The truth is indeed preached somewhere, but it is nevertheless despised together with God. For some of the prophets prophesy lies in the pope, and others, who seem to stand by the truth, are too silent in that part where they should have spoken loudest, whilst they sweetly discourse and with greatest applause of the people of charity, meekness, and divine mercy, where it were meet to discourse of justice and severely to punish the crimes with which the world is at this day overspread. For the magistrates, to whom it appertaineth to exercise equity and justice, partly banish and behead the innocent in the name of truth, proscribe truth itself, and live upon the blood of their subjects, partly counterfeit religion, and so neglect judgment and justice, yea, and ofttimes force, receive persons, drink to excess, play the whore, waste their substance in apparel, gaming, hunting, pride, and pomp, and impoverish the people of all that was left in the public treasury, and afterwards by new exactions, foreign wars, and evil arts, enervate both their strength and their substance. The people also defraud, lie, swear and forswear, drink and no less wastefully spend what they had gotten by evil arts. Yet all sweetly discourse of the gospel, but none amend their life, none accuse wickedness as they ought, and none bring to punishment and finish it. What shall I say of monopolists, cheaters [!], publicans, and usurers, who have so deep rooted these their iniquities, that it were easier to pluck up an old oak than to reduce them to order?

seg.output: What else should I mention about John, son of Zechariah, who was born of more holy women than anyone else, or our vessel of election, Paul? The former was killed in prison by the most impure Herod, because of the advice of a very wicked prostitute, and the latter was beheaded by the most cruel tyrant of all, Domitian Nero, as a disturber of public peace. Nevertheless, no one except the most impious has ever doubted the doctrine and life of these men on account of their punishments. Why then do our Zwinglians draw his death to condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is sufficiently clear that the pious have nothing to desire from them? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: “If they persecuted me, they will also persecute you” [John 15:20]? Likewise, “It will come to pass that whoever kills you will think that he is doing God a service” [John 16:2]. Do they not know that “We must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God” [Acts 14:21]? Or shall they preach the gospel to the world so that they may suffer nothing, always please, offend no one, enjoy delights and promise security to their followers? This is indeed a new manner of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, drawing the hatred of all men upon themselves, cried out: “If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God” [Galatians 1:10]. And: “They that desire to make a fair show in the flesh, they constrain you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ” [Galatians 6:12]. If these men have other sentiments, why, I pray, are we so vilified, and that especially on the ground that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, disgraced, stripped of our substance, bruised and daily harassed with the expectation of death? Why do they threaten daily that even the survivors of his (as they say) sect shall perish? As though they had found a kind of doctrine, to which he that adheres is out of the reach of every dart. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not our times which deserve lenity and security, nor are we such men as can bear a free truth, or will. Since, therefore, we that presume to preach the word, agree so well with the world (for none forbids the pious to be approved) it were to be feared that much will be done by us to please by flattery, and much more omitted through a cowardly fear. And to speak freely with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will shortly fall out so, that we shall wish ourselves to be included in the same destruction with those whom we now devote to dismal curses, and say that those are the most happy who have been intercepted by the Capellan calamity for the truth and their country, and courageously opposed what we shall be forced to endure in a far more cruel manner through all Germany. And would to God I were a false prophet. But the scripture shows that even in the time of Josiah a book of the law was found, and the worship of the true God restored; yet a few years after, the most holy king Josiah was slain by the hand of the impious idolater Necho, notwithstanding he had received an oracle from the Lord, saying: “Because thou hast humbled thyself before the Lord when thou heardest the words against this place, and hast humbled thyself before me, and hast rent thy clothes, and wept before me; I have even heard thee also, saith the Lord. Behold, I will gather thee to thy fathers, and thou shalt be gathered to thy grave in peace, and thine eyes shall not see all the evil which I will bring upon this place” [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. For a few years after, Jerusalem, the most renowned of cities, was plundered, burned, and destroyed by the impious. The cause was given by Jeremiah, in chap. 11 [v. 16f.]: “Because your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and have walked after other gods, and have served them, and have worshipped them, and have forsaken me, and have not kept my law; and you have done worse than your fathers; for, behold, ye walk every one after the imagination of his evil heart, that they may not hearken unto me”. If we compare our times with these, what, I pray, is more like? The law of the Lord is indeed restored; but immediately the best of men perish. And what after? Truth is indeed preached in some places; but yet that is contemned with God, notwithstanding. For some of the prophets lie in the pope’s name, and others, which seem to stand in the truth, are too much silent in that point, wherein they should have been most vocal, namely, wherein they should have sweetly and with greatest applause of the multitude commented on charity, lenity, and divine mercy, and severely reproved the sins, wherein the world doth now abound. The magistrate also, whose duty it was to set forth equity and justice, partly banisheth and beheadeth the innocent in the name of truth, and proscribeth truth itself, and liveth on the blood of the people, partly feigned religion, and therefore neglecteth judgment and justice, yea, and himself doth violence, receiveth persons, drinketh, whoremongeth, decketh himself in bravery of apparel, playeth, hunteth immoderately, and with pride and pomp consumeth what was in the public treasury, and then by new exactions, foreign wars, and evil devices, enervateth both the strength and riches of the people. The people also defraud, lie, swear falsely, and spend their wealth in luxury no less than in drinking; which they had gotten by evil arts. In the meantime, all men sweetly comment on the gospel, but no man amendeth his life for the better, no man accuseth the sins, as he ought, no one exacteth and performeth justice; what shall I say of monopolists, usurers, and tax-gatherers, who have rooted so deep their iniquities, that thou mayst sooner pluck up an ancient oak, than reduce them to order? These spoil the whole world, and have the negotiation and treasure of all the world in their hands; and being raised up hereby by theft, fraud, and rapine, yet none of them, which will be seen to be pillars of the Christian religion, oppose themselves unto them.

seg.input: Quid praeterea commemorem Ioannem, Zachariae filium, quo sanctior alius a mulieribus nemo prognatus est, quid vas electionis Paulum nostrum? Quorum ille consilio turpissimi scorti ab omnium impurissimo Herode etiam in carcere caesus, hic vero ceu publicae pacis interturbator ab omnium, qui sunt et fuerunt, crudelissimo latrone Domitio Nerone truncatus est capite. Interim vero nemo nisi impiissimus quisque doctrinam et vitam istorum propter supplicia posuit in dubium . Cur ergo isti Zuinglii nostri interitum trahunt ad damnationem fidei eius et doctrinae, cum satis constet in iis a piis desiderari nihil? An vero obliti sunt verborum domini: «Si me persecuti sunt et vos persequentur» [Ioh 15,20]? Item: «Veniet tempus, ut quisquis interficiat vos, videatur cultum praestare deo» [Ioh 16,2]. An ignorant, quod «per multas afflictiones oporteat nos intrare in regnum dei» [Apg 14,21]? An vero evangelium ita orbi praedicabunt, ut nihil patiantur, semper placeant, neminem offendant, delitiis fruantur et securi sequacibus securitatem polliceantur? Novus sane praedicandi modus, prophetis et apostolis incognitus. Illi enim omnium hominum odia in se suscipientes clamabant: «Si hominibus placuissemus, servi dei nequaquam essemus» [Gal 1,10]. Et: «Qui iuxta faciem volunt placere in carne, cogunt vos circuncidi, tantum ne ob crucem Christi persecutionem patiantur» [Gal 6,12]. Quodsi aliud sentiunt isti, cur, obsecro, nos adeo vilipendimur, idque eo potissimum nomine, quod ab hostibus veritatis affligimur, contumeliis afficimur, substantia nostra exuimur, caedimur et quotidie mortis expectatione angimur? Cur indies minantur interituros etiam superstites eius (ut aiunt) sectae viros? Quasi vero ipsi doctrinae genus invenerint, cui qui adhaereat, extra omnem teli iactum constiterit. At mihi crede, illustrissime princeps: Non ea sunt nostra tempora, quae lenitatem et securitatem mereantur, neque tales hodie sumus, qui liberam veritatem ferre aut possimus aut velimus. Cum itaque nobis, qui verbo praesumus, cum mundo (nemo enim piis probari vetat) tam bene conveniat, verendum est plurima a nobis per adulationem fieri et multo plura per ignavum timorem omitti. Et ut libere tecum loquar, princeps clementissime, id non minus timendum est, eo res nostras brevi deventuras, ut communibus votis optemus nos una cum iis, quos nunc diris devovemus, illa clade Capellana interceptos dicamusque eos esse foelicissimos, quibus pro veritate et patria fortiter oppetere contigit, quod miseri longe crudeliora tandem per universam Germaniam experiri cogemur. Atque utinam vanus sim vates. Atqui scriptura prodit, Iosiae quoque temporibus legis librum esse repertum, prophetiam quoque una cum vero dei cultu restitutam: at nihilominus paucis post annis sanctissimum regem Iosiam impiissimi idololatrae Nechaonis manu esse interfectum, adeoque eum esse interfectum, qui oraculo a domino acceperat . «Quoniam audisti legem et humiliatus es in conspectu dei, ego quoque exaudivi te et colligam te ad patres tuos, nec videbunt oculi tui malum, quod ego inducturus sum super locum istum» [2 Chr 34,26-28]. Siquidem non multis post annis maxima et principum et populi strage Hierusalem, urbium laudatissima, ab impiis direpta, incensa, et funditus excisa est . Caussam istis reddidit Ieremias in 16 [11f]: «Eo, quod patres vestri dereliquerunt me, ait dominus, et secuti sunt deos alienos, quos et coluerunt et ado- raverunt, me autem deseruerunt et legem meam non custodierunt. Vos quoque sceleribus vestris malitiam patrum vestrorum superavistis. Quisque enim vestrum sequitur pravas cogitationes cordis sui mali, quominus mihi pareat». Quibus si nostra conferamus tempora, quid, oro, similius? Restituta enim est lex domini, sed pereunt protinus optimi viri. Et quid postea? Praedicatur equidem alicubi veritas, sed ea nihilosetius una cum deo floccipenditur. Nam ex prophetis alii quidem in papa mendacium prophetant, alii vero, qui a veritate stare videntur, ea parte plus, quam decet, muti sunt, qua tamen maxime vocales esse oportebat, siquidem de charitate, lenitate et divina miseratione suaviter et maximo vulgi plausu commentantur, ubi de iusticia disserendum erat eaque severiter protrahenda scelera, quibus totus orbis hodie scatet. Ipse enim magistratus, cuius erat aequitatem et iusticiam colere, partim innocentes veritatis nomine in exilium pellit et iugulat, veritatem ipsam proscribit et sanguine civium vivit, partim religionem simulat ideoque et iudicium et iusticiam negligit, imo et ipse vim facit, personas suscipit, perpotat, scortatur, luxu vestium, alea, immoderatis venationibus, fastu et pompa concoquit, quicquid in publico erat aerario, deinde vero novis exactionibus, alienis bellis et malis artibus totas populi enervat cum vires tum opes. Populus quoque ipse frau- dat, mentitur, iurat et peiurat, potat et nihilo segnius luxu dissipat, quod malis artibus collegerat. Interea vero omnes suaviter commentamur de evangelio, sed nemo vitam mutat in melius, nemo ita, ut decebat, accusat scelera, nemo protrahit et conficit . Quid autem dicam de monopolis, crematistis [!], publicanis et usurariis, qui omnes suas illas iniquitatis radices tam alte egerunt, tu annosam quercum minori negotio evellas, quam istos redigas in ordinem? Hi impune totum orbem expilant, in horum manibus sunt totius orbis negotiationes et thesauri, cumque eo per furtum, fraudem et rapinam evecti sint, nemo tamen ex illis, qui christianae religionis columina videri volunt, se illis vel mediocriter opponit. Ita fit, ut vi quadam res nostrae agantur, pauperes opprimantur ipseque iudex (ut propheta ait) in reddendo sit .
seg.output: What else shall I mention about John, son of Zechariah, of whom no man born of women was more holy, or our vessel of election Paul? The former was put to death in prison, by the most impure Herod, even on the advice of a most despicable harlot; but the latter was beheaded by the most cruel tyrant of all, Domitius Nero, as an disturber of the public peace. Nevertheless, no one, except the most impious, ever doubted their doctrine and life on account of their sufferings. Why then do our Zuinglians draw his death to the condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is manifest that nothing is desired from the pious? Do they forget the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? Also: "It shall come to pass that whosoever will kill you, will think that he does God a service" [John 16:2]. Do they not know that "we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God" [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world so that they shall suffer nothing, always please, offend no one, enjoy delights, and promise security to their followers? It is a new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, incurring the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had been servants of men, we would not have been servants of God" [Galatians 1:10]. And: "They who will please men in the flesh, compel you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Galatians 6:12]. If they think otherwise, why, I beseech you, are we so much contemned, and that chiefly on this account, that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, treated with contempt, stripped of our substance, beaten, and every day in expectation of death? Why do they threaten continually the death of those who shall survive (as they say) this sect? As though they had found a kind of doctrine, to which whosoever adheres, shall be safe from all darts. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not our times that deserve mildness and safety; nor are we at this day such, as we can or will bear free truth. So that it being so well with us, who presume to speak the truth, with the world (for none forbideth the just to be approved), it is to be feared that much is done by us through flattery, and much more omitted through a cowardly fear. And, that I may freely speak with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared, that our affairs will shortly come to such a pass, that we shall wish those intercepted by the Capellian slaughter, to be happy, who for truth and their country had courageously to undergo what we, wretched men, shall be compelled to suffer with much more cruelty throughout Germany. And would to God I were a false prophet. Yet the scripture tells us, that in the time of Josiah a book of the law was found, and the true worship of God was restored; nevertheless, a few years after, that most holy king Josiah was slain by the hand of the impious idolator Necho; whom the Lord had, by an oracle, assured thus: "Because thou hast humbled thyself before me, and hast heard my words, behold, I will gather thee to thy fathers, and thine eyes shall not see all the evil which I will bring upon this place" [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. For a few years after, Jerusalem, the most renowned of cities, was spoiled, burnt, and utterly destroyed, by the impious. The prophet Jeremiah gave the reason of it, chap. 11 [v. 8-17]: "For thus saith the Lord, Because they have forsaken me, and have followed other gods, and have worshipped them, and served them; therefore thus saith the Lord, Behold, I will bring evil upon them, which they shall not be able to escape; and though they shall cry unto me, I will not hearken unto them. Then shall the cities of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem go, and cry unto the gods unto whom they offer incense; but they shall not save them at all in the time of their trouble. For according to the number of thy cities were thy gods, O Judah; and according to the number of the streets of Jerusalem have ye set up altars to that shameful thing, even altars to burn incense unto Baal. Therefore pray not thou for this people, neither lift up a cry nor prayer for them; for I will not hear them in the time that they cry unto me for their trouble." If we compare our times with these, what, I pray, is more like? For the law of the Lord is restored, but immediately the best of men perish. And what follows? The truth is indeed preached in some places, yet it is contemned with God, notwithstanding. For some of the prophets prophecy lies in the Pope's behalf, and others, who seem to stand for truth, are too much silent in that point wherein they should have been most vocal, viz. in sweetly and with the greatest applause of the people, speaking of charity, meekness, and divine mercy; and severely reproving the crimes, which now fill the whole world. For the magistrate himself, whose office it was to reverence equity and justice, partly drives innocent persons into exile and slays them in the name of truth, and proscribes the truth itself, and lives upon the blood of the people; partly feigns religion, and therefore neglects judgment and justice; yea, he himself uses violence, takes persons, drinks to excess, keeps a harlot, consumes his substance in apparel, gaming, immoderate hunting, pride and pomp; what was in the public treasury he spends, and then by new exactions, foreign wars, and evil designs, he enervates both the strength and riches of the people. The people also commit frauds, lies, swear and forswear, drink and dissipate no less in luxury, what they had gotten by evil trades. Meanwhile, we all discourse sweetly of the gospel, but nobody changes his life for the better; nobody so much as he ought, accuses crimes, nobody reproves and finishes them. What shall I say of monopolies, engrossers, publicans, and usurers, who have so deeply rooted their iniquity, that you may sooner pluck up a year-old oak, than reduce them? These spoil the whole world with impunity, in whose hands are the dealings and treasures of the whole world; and being raised by theft, fraud, and rapine, yet no one of those, who would be thought pillars of the Christian religion, opposes them in the least. So that our affairs are carried on by a kind of violence, the poor are oppressed, and the judge himself, (as the prophet saith) is unjust in judgment.
