seg.output: What else should I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, who was born more holy than any other man by any woman, and our vessel of election Paul? The former was killed in prison by the most impure Herod at the instigation of a most disgraceful harlot, while the latter, as a disturber of public peace, was beheaded by the most cruel robber Domitius Nero. Nevertheless, no one but the most impious questioned the teachings and lives of these men because of their sufferings. So why do our Zwinglians draw the death of John as a condemnation of his faith and teaching, when it is clear that nothing is lacking from his piety? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? And again: "A time is coming when anyone who kills you will think he is offering a service to God" [John 16:2]. Or do they not know that "we must enter the kingdom of God through many tribulations" [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world without suffering anything, always pleasing everyone, offending no one, enjoying pleasures and promising security to their followers? That would be a new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, incurring the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we would not have been servants of God" [Galatians 1:10]. And: "Those who want to make a good impression outwardly in the flesh force you to be circumcised, only so that they may not suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Galatians 6:12]. If these men have other thoughts, why, I beseech you, are we so despised, and especially on the grounds that we are afflicted by the enemies of the truth, reviled, deprived of our property, beaten and daily in expectation of death? Why do they threaten that even the survivors of his (as they call it) sect will perish? As if they had invented a kind of doctrine, which anyone who adheres to it will remain safe from any missile. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not our times, which deserve leniency and security, nor are we today such that we can or want to bear free truth. When, therefore, it is so well suited to us who presume to speak the word, as well as to the world (for no one forbids it to the pious), it is to be feared that much will be done by us through flattery and much more will be omitted through cowardly fear. And to speak frankly with you, most merciful prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will soon come to such a pass that we will wish that we may be taken away by the same disaster that we now devote to the dregs, and may say that they are the most fortunate who, for the truth and their country, had the courage to suffer what we miserable will soon be compelled to experience all over Germany. And would that I were a false prophet. But Scripture reveals that in the time of Josiah a book of the Law was found and that prophecy, with the true worship of God, was restored. Yet a few years afterwards the most holy king Josiah was slain by the hand of the impious idolater Necho, and so he was slain who had received the oracle from the Lord, "Because you have heard the Law and have humbled yourself before God, I too have heard you and will gather you to your fathers, and your eyes shall not see the evil that I am going to bring upon this place" [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. For a few years later Jerusalem, most praised of cities, was plundered, burned and destroyed by the wicked. Jeremiah gave the reason in 16 [11ff]: "Because your fathers have forsaken me, says the Lord, and have followed other gods, which they have served and worshipped, whereas they have forsaken me and not kept my Law. And you have done worse than your fathers. For every one of you follows the evil thoughts of his own wicked heart, so that he may not obey me" [Jeremiah 16: 11ff]. If we compare our times to these, what, I pray, is more similar? For the Law of the Lord is restored, but immediately the best of men perish. And what then? The truth is indeed proclaimed somewhere, but it is nevertheless despised along with God. For some of the prophets prophesy lies in the name of the Pope, while others, who seem to stand by the truth, are more silent than is fitting in that part, where they should have been the loudest, namely when they speak sweetly and to the greatest applause of the people about charity, gentleness and divine mercy, where discourse was to be had about justice and it was to be severely prosecuted for the crimes with which the whole world is today full. For the magistrate, whose duty it was to cultivate equity and justice, partly banishes and beheads the innocent in the name of the truth, proscribes the truth itself and lives on the blood of the citizens, partly simulates religion and therefore neglects judgment and justice, yea, he himself uses violence, receives persons, revels, whores, consumes luxurious clothing, gambling, immoderate hunting, pomp and splendor, whatever was in the public treasury, and then further weakens the strength and riches of the whole people with new exactions, foreign wars and evil arts. The people too defraud, lie, swear and perjury, drink and no less dissipate in luxury what they had gathered with evil arts. Meanwhile all of us speak sweetly about the gospel, but no one changes his life for the better, no one accuses the crimes as is fitting, no one prosecutes and punishes them. What shall I say about the monopolists, usurers, publicans and lenders, who have driven all these roots of iniquity so deep that you can more easily uproot an ancient oak than reduce them to order? These plunder the whole world with impunity, the transactions and treasures of the whole world are in their hands, and since they have been exalted by theft, fraud and rapine, none of those who wish to appear the pillars of the Christian religion in the least oppose them. So it is that our affairs are carried on by some force, the poor are oppressed and the judge himself (as the prophet says) is partial in his judgments. What then can we expect for ourselves but some common pestilence, whether Nebuchadnezzar, Sennacherib, Antiochus, or some other plague of mankind, which once with sword and flame, famine and pestilence will purge this abominable land?

Cum itaque nobis, qui verbo praesumus, cum mundo (nemo enim piis probari vetat) tam bene conveniat, verendum est plurima a nobis per adulationem fieri et multo plura per ignavum timorem omitti. Et ut libere tecum loquar, princeps clementissime, id non minus timendum est, eo res nostras brevi deventuras, ut communibus votis optemus nos una cum iis, quos nunc diris devovemus, illa clade Capellana interceptos dicamusque eos esse foelicissimos, quibus pro veritate et patria fortiter oppetere contigit, quod miseri longe crudeliora tandem per universam Germaniam experiri cogemur. Atque utinam vanus sim vates. Atqui scriptura prodit, Iosiae quoque temporibus legis librum esse repertum, prophetiam quoque una cum vero dei cultu restitutam: at nihilominus paucis post annis sanctissimum regem Iosiam impiissimi idololatrae Nechaonis manu esse interfectum, adeoque eum esse interfectum, qui oraculo a domino acceperat . «Quoniam audisti legem et humiliatus es in conspectu dei, ego quoque exaudivi te et colligam te ad patres tuos, nec videbunt oculi tui malum, quod ego inducturus sum super locum istum» [2 Chr 34,26-28]. Siquidem non multis post annis maxima et principum et populi strage Hierusalem, urbium laudatissima, ab impiis direpta, incensa, et funditus excisa est . Caussam istis reddidit Ieremias in 16 [11f]: «Eo, quod patres vestri dereliquerunt me, ait dominus, et secuti sunt deos alienos, quos et coluerunt et ado- raverunt, me autem deseruerunt et legem meam non custodierunt. Vos quoque sceleribus vestris malitiam patrum vestrorum superavistis. Quisque enim vestrum sequitur pravas cogitationes cordis sui mali, quominus mihi pareat». Quibus si nostra conferamus tempora, quid, oro, similius? Restituta enim est lex domini, sed pereunt protinus optimi viri. Et quid postea? Praedicatur equidem alicubi veritas, sed ea nihilosetius una cum deo floccipenditur. Nam ex prophetis alii quidem in papa mendacium prophetant, alii vero, qui a veritate stare videntur, ea parte plus, quam decet, muti sunt, qua tamen maxime vocales esse oportebat, siquidem de charitate, lenitate et divina miseratione suaviter et maximo vulgi plausu commentantur, ubi de iusticia disserendum erat eaque severiter protrahenda scelera, quibus totus orbis hodie scatet. Ipse enim magistratus, cuius erat aequitatem et iusticiam colere, partim innocentes veritatis nomine in exilium pellit et iugulat, veritatem ipsam proscribit et sanguine civium vivit, partim religionem simulat ideoque et iudicium et iusticiam negligit, imo et ipse vim facit, personas suscipit, perpotat, scortatur, luxu vestium, alea, immoderatis venationibus, fastu et pompa concoquit, quicquid in publico erat aerario, deinde vero novis exactionibus, alienis bellis et malis artibus totas populi enervat cum vires tum opes. Populus quoque ipse frau- dat, mentitur, iurat et peiurat, potat et nihilo segnius luxu dissipat, quod malis artibus collegerat. Interea vero omnes suaviter commentamur de evangelio, sed nemo vitam mutat in melius, nemo ita, ut decebat, accusat scelera, nemo protrahit et conficit . Quid autem dicam de monopolis, crematistis [!], publicanis et usurariis, qui omnes suas illas iniquitatis radices tam alte egerunt, tu annosam quercum minori negotio evellas, quam istos redigas in ordinem? Hi impune totum orbem expilant, in horum manibus sunt totius orbis negotiationes et thesauri, cumque eo per furtum, fraudem et rapinam evecti sint, nemo tamen ex illis, qui christianae religionis columina videri volunt, se illis vel mediocriter opponit. Ita fit, ut vi quadam res nostrae agantur, pauperes opprimantur ipseque iudex (ut propheta ait) in reddendo sit . Quid ergo nobis nisi communis aliqua pestis, vel Nabuchodonosor vel Sanherib vel Antiochus vel alia generis humani lues, expectanda, quae semel ferro et flamma, fame et peste execrabilem hanc terram lustret? Quod ergo Zuinglium sustulit dominus, quod cum eo tot sanctos, tot probos, tot doctos, tot patritios et senatores, tot denique innocentes cives et colonos una hora sustulit, nimirum omine et divino quodam consilio factum est.
seg.output: What further shall I mention about John, the son of Zechariah, who was born of women no holier than him, or our Paul, the vessel of election? The former was put to death in prison by the most impure Herod, even with the counsel of a most shameful harlot, while the latter was beheaded by the most cruel robber of all, Domitian Nero, as a disturber of the public peace. And yet none but the most impious have ever questioned the doctrine and life of these on account of their punishments. Why then do these of ours drag Zwingli's death to the condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is evident that the pious desired nothing else from him? Do they forget the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" (John 15:20)? And again: "The time will come, when whosoever kills you will think he does God service" (John 16:2)? Do they not know that "we must through many tribulations enter into the kingdom of God" (Acts 14:21)? Shall they preach the gospel to the world, so that they shall suffer nothing, always please, offend no man, enjoy delights, and promise security to their followers? A new way of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, drawing upon themselves the hatred of all men, cried out: "Had we been pleasing to men, we should not have been the servants of God" (Galatians 1:10). And again: "They who are of the flesh seek to please men; they compel you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" (Galatians 6:12). But if these think otherwise, why, I pray, are we so vilified, and that by this especially, that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, disgraced, stripped of our possessions, slain, and daily brought into expectation of death? Why do they threaten daily that the survivors of those (as they say) will also perish? As if they had found a kind of doctrine, to which he that adhereth shall be secure from all darts. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not our times which deserve gentleness and security, nor are we such as can or will bear free truth. Since therefore it is so well with us who presume to speak the word, with the world (for none forbideth the pious to be approved), it is to be feared that much will be done by us through flattery, and much more omitted through a cowardly fear. And that I may speak freely with you, most clement prince, it is no less to be feared that our affairs will shortly come to pass, that we shall wish ourselves to be taken away with those whom we now devote to destruction by this Capellan slaughter, and that we shall say they are most happy who had it in their power to suffer for truth and their country bravely, what we wretched shall be forced to endure throughout all Germany, with much more cruelty. And would to God I were a false prophet. But the Scripture shows that in the time of Josiah was found a book of the law, and prophecy restored together with the true worship of God; yet a few years after, the most holy king Josiah was slain by the hands of the most impious idolater Nechoh; so that he was slain who had received this oracle from the Lord: "Because thou hast heard the law, and humbled thyself before the Lord, I also have heard thee, and I will gather thee to thy fathers, and thine eyes shall not see the evil which I will bring upon this place" (2 Chronicles 34:26-28). For a few years after, Jerusalem, that famous city, was spoiled, burned, and totally destroyed by the impious. The cause of this Jeremiah gives us in chapter 16 [11f]: "For your fathers have forsaken Me, saith the Lord, and have followed strange gods, and have served them, and have worshipped them, and have forsaken Me, and have not kept My law. And you have done worse than your fathers; for, behold, every one of you walketh after the imagination of his own evil heart, that he may not hearken unto Me" (Jeremiah 16:11-12). If we compare our times with these, what, I pray, is more like? For the law of the Lord is restored, but the best men presently perish. And what comes after? The truth is indeed preached in some places, but it is nevertheless, with God, contemned. For some of the prophets prophesy lies in the pope's name; others, who seem to stand to the truth, are too much silent in that part where they should have been most vocal, treating sweetly and to the great applause of the people of charity, gentleness, and divine mercy; when they should have disputed of justice, and have severely punished the sins wherewith the whole world is now filled. The magistrate himself, whose part it was to keep equity and justice, sends some innocent persons into banishment and slays them in the name of truth, and proscribeth truth itself, and lives upon the blood of his subjects; and counterfeits religion, and therefore neglects justice and judgment; yea, and does violence himself, receives persons, drinks, whores, spends upon apparel, gaming, immoderate hunting, pomp and pride, all that was in the public treasury, and afterwards upon new exactions, foreign wars, and bad practices, enervates the strength and riches of all the people. The people also cheat, lie, swear, perjure, drink, and no less spend upon luxury, what they had got by bad practices. And all this while we sweetly discourse of the gospel, but no man changes his life to the better, no man accuseth sins as he ought, no man punishes and reformeth them. What shall I say of monopolies, crematists [!], publicans, and usurers, who have rooted these their iniquities so deep, that you may sooner pluck up an old oak tree than reduce them to order? These spoil the whole world with impunity, all traffick and treasures are in their hands; and being lifted up by theft, fraud, and rapine, yet none of those who will be seen to bear the columns of Christianity, makes any opposition to them. So that things are carried by a kind of violence, the poor are oppressed, and the judge himself (as the prophet saith) is partial in judgment. What then can we expect but some common plague, either of Nabuchodonosor, or Sanherib, or Antiochus, or some other scourge of mankind, which may once with sword and fire, famine and pestilence, purify this execrable land? What therefore the Lord hath taken away with Zwingli, and with him so many saints, so many honest, so many learned, so many patriots and senators, so many innocent citizens and countrymen, in one hour, it was no doubt done by an omen and divine counsel.

Interim vero nemo nisi impiissimus quisque doctrinam et vitam istorum propter supplicia posuit in dubium . seg.output: What else should I mention about John, son of Zachariah, who was born of women more holy than any other, and of Paul, our chosen vessel? The former was slain by the most impure Herod even in prison, with the advice of a most shameful harlot; the latter was beheaded by the most cruel robber, Domitius Nero, as an disturber of the public peace. Nevertheless, no one but the most impious has ever called in question the doctrine and lives of these men on account of their sufferings. Why, then, do our Zuinglians drag his death to the condemnation of his faith and doctrine, when it is sufficiently evident that nothing more is required of the pious? Or have they forgotten the words of the Lord: "If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you" [John 15:20]? And again: "The time will come when whoever kills you will think that he is doing God a service" [John 16:2]. Or are they ignorant that "we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God" [Acts 14:21]? Or will they preach the gospel to the world in such a manner that they suffer nothing, always pleasing everyone, offending no one, living in pleasure, and promising security to their followers? That would indeed be a new mode of preaching, unknown to the prophets and apostles. For they, incurring the hatred of all men, cried out: "If we had pleased men, we should not have been the servants of God" [Galatians 1:10]. And again: "They who seek to please men in the flesh compel you to be circumcised, only lest they should suffer persecution for the cross of Christ" [Galatians 6:12]. But if these men think otherwise, why, I pray, are we so vilely abused, and especially on this account, that we are afflicted by the enemies of truth, treated with reproach, stripped of our substance, scourged, and every day exposed to the danger of death? Why do they daily threaten the very survivors of this (as they call it) sect with destruction? As if they had found out some kind of doctrine, to which those that adhere may stand secure from the darts of death. But believe me, most illustrious prince, these are not our times that merit clemency and security; nor are we such at this day, who are able to bear free truth, or willing. Since, then, it is so well become us who presume to speak the truth, and the world (for none forbid the pious to be approved) that we have great reason to fear, that by flattery many things will be done, and by cowardly fear much more left undone, amongst us. And, to speak freely with you, most gracious prince, we have as great cause to fear, that our affairs will shortly come to that pass, that we shall wish ourselves with those, whom we now devotedly curse, intercepted by that Capellan disaster; and that we shall call them most happy, who have suffered bravely for truth and their country; whereas we shall be forced to endure more cruel things throughout Germany. And, would to God I were a false prophet. Yet the Scripture tells us, that in the days of Josiah a book of the law was found, and the true worship of God restored; yet notwithstanding, the most holy king Josiah was soon after slain by the most impious idolater Necho; though by the oracle of the Lord he had before received this assurance: "Because thou hast humbled thyself before me, and hast heard my words, I also have heard thee, and will gather thee to thy fathers, and thou shalt not see the evil that I will bring upon this place" [2 Chronicles 34:26-28]. For a few years after, the most royal city of Jerusalem, the admiration of all the world, was destroyed, and by the wicked plundered, burnt, and quite demolished; which the prophet Jeremiah gives us the reason of, in the 16th [11f]: "Because your fathers have forsaken me, saith the Lord, and have walked after other gods, and have served them, and have worshipped them, and have forsaken me, and have not kept my law. And you have done worse than your fathers; for, behold, ye walk every one after the imagination of his evil heart, that they may not hearken unto me" [Jeremiah 16:11f]. If we compare these times with ours, what, I pray, is more like? The law of the Lord is certainly restored, but the best of men presently perish. And what comes of it? The truth is indeed preached in some places, but it is contemned with God himself. For some of the prophets prophesy a lie in the pope's name, and others, who seem to stand for the truth, are too much silent in that part, where they should have been most vocal; where they sweetly and with great applause of the people comment on charity, meekness, and divine mercy; when it is to be handled of justice, and that severely, to reprove the crimes, by which the world is at this day so overspread. The magistrate himself, whose office it is to observe equity and justice, partly banishes and slays the innocent upon the name of truth, proscribes the truth itself, and lives upon the blood of the people; partly pretends religion, and so neglects judgment and justice, yea, and practises violence, receives persons, is given to drinking, whoring, luxury in apparel, gaming, immoderate hunting, pride, and pomp; and when there is any thing in the public treasury, devours it; then he raises new taxes, and engages the people in foreign wars and mischievous projects, which enfeeble both their bodies and estates. The people also cheat, lie, swear, and forswear, drink, and no less waste themselves in luxury; all which they had gotten by their wicked practices. In the mean time, we all comment sweetly on the gospel, but no man alters his life for the better; no man so much as he should accuse the crimes, and lay hold on and punish the offenders; what shall I say of monopolists, forestallers, farmers of the revenue, and usurers, who have so deeply rooted their iniquities, that you may sooner pluck up an old oak by the roots, than you can reduce them to order? These with impunity spoil all the world, all trading and treasuring is in their hands, and when they are thus lifted up by theft, fraud, and rapine, none of those who would be thought pillars of the Christian religion, take any effectual course with them. So that our matters are carried on by some invisible power, the poor are oppressed, and the judge (as the prophet speaks) is in a manner bribed in giving his sentence. What then is left for us, but some general plague, or the like of Nebuchadnezzar, Sanherib, Antiochus, or other such scourge of mankind, to wipe away this execrable land with sword and fire, famine and pestilence? What the Lord hath done in taking away Zuinglius, and with him so many holy, so many good, so many learned, so many noblemen and senators, so many innocent citizens and countrymen in a moment, no doubt it was done by a divine omen, and by some secret counsel of God's. For doubt- less, if we turn not, worse things will befall us.

Tollite iugum meum super vos et discite a me, quod mitis sim et humilis corde, et invenietis requiem animabus vestris. Iugum enim meum commodum est, et onus meum leve est» [Mt 11,28-30]. Equidem quod nos attinet, libere hoc de veritate et benignitate domini cum gratiarum actione referre possumus, quod ecclesiae nostrae in mediis afflictionum procellis nunquam defuit, sed perinde suos animavit, imo ne nunc quidem deserit, siquidem senatus noster perstat et prophetia , perstant leges quoque adversus papismum et luxum aeditae , perstat et populus. Atque utinam sic benefacere pergat dominus. Patri itaque tam potenti et benigno te quoque totum trade, veritatem eius cole, in hac persta huic immorere. Id si feceris, illud sane praestiteris, quod Paulus tota hac ad Hebraeos epistola ambit.
seg.output: Therefore, do not be discouraged by this disaster, but rather be encouraged by the holy teachings of your Lord, who says: "Come to me, all you who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls. For my yoke is easy and my burden is light" [Matthew 11:28-30]. We can testify, with great gratitude, to the truth and kindness of our Lord, that He has never abandoned our church in the midst of the storms of affliction, but has instead encouraged us, and even now He does not abandon us, for our senate stands, prophecy stands, the laws stand against papacy and luxury, and the people remain. May the Lord continue to be so merciful. Surrender yourself to this powerful and kind Father, honor His truth, and remain steadfast in this. If you do this, you will do that which Paul enjoins throughout his letter to the Hebrews.

seg.output:
Therefore, remember the wit of some, illustrious prince, the words of your Lord, with which he speaks to his people with the utmost respect and says: "Come to me all who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and lowly in heart; and you shall find rest for your souls. For my yoke is easy, and my burden is light" [Mt 11: 28-30]. Indeed, what concerns us, we can freely refer, with thanks, to the truth and kindness of the Lord, that our Church has never failed in the midst of storms of afflictions, but has instead encouraged its own, and even now does not abandon them, since our Senate persists, and so does the prophecy, the laws against Papism and luxury remain, and so does the people. And may the Lord continue to do such good. Therefore, dedicate yourself entirely to this powerful and kind Father, honor his truth, abide in this, cling to it. If you do this, you will certainly accomplish what Paul seeks throughout this Epistle to the Hebrews. Which we have wished to dedicate to your name, illustrated by our commentaries. May the Lord Jesus confirm you with his holy spirit. Amen.
Tiguri, 17 August 1532.
